entry.def: A peculiar larval form of Phoronis, a genus of marine worms, having a circle of ciliated tentacles.
A group of Cœlenterata, comprising the Anthozoa and Ctenophora. The sea anemone, or actinia, is a familiar example.
Of or pertaining to the Actinozoa.
One of the Actinozoa.
A kind of embryo of certain hydroids (Tubularia), having a stellate form.

entry.cs: Chose in action. Law See Chose. Quantity of action Physics the product of the mass of a body by the space it runs through, and its velocity.
entry.usage: In many cases action and act are synonymous; but some distinction is observable. Action involves the mode or process of acting, and is usually viewed as occupying some time in doing. Act has more reference to the effect, or the operation as complete.To poke the fire is an act, to reconcile friends who have quarreled is a praiseworthy action. C. J. Smith.
entry.ety: OF. action, L. actio, fr. agere to do. See Act

sn.def: A process or condition of acting or moving, as opposed to rest; the doing of something; exertion of power or force, as when one body acts on another; the effect of power exerted on one body by another; agency; activity; operation; as, the action of heat; a man of action.
sn.q: One wise in council, one in action brave.

sn.def: An act; a thing done; a deed; an enterprise. pl: Habitual deeds; hence, conduct; behavior; demeanor.
sn.q: The Lord is a Good of knowledge, and by him actions are weighed.

sn.def: The event or connected series of events, either real or imaginary, forming the subject of a play, poem, or other composition; the unfolding of the drama of events.
Movement; as, the horse has a spirited action .
Effective motion; also, mechanism; as, the breech action of a gun.
Any one of the active processes going on in an organism; the performance of a function; as, the action of the heart, the muscles, or the gastric juice.
Gesticulation; the external deportment of the speaker, or the suiting of his attitude, voice, gestures, and countenance, to the subject, or to the feelings.
The attitude or position of the several parts of the body as expressive of the sentiment or passion depicted.

sd.def: A suit or process, by which a demand is made of a right in a court of justice; in a broad sense, a judicial proceeding for the enforcement or protection of a right, the redress or prevention of a wrong, or the punishment of a public offense.
A right of action; as, the law gives an action for every claim.

sn.def: A share in the capital stock of a joint-stock company, or in the public funds; hence, in the plural, equivalent to stocks.
sn.q: The Euripus of funds and actions.

sn.def: An engagement between troops in war, whether on land or water; a battle; a fight; as, a general action, a partial action .
The mechanical contrivance by means of which the impulse of the player's finger is transmitted to the strings of a pianoforte or to the valve of an organ pipe.

entry.def: That may be the subject of an action or suit at law; as, to call a man a thief is actionable .
In an actionable manner.
A shareholder in joint-stock company.
Void of action.

sn.def: naval battle where Antony and Cleopatra were defeated by Octavian's fleet under Agrippa in 31 BC.

entry.def: To make active.

sn.def: treated with aeration and bacteria to aid decomposition; -- of sewage
made reactive or more reactive; -- of e.g. a molecule
rendered active; -- as e.g. radioactive or luminescent or photosensitive or conductive
set up and placed on active assignment
causing motion or action or change
same as activation{1}.

entry.note: certain devices, as bombs or artillery shells, are designed to be unable to operate until a specific action (activation or arming) is taken to make them operable.

sn.def: the process of making active.
making active and effective (as a bomb).
any agency bringing about activation; (Biol.) a molecule that increases the activity of an enzyme or a protein that increases the production of a gene product in DNA transcription.

cs.cd: money, or property that may readily be converted into money.

entry.ety: F. actif, L. activus, fr. agere to act

sn.def: Having the power or quality of acting; causing change; communicating action or motion; acting; -- opposed to passive, that receives; as, certain active principles; the powers of the mind.
Quick in physical movement; of an agile and vigorous body; nimble; as, an active child or animal.
sn.q: Active and nervous was his gait.

sn.def: In action; actually proceeding; working; in force; -- opposed to quiescent dormant, or extinct; as, active laws; active hostilities; an active volcano.
Given to action; constantly engaged in action; energetic; diligent; busy; -- opposed to dull sluggish indolent, or inert; as, an active man of business; active mind; active zeal.
Requiring or implying action or exertion; -- opposed to sedentary or to tranquil; as, active employment or service; active scenes.
Given to action rather than contemplation; practical; operative; -- opposed to speculative or theoretical; as, an active rather than a speculative statesman.
Brisk; lively; as, an active demand for corn.
Implying or producing rapid action; as, an active disease; an active remedy.

sd.def: Applied to a form of the verb; -- opposed to passive. See Active voice, under Voice.
Applied to verbs which assert that the subject acts upon or affects something else; transitive.
Applied to all verbs that express action as distinct from mere existence or state.
sd.syn: Agile; alert; brisk; vigorous; nimble; lively; quick; sprightly; prompt; energetic.

sn.def: In an active manner; nimbly; briskly; energetically; also, by one's own action; voluntarily, not passively.
In an active signification; as, a word used actively .

entry.def: The quality of being active; nimbleness; quickness of motion; activity.

sn.def: a policy of taking direct and militant action to achieve a political or social goal.
one who is aggressively active on behalf of a cause.
advocating a cause or engaged in activism

entries.entry:
Ac*tiv"i*ty n.; pl.Activities. Cf. F. activité, LL. activitas
The state or quality of being active; nimbleness; agility; vigorous action or operation; energy; active force; as, an increasing variety of human activities . Theactivityof toil. Liveliness; briskness; quickness.

entry.def: Without action or spirit.

entry.ety: OF. aketon auqueton, F. hoqueton, a quilted jacket, fr. Sp. alcoton algodon, cotton. Cf. Cotton
entry.def: A stuffed jacket worn under the mail, or (later) a jacket plated with mail.

entry.ety: L. actor, fr. agere to act

sn.def: One who acts, or takes part in any affair; a doer.
A theatrical performer; a stageplayer.
sn.q: After a well graced actor leaves the stage.

sd.def: An advocate or proctor in civil courts or causes.
One who institutes a suit; plaintiff or complainant.

sn.def: A female actor or doer.
A female stageplayer; a woman who acts a part.
one of the books of the Christian New Testament describing the activities of Christ's apostles after his death.

entry.cs: Actual cautery. See under Cautery. Actual sin Theol that kind of sin which is done by ourselves in contradistinction to “original sin.”
entry.ety: OE. actuel, F. actuel, L. actualis, fr. agere to do, act

sn.def: Involving or comprising action; active.
sn.q: Her walking and other actual performances.
Let your holy and pious intention be actual; that is . . . by a special prayer or action, . . . given to God.

sn.def: Existing in act or reality; really acted or acting; in fact; real; -- opposed to potential possible virtual speculative conceivable theoretical, or nominal; as, the actual cost of goods; the actual case under discussion.
In action at the time being; now exiting; present; as the actual situation of the country.
sn.syn: Real; genuine; positive; certain. See Real.

entry.def: Something actually received; real, as distinct from estimated, receipts.
entry.q: The accounts of revenues supplied . . . were not real receipts: not, in financial language, “actuals,” but only Egyptian budget estimates.

entry.def: One who deals with or considers actually existing facts and conditions, rather than fancies or theories; a realist; -- opposed to idealist.

entries.entry: Ac`tu*al"i*ty n.; pl.Actualities. The state of being actual; reality; as, the actuality of God's nature.

entry.def: A making actual or really existent; giving the appearance of reality.
To make actual; to realize in action.
changed from potential to actual; as, saw his worst fears actualized .

sn.def: Actively.
sn.q: Neitheractually. . . nor passively.

sn.def: In act or in fact; really; in truth; positively.

entry.def: Quality of being actual; actuality.
Of or pertaining to actuaries; as, the actuarial value of an annuity.

entries.entry:
Ac"tu*a*ry n.; pl.Actuaries. L. actuarius copyist, clerk, fr. actus, p. p. of agere to do, act
Law A registrar or clerk; -- used originally in courts of civil law jurisdiction, but in Europe used for a clerk or registrar generally.
The computing official of an insurance company; one whose profession it is to calculate for insurance companies the risks and premiums for life, fire, and other insurances.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Actuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Actuating
entry.ety: LL. actuatus, p. p. of actuare, fr. L. actus act

sn.def: To put into action or motion; to move or incite to action; to influence actively; to move as motives do; -- more commonly used of persons.
sn.q: Wings, which others were contriving to actuate by the perpetual motion.
Men of the greatest abilities are most fired with ambition; and, on the contrary, mean and narrow minds are the least actuated by it.

sn.def: To carry out in practice; to perform.
sn.q: Toactuatewhat you command.
sn.syn: To move; impel; incite; rouse; instigate; animate.

entry.ety: LL. actuatus, p. p. of actuare
entry.def: Put in action; actuated.

sn.def: moved to action
causing motion or action or change

entry.def: A bringing into action; movement.
One who actuates, or puts into action.
Very active.
Abundant activity.
Action.

entry.ety: A desid. of L. agere actum, to act
entry.def: Tendency or impulse to act.
entry.q: Acturience, or desire of action, in one form or another, whether as restlessness, ennui, dissatisfaction, or the imagination of something desirable.

entry.def: To sharpen; to make pungent; to quicken.
entry.q: Toacuatethe blood.

entry.def: Sharpened; sharp-pointed.
Act of sharpening.

entry.ety: L. acutus, as if acuitus, p. p. of acuere to sharpen
entry.def: The act of sharpening.
Sharpness or acuteness, as of a needle, wit, etc.

entry.ety: L. aculeus, dim. of acus needle
entry.def: A small spiny outgrowth on the wings of certain insects.

entry.ety: L. aculeatus, fr. aculeus, dim. of acus needle

sn.def: Having a sting; covered with prickles; sharp like a prickle.
Having prickles, or sharp points; beset with prickles.
Severe or stinging; incisive.

entry.def: Having a sharp point; armed with prickles; prickly; aculeate.
Like a prickle.
Having small prickles or sharp points.
Aculeate.

entries.entry:
A*cu"le*us A*cu"le*us n.; pl.Aculei. L., dim. of acus needle
Bot A prickle growing on the bark, as in some brambles and roses.
Zoöl A sting.

entry.ety: L. acumen, fr. acuere to sharpen. Cf. Acute
entry.def: Quickness of perception or discernment; penetration of mind; the faculty of nice discrimination.

entry.ety: L. acuminatus, p. p. of acuminare to sharpen, fr. acumen. See Acumen
entry.def: Tapering to a point; pointed; as, acuminate leaves, teeth, etc.
To render sharp or keen.
entry.q: Toacuminateeven despair.

entry.def: To end in, or come to, a sharp point.
entry.q: Acuminatingin a cone of prelacy.

entry.def: A sharpening; termination in a sharp point; a tapering point.
Terminating in a flat, narrow end.
Characterized by acumen; keen.

entry.ety: L. acus needle + premere pressum, to press
entry.def: A mode of arresting hemorrhage resulting from wounds or surgical operations, by passing under the divided vessel a needle, the ends of which are left exposed externally on the cutaneous surface.
See Acupuncture.

entries.entry:
Ac`u*punc"ture n. L. acus needle + punctura a pricking, fr. pungere to prick: cf. F. acuponcture
Pricking with a needle; a needle prick. Specifically Med: The insertion of needles into the living tissues for remedial purposes.

entry.def: To treat with acupuncture.
See Accustomance.
Acute-angled.

cs.cd: an angle less than a right angle.

entry.ety: L. acutus, p. p. of acuere to sharpen, fr. a root ak to be sharp. Cf. Ague Cute Edge

sn.def: Sharp at the end; ending in a sharp point; pointed; -- opposed to blunt or obtuse; as, an acute angle; an acute leaf.
Having nice discernment; perceiving or using minute distinctions; penetrating; clever; shrewd; -- opposed to dull or stupid; as, an acute observer; acute remarks, or reasoning.
Having nice or quick sensibility; susceptible to slight impressions; acting keenly on the senses; sharp; keen; intense; as, a man of acute eyesight, hearing, or feeling; acute pain or pleasure.
High, or shrill, in respect to some other sound; -- opposed to grave or low; as, an acute tone or accent.
Attended with symptoms of some degree of severity, and coming speedily to a crisis; -- opposed to chronic; as, an acute disease.
sn.syn: Subtile; ingenious; sharp; keen; penetrating; sagacious; sharp-witted; shrewd; discerning; discriminating. See Subtile.

entry.def: To give an acute sound to; as, he acutes his rising inflection too much.
Having acute angles; as, an acute-angled triangle, a triangle with every one of its angles less than a right angle.
In an acute manner; sharply; keenly; with nice discrimination.

sn.def: The quality of being acute or pointed; sharpness; as, the acuteness of an angle.

The faculty of nice discernment or perception; acumen; keenness; sharpness; sensitiveness; -- applied to the senses, or the understanding. By acuteness of feeling, we perceive small objects or slight impressions: by acuteness of intellect, we discern nice distinctions.
sn.q: Perhaps, also, he felt his professional acuteness interested in bringing it to a successful close.

sn.def: Shrillness; high pitch; -- said of sounds.
Violence of a disease, which brings it speedily to a crisis.
sn.syn: Penetration; sagacity; keenness; ingenuity; shrewdness; subtlety; sharp-wittedness.

entry.def: Having sharp-pointed leaves.
Having acute lobes, as some leaves.

entry.note: [Not in Stedman -- an obsolete procedure?]
entry.def: The twisting of an artery with a needle to arrest hemorrhage.

entries.entry:
A*cyc"lic a. Pref. a- not + cyclic
Not cyclic; not disposed in cycles or whorls; as: Bot Of a flower, having its parts inserted spirally on the receptacle. Org. Chem Having an open-chain structure; aliphatic.

entry.def: An acid radical, as acetyl, malonyl, or benzoyl. An acyl radical can be depicted as R-CO-, where -CO- is the carbonyl group, and R is the group that characterizes the acyl moiety.

entries.entry:
Ad- Ad-. A Latin preposition, signifying to. See At
As a prefix ad- assumes the forms ac- af- ag- al- an- ap- ar- as- at-, assimilating the d with the first letter of the word to which ad- is prefixed. It remains unchanged before vowels, and before dhjmv. Examples: adduce, adhere, adjacent, admit, advent, accord, affect, aggregate, allude, annex, appear, etc. It becomes ac- before qu, as in acquiesce.

entry.ety: L. adactus, p. p. of adigere
entry.def: To compel; to drive.
Without fingers or without toes.
Without claws on the feet (of crustaceous animals).

sn.def: the Babylonian god of storms and wind.

entry.ety: F. adage, fr. L. adagium; ad + the root of L. aio I say
entry.def: An old saying, which has obtained credit by long use; a proverb.
entry.q: Letting “I dare not” wait upon “I would,” Like the poor cat i' the adage.
entry.syn: Axiom; maxim; aphorism; proverb; saying; saw; apothegm. See Axiom.

entry.def: Pertaining to an adage; proverbial.
entry.q: Adagialverse.

entry.ety: It. adagio; adL. ad) at + agio convenience, leisure, ease. See Agio
entry.def: Slow; slowly, leisurely, and gracefully. When repeated, adagio adagio, it directs the movement to be very slow.
A piece of music in adagio time; a slow movement; as, an adagio of Haydn.

entry.cs: Adam's ale water. Coll Adam's apple. Bot A species of banana (Musa paradisiaca). It attains a height of twenty feet or more. Paxton. A species of lime (Citris limetta). The projection formed by the thyroid cartilage in the neck. It is particularly prominent in males, and is so called from a notion that it was caused by the forbidden fruit (an apple) sticking in the throat of our first parent. Adam's flannel Bot the mullein (Verbascum thapsus). Adam's needle Bot the popular name of a genus (Yucca) of liliaceous plants.

sn.def: The name given in the Bible to the first man, the progenitor of the human race.
“Original sin;” human frailty.
sn.q: And whipped the offending Adam out of him.

sn.def: same as adamancy.
obstinacy.
North American orchid (Aplectrum hyemale) bearing a single leaf and yellowish-brown flowers.

entry.ety: OE. adamaunt adamant, diamond, magnet, OF. adamant, L. adamas adamantis, the hardest metal, fr. Gr. 'ada`mas -antos; 'a priv. + dama^,n to tame, subdue. In OE., from confusion with L. adamare to love, be attached to, the word meant also magnet, as in OF. and LL. See Diamond Tame

sn.def: A stone imagined by some to be of impenetrable hardness; a name given to the diamond and other substances of extreme hardness; but in modern mineralogy it has no technical signification. It is now a rhetorical or poetical name for the embodiment of impenetrable hardness.
sn.q: Opposed the rocky orb Of tenfold adamant, his ample shield.

sn.def: Lodestone; magnet.
sn.q: A greatadamantof acquaintance.
As true to thee as steel to adamant.

entry.def: Of adamant; hard as adamant.

sn.def: Made of adamant, or having the qualities of adamant; incapable of being broken, dissolved, or penetrated; as, adamantine bonds or chains.
Like the diamond in hardness or luster.

entry.def: Next to the ambulacra; as, the adambulacral ossicles of the starfish.

cs.cd: a name given to common red clay, from a notion that Adam means red earth.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Adam, or resembling him.

sn.def: A descendant of Adam; a human being.
One of a sect of visionaries, who, professing to imitate the state of Adam, discarded the use of dress in their assemblies.

entries.entry: Ad"am's ap"ple. See under Adam.

entry.def: Dancing.
Dangling.

A genus of great trees related to the Bombax. There are two species, Adansonia digitata, the baobab or monkey-bread of Africa and India, and Adansonia Gregorii, the sour gourd or cream-of-tartar tree of Australia. Both have a trunk of moderate height, but of enormous diameter, and a wide-spreading head. The fruit is oblong, and filled with pleasantly acid pulp. The wood is very soft, and the bark is used by the natives for making ropes and cloth.

sn.def: a demigod or first man: "seed of mankind"; sometimes identified with Adam.

extinct small mostly diurnal lower primates that fed on leaves and fruit; abundant in North America and Europe 30 to 50 million years ago; their descendents probably include the lemurs and lorises; some authorities consider them ancestral to anthropoids but others consider them only cousins.

entry.def: Fitted; suited.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adapted; p. pr. & vb. n. Adapting
entry.ety: L. adaptare; ad + aptare to fit; cf. F. adapter. See Apt Adept
entry.def: To make suitable; to fit, or suit; to adjust; to alter so as to fit for a new use; -- sometimes followed by to or for.
entry.q: For nature, always in the right, To your decays adapts my sight.
Appeals adapted to his [man's] whole nature.
Streets ill adapted for the residence of wealthy persons.

entry.def: The quality of being adaptable; suitableness.
entry.q: Generaladaptabilityfor every purpose.

entry.def: Capable of being adapted.

sn.def: The act or process of adapting, or fitting; or the state of being adapted or fitted; fitness.
sn.q: Adaptationof the means to the end.

sn.def: The result of adapting; an adapted form.

entry.def: Adaptive.

sn.def: having a capacity for adaptation. Opposed to maladaptive.

entry.def: The state or quality of being adapted; suitableness; special fitness.

sn.def: One who adapts.
A connecting tube; an adopter.

entry.def: Adaptation.
Suited, given, or tending, to adaptation; characterized by adaptation; capable of adapting.
The quality of being adaptive; capacity to adapt.

an optical system used in some telescopes since the 1980's which rapidly changes the shape of the primary reflecting mirror to adjust for distortions of light which are caused by atmospheric turbulence. By reducing the distortions caused by the atmosphere, telescopes fitted with such optics can achieve a higher resolving power than normal telescopes with static mirrors.

sn.def: the evolutionary generation of multiple specialized life forms from one ancestral form, evidenced in the fossil record. The inverse of extinction.

entry.def: In a suitable manner.
Adaptedness.
Adaptive.
The twelfth month of the Hebrew ecclesiastical year, and the sixth of the civil. It corresponded nearly with March.
A saltish concretion on reeds and grass in marshy grounds in Galatia. It is soft and porous, and was formerly used for cleansing the skin from freckles and tetters, and also in leprosy.
A fine cotton cloth of India.

entry.ety: OE. adaunten to overpower, OF. adonter; àL. ad) + donter, F. dompter. See Daunt
entry.def: To daunt; to subdue; to mitigate.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. adawe of dawe, AS. of dagum from days, i. e., from life, out of life
entry.def: To subdue; to daunt.
entry.q: The sight whereof did greatly him adaw.

entry.ety: OE. adawen to wake; pref. a-cf. Goth. us-, Ger. er-) + dawen dagon, to dawn. See Daw
entry.def: To awaken; to arouse.
entry.q: A man that waketh of his sleep He may not suddenly well taken keep Upon a thing, ne seen it parfitly Till that he be adawed verily.

entry.ety: Pref. a-for on) + day; the final s was orig. a genitive ending, afterwards forming adverbs
entry.def: By day, or every day; in the daytime.

entries.entry: Ad cap*tan"dum Ad cap*tan"dum. L., for catching A phrase used adjectively sometimes of meretricious attempts to catch or win popular favor.

entry.usage: We add by bringing things together so as to form a whole. We join by putting one thing to another in close or continuos connection. We annex by attaching some adjunct to a larger body. We unite by bringing things together so that their parts adhere or intermingle. Things coalesce by coming together or mingling so as to form one organization. To add quantities; to join houses; to annex territory; to unite kingdoms; to make parties coalesce.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Added; p. pr. & vb. n. Adding
entry.ety: L. addere; ad + dare to give, put. Cf. Date Do

sn.def: To give by way of increased possession (to any one); to bestow (on).
sn.q: The Lord shall add to me another son.

sn.def: To join or unite, as one thing to another, or as several particulars, so as to increase the number, augment the quantity, enlarge the magnitude, or so as to form into one aggregate. Hence: To sum up; to put together mentally; as, to add numbers; to add up a column.
sn.q: Back to thy punishment, False fugitive, and to thy speed add wings.
As easily as he can add together the ideas of two days or two years.

sn.def: To append, as a statement; to say further.
sn.q: He added that he would willingly consent to the entire abolition of the tax.
sn.syn: To Add Join Annex Unite Coalesce.

sn.def: To make an addition. To add to, to augment; to increase; as, it adds to our anxiety.
sn.q: I willaddto your yoke.

sn.def: To perform the arithmetical operation of addition; as, he adds rapidly.

entry.def: Addible.

entry.note: ☞ It is now believed to be the Strepsicerostwisted horn) of the ancients. By some it is thought to be the pygarg of the Bible.
entry.def: One of the largest African antelopes (HippotragusnasomaculatusorOryx nasomaculatus).

entry.sn: being in addition [to something elseNarrower terms: accessorial additional, further(prenominal), more(prenominal) --- (used with mass nouns: "takes on added significance"; "asked for additional help"; "we have further information"; "there will be further delays"; "kids have more fun than anybody")Narrower terms: another(prenominal), other(prenominal), else(postnominal), extra, intercalary] [Narrower terms: superimposed ] [Narrower terms: supplementary, supplemental ] [Narrower terms: value-added subtracted

entry.def: To award; to adjudge.
entry.q: Unto him they didaddeemthe prise.

sn.def: a number that is added to another number.

entries.entry:
Ad*den"dum Ad*den"dum
Addendum circle Mech the circle which may be described around a circular spur wheel or gear wheel, touching the crests or tips of the teeth. Rankine.
n.; pl.Addenda. L., fr. addere to add A thing to be added; an appendix or addition.

entry.def: One who, or that which, adds; esp., a machine for adding numbers.

entry.note: ☞ In the sculptures the appellation is given to several venomous serpents, -- sometimes to the horned viper (Cerastles).
entry.ety: OE. addere naddere eddre, AS. nædre, adder, snake; akin to OS. nadra, OHG. natra natara, Ger. natter, Goth. nadrs, Icel. naðr, masc., naðra, fem.: cf. W. neidr, Gorn. naddyr, Ir. nathair, L. natrix, water snake. An adder is for a nadder

sn.def: A serpent.
sn.q: Theeddreseide to the woman.

sd.def: A small venomous serpent of the genus Vipera. The common European adder is the Vipera berusorPelias berus. The puff adders of Africa are species of Clotho.
In America, the term is commonly applied to several harmless snakes, as the milk adder puffing adder, etc.
Same as Sea Adder.

entries.entry: Ad"der fly/. A dragon fly.

entry.def: A genus of ferns (Ophioglossum), whose seeds are produced on a spike resembling a serpent's tongue.
The yellow dogtooth violet.
The common bistort or snakeweed (Polygonum bistorta).
The quantity of being addible; capability of addition.
Capable of being added.
entry.q: Addiblenumbers.

entry.def: See Adze.
Addicted; devoted.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Addicted; p. pr. & vb. n. Addicting
entry.ety: L. addictus, p. p. of addicere to adjudge, devote; ad + dicere to say. See Diction

sn.def: To apply habitually; to devote; to habituate; -- with to.
sn.q: Theyaddictthemselves to the civil law.
He is addicted to his study.
That part of mankind that addict their minds to speculations.
His genius addicted him to the study of antiquity.
A man gross . . . and addicted to low company.

sn.def: To adapt; to make suitable; to fit.
sn.q: The land about is exceedingly addicted to wood, but the coldness of the place hinders the growth.
sn.syn: Addict Devote Consecrate Dedicate. Addict was formerly used in a good sense; as, addicted to letters; but is now mostly employed in a bad sense or an indifferent one; as, addicted to vice; addicted to sensual indulgence. “Addicted to staying at home.” J. S. Mill. Devote is always taken in a good sense, expressing habitual earnestness in the pursuit of some favorite object; as, devoted to science. Consecrate and dedicate express devotion of a higher kind, involving religious sentiment; as, consecrated to the service of the church; dedicated to God.

entry.def: The quality or state of being addicted; attachment.
The state of being addicted; devotion; inclination.
entry.q: Hisaddictionwas to courses vain.

entries.entry: Ad"di*son's dis*ease". Named from Thomas Addison, M. D., of London, who first described it Med A morbid condition causing a peculiar brownish discoloration of the skin, and thought, at one time, to be due to disease of the suprarenal capsules (two flat triangular bodies covering the upper part of the kidneys), but now known not to be dependent upon this causes exclusively. It is usually fatal.

entry.ety: L. additamentum, fr. additus, p. p. of addere to add
entry.def: An addition, or a thing added.
entry.q: My persuasion that the latter verses of the chapter were an additament of a later age.

cs.cd: that kind of addition of two lines, or vectors, AB and BC, by which their sum is regarded as the line, or vector, AC.

entry.ety: F. addition, L. additio, fr. addere to add

sn.def: The act of adding two or more things together; -- opposed to subtraction or diminution.
sn.q: This endlessadditionor addibility of numbers.

sn.def: Anything added; increase; augmentation; as, a piazza is an addition to a building.
That part of arithmetic which treats of adding numbers.
A dot at the right side of a note as an indication that its sound is to be lengthened one half.
A title annexed to a man's name, to identify him more precisely; as, John Doe, Esq .; Richard Roe, Gent.; Robert Dale, Mason; Thomas Way, of New York; a mark of distinction; a title.
Something added to a coat of arms, as a mark of honor; -- opposed to abatement.

entry.def: Added; supplemental; in the way of an addition.
Something added.
By way of addition.
Additional.
Additive.
Proper to be added; positive; -- opposed to subtractive.
Tending to add; making some addition.

sn.def: Liquid filth; mire.
Lees; dregs.

entry.def: Having lost the power of development, and become rotten, as eggs; putrid. Hence: Unfruitful or confused, as brains; muddled.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Addled; p. pr. & vb. n. Addling
entry.def: To make addle; to grow addle; to muddle; as, he addled his brain.
entry.q: Their eggs wereaddled.

entry.ety: OE. adlen adilen, to gain, acquire; prob. fr. Icel. öðlask to acquire property, akin to oðal property. Cf. Allodial

sn.def: To earn by labor.
To thrive or grow; to ripen.
sn.q: Kill ivy, else tree will addle no more.

entry.def: A foolish or dull-witted fellow.
Dull-witted; stupid.
entry.q: Theaddle-brainedOberstein.
Dull and addle-pated.

entry.def: Stupidity.
Earnings.
To adjudge.

entry.ety: L. ad + dorsum, back: cf. F. adossé
entry.def: Set or turned back to back.

entry.cs: To address one's self to. To prepare one's self for; to apply one's self to. To direct one's speech or discourse to. To address the ball Golf to take aim at the ball, adjusting the grip on the club, the attitude of the body, etc., to a convenient position.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Addressed -drĕst"; p. pr. & vb. n. Addressing
entry.ety: OE. adressen to raise erect, adorn, OF. adrecier, to straighten, address, F. adresser, fr. àL. ad) + OF. drecier, F. dresser, to straighten, arrange. See Dress v.

sn.def: To aim; to direct.
sn.q: And this good knight his way with me addrest.

sn.def: To prepare or make ready.
sn.q: His foe was soon addressed.
Turnus addressed his men to single fight.
The five foolish virgins addressed themselves at the noise of the bridegroom's coming.

sn.def: Reflexively: To prepare one's self; to apply one's skill or energies (to some object); to betake.
sn.q: These men addressed themselves to the task.

sn.def: To clothe or array; to dress.
sn.q: Tecla . . . addressed herself in man's apparel.

sn.def: To direct, as words (to any one or any thing); to make, as a speech, petition, etc. (to any one, an audience).
sn.q: The young hero had addressed his players to him for his assistance.

sn.def: To direct speech to; to make a communication to, whether spoken or written; to apply to by words, as by a speech, petition, etc., to speak to; to accost.
sn.q: Are not your orders to address the senate?
The representatives of the nation addressed the king.

sn.def: To direct in writing, as a letter; to superscribe, or to direct and transmit; as, he addressed a letter.
To make suit to as a lover; to court; to woo.
To consign or intrust to the care of another, as agent or factor; as, the ship was addressed to a merchant in Baltimore.

entry.note: ☞ The intransitive uses come from the dropping out of the reflexive pronoun.

sn.def: To prepare one's self.
sn.q: Let usaddressto tend on Hector's heels.

sn.def: To direct speech.
sn.q: Young Turnus to the beauteous maid addrest.

entry.ety: Cf. F. adresse. See Address v. t.

sn.def: Act of preparing one's self.
Act of addressing one's self to a person; verbal application.

A formal communication, either written or spoken; a discourse; a speech; a formal application to any one; a petition; a formal statement on some subject or special occasion; as, an address of thanks, an address to the voters.
Direction or superscription of a letter, or the name, title, and place of residence of the person addressed.
Manner of speaking to another; delivery; as, a man of pleasing or insinuating address .
Attention in the way one's addresses to a lady.
Skill; skillful management; dexterity; adroitness.
sn.syn: Speech; discourse; harangue; oration; petition; lecture; readiness; ingenuity; tact; adroitness.

entry.sn: marked with a destination; -- of mailNarrower terms: self-addressed unaddressed

entry.def: One to whom anything is addressed.
The act of addressing or directing one's course.

sn.def: a printer that automatically prints addresses on letters for mailing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adduced; p. pr. & vb. n. Adducing
entry.ety: L. adducere adductum, to lead or bring to; ad + ducere to lead. See Duke, and cf. Adduct
entry.def: To bring forward or offer, as an argument, passage, or consideration which bears on a statement or case; to cite; to allege.
entry.q: Reasons . . . were adduced on both sides.
Enough could not be adduced to satisfy the purpose of illustration.
entry.syn: To present; allege; advance; cite; quote; assign; urge; name; mention.

entry.ety: L. addunces, p. pr. of adducere
entry.def: Bringing together or towards a given point; -- a word applied to those muscles of the body which pull one part towards another. Opposed to abducent.
One who adduces.
Capable of being adduced.
entry.q: Proofs innumerable, and in every imaginable manner diversified, are adducible.

entry.ety: L. adductus, p. p. of adducere. See Adduce
entry.def: To draw towards a common center or a middle line.

sn.def: The act of adducing or bringing forward.
sn.q: An adduction of facts gathered from various quarters.

sn.def: The action by which the parts of the body are drawn towards its axis]; -- opposed to abduction.

entry.def: Adducing, or bringing towards or to something.

A muscle which draws a limb or part of the body toward the middle line of the body, or closes extended parts of the body; -- opposed to abductor; as, the adductor of the eye, which turns the eye toward the nose.
entry.q: In the bivalve shells, the muscles which close the values of the shell are called adductor muscles.

entry.ety: Like F. adoucir; fr. L. ad. + dulcis sweet
entry.def: To sweeten; to soothe.
To revoke, as a legacy, grant, etc., or to satisfy it by some other gift.

Applied to sexual zooids of hydroids, that have a saclike form and do not become free; -- opposed to phanerocodonic.
An animal having feet that are not apparent.
A “brotherhood,” or collection of stamens in a bundle;used in composition, as in the class names, Monadelphia, Diadelphia, etc.
Having coalescent or clustered filaments; -- said of stamens; as, adelphous stamens. Usually in composition; as, monadelphous .

Combining forms of the Greek word for gland; -- used in words relating to the structure, diseases, etc., of the glands.

Shaped like a gland; adenoid.
Glandular inflammation.
Pertaining to adenography.
That part of anatomy which describes the glands.
A swelling produced by overgrowth of the adenoid tissue in the roof of the pharynx; -- usually in pl.
Glandlike; glandular.
Pertaining to adenology.
The part of physiology that treats of the glands.

entries.entry: A"den ul"cer. So named after Aden, a seaport in Southern Arabia, where it occurs Med A disease endemic in various parts of tropical Asia, due to a specific microörganism which produces chronic ulcers on the limbs. It is often fatal. Called also Cochin China ulcer Persian ulcer tropical ulcer, etc.

entry.def: Animal fat; lard.

entry.ety: L. adeptus obtained (sc. artem), �he who has obtained an art, p. p. of adipsci to arrive �at, to obtain; ad + apisci to pursue. See Apt, and cf. Adapt

The state or quality of being adequate, proportionate, or sufficient; a sufficiency for a particular purpose; as, the adequacy of supply to the expenditure.

entry.ety: L. adaequatus, p. p. of adaequare to make equal to; ad + aequare to make equal, aequus equal. See Equal

entry.q: Ireland had no adequate champion.
entry.syn: Proportionate; commensurate; sufficient; suitable; competent; capable.

To equal.

The quality of being adequate; suitableness; sufficiency; adequacy.
The act of equalizing; act or result of making adequate; an equivalent.

See Affiliation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adhered; p. pr. & vb. n. Adhering
entry.ety: L. adhaerere adhaesum; ad + haerere to stick: cf. F. adhérer. See Aghast

sn.def: To stick fast or cleave, as a glutinous substance does; to become joined or united; as, wax to the finger; the lungs sometimes adhere to the pleura.
To hold, be attached, or devoted; to remain fixed, either by personal union or conformity of faith, principle, or opinion; as, men adhere to a party, a cause, a leader, a church.
To be consistent or coherent; to be in accordance; to agree.
sn.q: Nor time nor place did thenadhere.
Every thingadherestogether.
sn.syn: To attach; stick; cleave; cling; hold

entry.usage: These words, which were once freely interchanged, are now almost entirely separated. Adherence is no longer used to denote physical union, but is applied, to mental states or habits; as, a strict adherence to one's duty; close adherence to the argument, etc. Adhesion is now confined chiefly to the physical sense, except in the phrase “To give in one's adhesion to a cause or a party.”

sn.def: The quality or state of adhering.
The state of being fixed in attachment; fidelity; steady attachment; adhesion; as, adherence to a party or to opinions.
The state or quality of being adherent; adherence.
That which adheres.

entry.ety: L. adhaerens -entis, p. pr.: cf. F. adhérent

sn.def: Sticking; clinging; adhering.
Attached as an attribute or circumstance.
Congenitally united with an organ of another kind, as calyx with ovary, or stamens with petals.
One who adheres; one who adheres; one who follows a leader, party, or profession; a follower, or partisan; a believer in a particular faith or church.
That which adheres; an appendage.

entry.def: In an adherent manner.
One who adheres; an adherent.

entry.ety: L. adhaesio, fr. adhaerere: cf. F. adhésion

The union of parts which are separate in other plants, or in younger states of the same plant.

entry.cs: Adhesive attraction. Physics See Attraction .Adhesive inflammation Surg that kind of inflammation which terminates in the reunion of divided parts without suppuration. Adhesive plaster a sticking; a plaster containing resin, wax, litharge, and olive oil.

Apt or tending to adhere; clinging.

entry.def: In an adhesive manner.

sn.def: The quality of sticking or adhering; stickiness; tenacity of union.
Propensity to form and maintain attachments to persons, and to promote social intercourse.

To attach; to affix.

entry.def: Good-by; farewell; an expression of kind wishes at parting.

Becoming fatty.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fatty or oily substances; -- applied to certain acids obtained from fats by the action of nitric acid.

an aliphatic dicarboxylic acid (HO.CO.(CH2)4.CO.OH), containing six carbon atoms in a linear chain. It is found in beet juice. It is used in the manufacture of synthetic plastics such as Nylon, as well as other products.

The act or process of changing into adipocere.

entry.def: A soft, unctuous, or waxy substance, of a light brown color, into which the fat and muscle tissue of dead bodies sometimes are converted, by long immersion in water or by burial in moist places. It is a result of fatty degeneration.
Having the form or appearance of adipocere; as, an adipoceriform tumor.
Like adipocere.
Producing fat.

entry.ety: NL.; L. adeps adipis, fat + Gr. � a loosing

entry.ety: L. adeps adipis, fat + Gr. � to loose
entry.def: Hydrolyzing fats; converting neutral fats into glycerin and free fatty acids, esp. by the action of an enzyme; as, adipolytic action. Contrast saponify, to hydrolyze fat by the action of an alkali.

that form of animal tissue which forms or contains fat.

entry.ety: L. aditus, fr. adire �aitum, to go to; ad + ire to go

sn.def: An entrance or passage. Specifically: The nearly horizontal opening by which a mine is entered, or by which water and ores are carried away; -- called also drift and tunnel.
Admission; approach; access.
sn.q: Yourself and yours shall have Free adit.

sn.def: one of 7 to 12 sons of Aditi; gods of celestial light.
The state or attribute of being adjacent or contiguous; contiguity; the attribute of being so near as to be touching; as, the adjacency of lands or buildings.
That which is adjacent.

entry.cs: Adjacent or contiguous angle . Geom See Angle.
entry.usage: Adjacent Adjoining Contiguous. Things are adjacent when they lie close each other, not necessary in actual contact; as, adjacent fields, adjacent villages, etc. I find that all Europe with her adjacent isles is peopled with Christians. Howell. Things are adjoining when they meet at some line or point of junction; as, adjoining farms, an adjoining highway. What is spoken of as contiguous should touch with some extent of one side or the whole of it; as, a row of contiguous buildings; a wood contiguous to a plain.
entry.ety: L. adjacens -centis, p. pr. of adjacere to lie near; ad + jacēre to lie: cf. F. adjacent
entry.def: Lying near, close, or contiguous; neighboring; bordering on; as, a field adjacent to the highway.
entry.q: Theadjacentforest.

entry.def: That which is adjacent.
So as to be adjacent.

entry.ety: L. adjectus, p. p. of adjicere to throw to, to add to; ad + jacĕre to throw. See Jet a shooting forth
entry.def: To add or annex; to join.

entry.ety: L. adjectio, fr. adjicere: cf. F. adjection. See Adject
entry.def: The act or mode of adding; also, the thing added.
Pertaining to adjection; that is, or may be, annexed.
Added; additional.
Of or relating to the relating to the adjective; of the nature of an adjective; adjective.
As, or in the manner of, an adjective; adjectively.

cs.cd: a color which requires to be fixed by some mordant or base to give it permanency.

sn.def: Added to a substantive as an attribute; of the nature of an adjunct; as, an adjective word or sentence.
Not standing by itself; dependent.
Relating to procedure.
sn.q: The whole English law, substantive andadjective.

entry.ety: L. adjectivumsc. nomen), neut. of adjectivus that is added, fr. adjicere: cf. F. adjectif. See Adject

sn.def: A word used with a noun, or substantive, to express a quality of the thing named, or something attributed to it, or to limit or define it, or to specify or describe a thing, as distinct from something else. Thus, in phrase, “a wise ruler,” wise is the adjective, expressing a property of ruler.
A dependent; an accessory.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adjectived; p. pr. & vb. n. Adjectiving
entry.def: To make an adjective of; to form or change into an adjective.
entry.q: Language has as much occasion to adjective the distinct signification of the verb, and to adjective also the mood, as it has to adjective time. It has . . . adjectived all three.

entry.def: In the manner of an adjective; as, a word used adjectively .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adjoined; p. pr. & vb. n. Adjoining
entry.ety: OE. ajoinen, OF. ajoindre, F. adjoindre, fr. L. adjungere; ad + jungere to join. See Join, and cf. Adjunct
entry.def: To join or unite to; to lie contiguous to; to be in contact with; to attach; to append.
entry.q: Corrections . . . should be, as remarks, adjoined by way of note.

entry.note: ☞ The construction with to on, or with is obsolete or obsolescent.

sn.def: To lie or be next, or in contact; to be contiguous; as, the houses adjoin .
sn.q: When one man's land adjoins to another's.

sn.def: To join one's self.
sn.q: She lightly unto him adjoined side to side.

entry.def: Contiguous.
Joining to; contiguous; adjacent; as, an adjoining room.
entry.q: Theadjoiningfane.
Upon the hills adjoining to the city.
entry.syn: Adjacent; contiguous; near; neighboring; abutting; bordering. See Adjacent.

entry.def: An adjunct; a helper.

entry.usage: To Adjourn Prorogue Dissolve. These words are used in respect to public bodies when they lay aside business and separate. Adjourn, both in Great Britain and this country, is applied to all cases in which such bodies separate for a brief period, with a view to meet again. Prorogue is applied in Great Britain to that act of the executive government, as the sovereign, which brings a session of Parliament to a close. The word is not used in this country, but a legislative body is said, in such a case, to adjourn sine die. To dissolve is to annul the corporate existence of a body. In order to exist again the body must be reconstituted.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adjourned; p. pr. & vb. n. Adjourning
entry.ety: OE. ajornen, OF. ajoiner ajurner, F. ajourner; OF. aL. ad) + jor jur jorn, F. jour, day, fr. L. diurnus belonging to the day, fr. dies day. Cf. Journal Journey
entry.def: To put off or defer to another day, or indefinitely; to postpone; to close or suspend for the day; -- commonly said of the meeting, or the action, of convened body; as, to adjourn the meeting; to adjourn a debate.
entry.q: It is a common practice to adjourn the reformation of their lives to a further time.
'Tis a needful fitness That we adjourn this court till further day.
entry.syn: To delay; defer; postpone; put off; suspend.

entry.def: To suspend business for a time, as from one day to another, or for a longer period, or indefinitely; usually, to suspend public business, as of legislatures and courts, or other convened bodies; as, congress adjourned at four o'clock; the court adjourned without day.
Adjournment; postponement.
entry.q: Anadjournalof the Diet.

entry.ety: Cf. f. adjournement, OF. ajornement. See Adjourn

sn.def: The act of adjourning; the putting off till another day or time specified, or without day.
The time or interval during which a public body adjourns its sittings or postpones business.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adjudged; p. pr. & vb. n. Adjudging
entry.ety: OE. ajugen, OF. ajugier, fr. L. adjudicare; ad + judicare to judge. See Judge, and cf. Adjudicate

sn.def: To award judicially in the case of a controverted question; as, the prize was adjudged to the victor.
To determine in the exercise of judicial power; to decide or award judicially; to adjudicate; as, the case was adjudged in the November term.
To sentence; to condemn.
sn.q: Without reprieve, adjudged to death For want of well pronouncing Shibboleth.

sn.def: To regard or hold; to judge; to deem.
sn.q: He adjudged him unworthy of his friendship.
sn.syn: To decree; award; determine; adjudicate; ordain; assign.

entry.def: One who adjudges.
The act of adjudging; judicial decision; adjudication.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adjudicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Adjudicating
entry.ety: L. adjudicatus, p. p. of adjudicare. See Adjudge
entry.def: To adjudge; to try and determine, as a court; to settle by judicial decree.
To come to a judicial decision; as, the court adjudicated upon the case.

sn.def: The act of adjudicating; the act or process of trying and determining judicially.
A deliberate determination by the judicial power; a judicial decision or sentence.
sn.q: Anadjudicationin favor of natural rights.

sn.def: The decision upon the question whether the debtor is a bankrupt.
A process by which land is attached security or in satisfaction of a debt.

entry.def: Adjudicating.
One who adjudicates.
Adjudication.

entry.ety: L. adjugatus, p. p. of adjugare; ad + jugum a yoke
entry.def: To yoke to.

entry.ety: L. adjumentum, for adjuvamentum, fr. adjuvare to help; ad + juvare to help
entry.def: Help; support; also, a helper.

entry.ety: L. adjuvamentum, fr. adjuvare to help; ad + juvare to help

sn.def: A substance added to an immunogenic agent to enhance the production of antibodies.
A substance added to a formulation of a drug which enhances the effect of the active ingredient.

cs.cd: short notes between those essential to the harmony; auxiliary notes; passing notes.

entry.ety: L. adjunctus, p. p. of adjungere. See Adjoin

sn.def: Something joined or added to another thing, but not essentially a part of it.
sn.q: Learning is but an adjunct to our self.

sn.def: A person joined to another in some duty or service; a colleague; an associate.
A word or words added to quality or amplify the force of other words; as, the History of the American Revolution, where the words in italics are the adjunct or adjuncts of “History.”
A quality or property of the body or the mind, whether natural or acquired; as, color, in the body, judgment in the mind.
A key or scale closely related to another as principal; a relative or attendant key. R See Attendant keys, under Attendant a.

entry.ety: L. adjunctio, fr. adjungere: cf. F. adjonction, and see Adjunct
entry.def: The act of joining; the thing joined or added.

entry.ety: L. adjunctivus, fr. adjungere. See Adjunct
entry.def: Joining; having the quality of joining; forming an adjunct.
One who, or that which, is joined.
In an adjunctive manner.
By way of addition or adjunct; in connection with.

entry.ety: L. adjuratio, fr. adjurare: cf. F. adjuration. See Adjure

sn.def: The act of adjuring; a solemn charging on oath, or under the penalty of a curse; an earnest appeal.
sn.q: What an accusation could not effect, an adjuration shall.

entries.entry:
Ad*jure" v. t.
imp. & p. p. Adjured; p. pr. & vb. n. Adjuring . L. adjurare adjurdium, to swear to; later, to adjure: cf. F. adjurer. See Jury
To charge, bind, or command, solemnly, as if under oath, or under the penalty of a curse; to appeal to in the most solemn or impressive manner; to entreat earnestly. Joshua adjured them at that time, saying, Cursed be the man before the Lord, that riseth up and buildeth this city Jericho. The high priest . . . said . . . I adjure thee by the living God, that thou tell us whether thou be the Christ. The commissioners adjured them not to let pass so favorable an opportunity of securing their liberties.

entry.def: One who adjures.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adjusted; p. pr. & vb. n. Adjusting
entry.ety: OF. ajuster ajosterwhence F. ajouter to add), LL. adjuxtare to fit; fr. L. ad + juxta near; confused later with L. ad and justus just, right, whence F. ajuster to adjust. See Just, v. t. and cf. Adjute

sn.def: To make exact; to fit; to make correspondent or conformable; to bring into proper relations; as, to adjust a garment to the body, or things to a standard.
To put in order; to regulate, or reduce to system.
sn.q: Adjusting the orthography.

sn.def: To settle or bring to a satisfactory state, so that parties are agreed in the result; as, to adjust accounts; the differences are adjusted.
To bring to a true relative position, as the parts of an instrument; to regulate for use; as, to adjust a telescope or microscope.
sn.syn: To adapt; suit; arrange; regulate; accommodate; set right; rectify; settle.

entry.def: Capable of being adjusted.
Adjustment.

sn.def: accommodated to certain requirements

entries.entry:
Ad"mi*ral*ty ☞ In England, admiralty jurisdiction was formerly vested in the High Court of Admiralty, which was held before the Lord High Admiral, or his deputy, styled the Judge of the Admiralty; but admiralty jurisdiction is now vested in the probate, divorce, and admiralty division of the High Justice. In America, there are no admiralty courts distinct from others, but admiralty jurisdiction is vested in the district courts of the United States, subject to revision by the circuit courts and the Supreme Court of the United States. Admiralty jurisprudence has cognizance of maritime contracts and torts, collisions at sea, cases of prize in war, etc., and in America, admiralty jurisdiction is extended to such matters, arising out of the navigation of any of the public waters, as the Great Lakes and rivers. n.; pl.Admiralties. F. amirauté, for an older amiralté, office of admiral, fr. LL. admiralitas. See Admiral
The office or jurisdiction of an admiral.
The department or officers having authority over naval affairs generally.
The court which has jurisdiction of maritime questions and offenses.

entry.usage: Admittance Admission. These words are, to some extent, in a state of transition and change. Admittance is now chiefly confined to its primary sense of access into some locality or building. Thus we see on the doors of factories, shops, etc. “No admittance.” Its secondary or moral sense, as “admittance to the church,” is almost entirely laid aside. Admission has taken to itself the secondary or figurative senses; as, admission to the rights of citizenship; admission to the church; the admissions made by one of the parties in a dispute. And even when used in its primary sense, it is not identical with admittance. Thus, we speak of admission into a country, territory, and other larger localities, etc., where admittance could not be used. So, when we speak of admission to a concert or other public assembly, the meaning is not perhaps exactly that of admittance, viz., access within the walls of the building, but rather a reception into the audience, or access to the performances. But the lines of distinction on this subject are one definitely drawn.

entry.usage: Admonition is prospective, and relates to moral delinquencies; its object is to prevent further transgression. Reprehension and reproof are retrospective, the former being milder than the latter. A person of any age or station may be liable to reprehension in case of wrong conduct; but reproof is the act of a superior. It is authoritative fault-finding or censure addressed to children or to inferiors.

entry.usage: To Adorn Ornament Decorate Embellish. We decorate and ornament by putting on some adjunct which is attractive or beautiful, and which serves to heighten the general effect. Thus, a lady's head-dress may be ornament or decorated with flowers or jewelry; a hall may be decorated or ornament with carving or gilding, with wreaths of flowers, or with hangings. Ornament is used in a wider sense than decorate. To embellish is to beautify or ornament richly, not so much by mere additions or details as by modifying the thing itself as a whole. It sometimes means gaudy and artificial decoration. We embellish a book with rich engravings; a style is embellished with rich and beautiful imagery; a shopkeeper embellishes his front window to attract attention. Adorn is sometimes identical with decorate, as when we say, a lady was adorned with jewels. In other cases, it seems to imply something more. Thus, we speak of a gallery of paintings as adorned with the works of some of the great masters, or adorned with noble statuary and columns. Here decorated and ornamented would hardly be appropriate. There is a value in these works of genius beyond mere show and ornament. Adorn may be used of what is purely moral; as, a character adorned with every Christian grace. Here neither decorate, nor ornament, nor embellish is proper.

entries.entry: Ad*re"nal*ine n. Also Ad*re"nal*in . Physiol. Chem a hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla that acts as a powerful stimulant in reponse to fear or stress; it stimulates autonomic nerve action. It can be obtained as a crystalline substance, C9H13NO3. It is used in medicine as a vasoconstrictor (hemostatic) and cardiac stimulant, also to reduce allergic reactions and to stimulate the heart in cases of cardiac arrest. MI11

sn.def: producing or activated by epinephrine or adrenaline
of or pertaining to the adrenal cortex.
stimulating or acting on the adrenal cortex
a growth hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland; it stimulates the adrenal cortex.
sn.syn: adrenocorticotropic hormone, adrenocorticotrophic hormone, adrenocorticotrophin, corticotropin, corticotrophin, ACTH

sn.def: a steroid having androgenic activity; obtained from the cortex of the adrenal gland.

entry.def: Pertaining to the Adriatic Sea; as, Adrian billows.

sn.def: a city in Northwest Turkey; a Thracian town that was rebuilt and renamed by the Roman emperor Hadrian.
a city in Northwest Turkey; a Thracian town that was rebuilt and renamed by the Roman emperor Hadrian.

entry.ety: L. Adriaticus Hadriaticus, fr. Adria or Hadria, a town of the Veneti
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a sea so named, the northwestern part of which is known as the Gulf of Venice.
Floating at random; in a drifting condition; at the mercy of wind and waves. Also fig.
entry.q: So on the sea shall be set adrift.
Were from their daily labor turned adrift.

entry.def: In a dripping state; as, leaves all adrip .
To adopt (a person who is his own master).

entry.ety: L. adrogatio arrogatio, fr. adrogare. See Arrogate
entry.def: A kind of adoption in ancient Rome. See Arrogation.

entry.ety: F. adroit; àL. ad) = droit straight, right, fr. L. directus, p. p. of dirigere. See Direct
entry.def: Dexterous in the use of the hands or in the exercise of the mental faculties; exhibiting skill and readiness in avoiding danger or escaping difficulty; ready in invention or execution; -- applied to persons and to acts; as, an adroit mechanic, an adroit reply.
entry.q: Adroitin the application of the telescope and quadrant.
He wasadroitin intrigue.
entry.syn: Dexterous; skillful; expert; ready; clever; deft; ingenious; cunning; ready-witted.

entry.def: In an adroit manner.
The quality of being adroit; skill and readiness; dexterity.
entry.q: Adroitness was as requisite as courage.

entry.def: In a dry or thirsty condition.
entry.q: A man that isadry.

entry.ety: L. adscitus, p. p. of adsciscere asciscere, to take knowingly; ad + sciscere to seek to know, approve, scire to know
entry.def: Supplemental; additional; adventitious; ascititious.
entry.q: Adscititiousevidence.

entry.ety: L. adscriptus, p. p. of adscribere to enroll. See Ascribe
entry.def: Held to service as attached to the soil; -- said of feudal serfs.
One held to service as attached to the glebe or estate; a feudal serf.
Attached or annexed to the glebe or estate and transferable with it.
Additional signification.
To denote additionally.

to attract and bind (molecules of a substance in a fluid) so as to form a thin layer on the surface, by non-electrostatic forces; to bind by adsorption. Distinguished from absorb, in which the foreign substance penetrates the body of the absorbing material.

sn.def: the process by which molecules of a substance form a thin film on the surface of a solid. Distinguished from absorption, in which the foreign substance penetrates the body of the absorbing material.

entry.sn: having capacity or tendency to adsorb or cause to accumulate on a surface; displaying adsorption.Narrower terms: chemisorptive, chemosorptive nonadsorbent adsorbent, surface-assimilative

entry.def: See Astrict, and Astriction.
See Astrictory.
See Astringent.

entries.entry:
Ad*su"ki bean ăd*s�"kĭ; ăd*z�"kĭ. Jap. adzuki
A cultivated variety of the Asiatic gram, now introduced into the United States.

entry.ety: From Adula, a mountain peak in Switzerland, where fine specimens are found
entry.def: A transparent or translucent variety of common feldspar, or orthoclase, which often shows pearly opalescent reflections; -- called by lapidaries moonstone.

entry.ety: L. adulatus, p. p. of adulari
entry.def: To flatter in a servile way.

entry.usage: Adulation Flattery Compliment. Men deal in compliments from a desire to please; they use flattery either from undue admiration, or a wish to gratify vanity; they practice adulation from sordid motives, and with a mingled spirit of falsehood and hypocrisy. Compliment may be a sincere expression of due respect and esteem, or it may be unmeaning; flattery is apt to become gross; adulation is always servile, and usually fulsome.
entry.ety: F. adulation, fr. L. adulatio, fr. adulari adulatum, to flatter
entry.def: Servile flattery; praise in excess, or beyond what is merited.
entry.q: Think'st thou the fiery fever will go out With titles blown from adulation?

entry.ety: L., fr. adulari: cf. F. adulateur
entry.def: A servile or hypocritical flatterer.

entry.ety: L. adulatorius, fr. adulari: cf. OF. adulatoire
entry.def: Containing excessive praise or compliment; servilely praising; flattering; as, an adulatory address.
entry.q: A mere rant of adulatory freedom.

entry.def: A woman who flatters with servility.

entry.ety: L. adultus, p. p. of adolescere, akin to alere to nourish: cf. F. adulte. See Adolescent Old
entry.def: Having arrived at maturity, or to full size and strength; matured; as, an adult person or plant; an adult ape; an adult age.

entry.note: ☞ In the common law, the term is applied to a person who has attained full age or legal majority; in the civil law, to males after the age of fourteen, and to females after twelve.
entry.def: A person, animal, or plant grown to full size and strength; one who has reached maturity.
To commit adultery; to pollute.

entry.ety: L. adulterans, p. pr. of adulterare
entry.def: That which is used to adulterate anything.

def2.def: Adulterating; as, adulterant agents and processes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adulterated; p. pr. & vb. n. Adulterating
entry.ety: L. adulteratus, p. p. of adulterare, fr. adulter adulterer, prob. fr. ad + alter other, properly one who approaches another on account of unlawful love. Cf. Advoutry

sn.def: To defile by adultery.
To corrupt, debase, or make impure by an admixture of a foreign or a baser substance; as, to adulterate food, drink, drugs, coin, etc.
sn.q: The present war has . . . adulterated our tongue with strange words.
sn.syn: To corrupt; defile; debase; contaminate; vitiate; sophisticate.

entry.def: To commit adultery.

sn.def: Tainted with adultery.
Debased by the admixture of a foreign substance; adulterated; spurious.

entry.note: used ususally of articles of commerce, dulted with less costly materials so as to enhance profit; -- usually imlying that the dilution is surreptitious and unethical

sn.def: having been made impure by addition of inferior ingredients; -- said of substances or foods
making impure or corrupt by virtue of extraneous origin; -- of impurities.
sn.illu: the adulterating effect of extraneous materials

sn.def: making impure or corrupt by adding extraneous materials; -- of people.
The act of adulterating; corruption, or debasement (esp. of food or drink) by foreign mixture.
sn.q: The shameless adulteration of the coin.

sn.def: An adulterated state or product.

entry.def: One who adulterates or corrupts.

entry.ety: Formed fr. the verb adulter, with the E. ending -er. See Advoutrer

sn.def: A man who commits adultery; a married man who has sexual intercourse with a woman not his wife.
A man who violates his religious covenant.

entry.ety: Fem. from L. adulter. Cf. Advoutress

sn.def: A woman who commits adultery.
A woman who violates her religious engagements.

entry.def: Proceeding from adulterous intercourse. Hence: Spurious; without the support of law; illegal.
entry.q: When any particular class of artificers or traders thought proper to act as a corporation without a charter, such were called adulterine guilds.

entry.def: An illegitimate child.
To commit adultery.

sn.def: Guilty of, or given to, adultery; pertaining to adultery; illicit.
Characterized by adulteration; spurious.
sn.q: Anadulterousmixture.

entry.def: In an adulterous manner.

entries.entry:
A*dul"ter*y ☞ It is adultery on the part of the married wrongdoer. The word has also been used to characterize the act of an unmarried participator, the other being married. In the United States the definition varies with the local statutes. Unlawful intercourse between two married persons is sometimes called double adultery; between a married and an unmarried person, single adultery. n.; pl.Adulteries. L. adulterium. See Advoutry
The unfaithfulness of a married person to the marriage bed; sexual intercourse by a married man with another than his wife, or voluntary sexual intercourse by a married woman with another than her husband.
Adulteration; corruption. Obs
Script
Lewdness or unchastity of thought as well as act, as forbidden by the seventh commandment.
Faithlessness in religion.
Old Law The fine and penalty imposed for the offense of adultery.
Eccl The intrusion of a person into a bishopric during the life of the bishop.
Injury; degradation; ruin. Obs You might wrest the caduceus out of my hand to the adultery and spoil of nature.

entry.def: The state of being adult.

entry.ety: L. adumbrans, p. pr. of adumbrare
entry.def: Giving a faint shadow, or slight resemblance; shadowing forth.

entry.ety: L. adumbratus, p. p. of adumbrare; ad + umbrare to shade; umbra shadow

sn.def: To give a faint shadow or slight representation of; to outline; to shadow forth.
sn.q: Both in the vastness and the richness of the visible universe the invisible God is adumbrated.

sn.def: To overshadow; to shade.
The act of adumbrating, or shadowing forth.
A faint sketch; an outline; an imperfect portrayal or representation of a thing.
sn.q: Elegant adumbrations of sacred truth.

sn.def: The shadow or outlines of a figure.

entry.def: Faintly representing; typical.
A uniting; union.
Hooked; as, a parrot has an adunc bill.
Curvature inwards; hookedness.
entry.q: The aduncity of the beaks of hawks.

entry.ety: L. aduncus; ad + uncus hooked, hook
entry.def: Curved inwards; hooked.

entry.ety: L. adurere; ad + urere to burn
entry.def: To burn up.
Either of two compounds, a chlorine derivative and bromine derivative, of hydroquinone, used as developers.

entry.ety: L. adustus, p. p. of adurere: cf. F. aduste

sn.def: Inflamed or scorched; fiery.
sn.q: The Libyan airadust.

sn.def: Looking as if or scorched; sunburnt.
sn.q: A tall, thin man, of an adust complexion.

sn.def: Having much heat in the constitution and little serum in the blood. Obs Hence: Atrabilious; sallow; gloomy.

That may be burnt.

entry.ety: L. adustio, fr. adurere adustum: cf. F. adustion
