Cauterization.

entries.entry: Ad va*lo"rem Ad va*lo"rem. L., according to the value Com A term used to denote a duty or charge laid upon goods, at a certain rate per cent upon their value, as stated in their invoice, -- in opposition to a specific sum upon a given quantity or number; as, an ad valorem duty of twenty per cent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Advanced; p. pr. & vb. n. Advancing#)
entry.ety: OE. avancen avauncen, F. avancer, fr. a supposed LL. abantiare; ab + anteF. avant) before. The spelling with d was a mistake, a- being supposed to be fr. L. ad. See Avaunt

sn.def: To bring forward; to move towards the van or front; to make to go on.
To raise; to elevate.
sn.q: They . . . advanced their eyelids.

sn.def: To raise to a higher rank; to promote.
sn.q: Ahasueres . . . advanced him, and set his seat above all the princes.

sn.def: To accelerate the growth or progress; to further; to forward; to help on; to aid; to heighten; as, to advance the ripening of fruit; to advance one's interests.
To bring to view or notice; to offer or propose; to show; as, to advance an argument.
sn.q: Some ne'er advance a judgment of their own.

sn.def: To make earlier, as an event or date; to hasten.
To furnish, as money or other value, before it becomes due, or in aid of an enterprise; to supply beforehand; as, a merchant advances money on a contract or on goods consigned to him.
To raise to a higher point; to enhance; to raise in rate; as, to advance the price of goods.
To extol; to laud.
sn.q: Greatly advancing his gay chivalry.
sn.syn: To raise; elevate; exalt; aggrandize; improve; heighten; accelerate; allege; adduce; assign.

sn.def: To move or go forward; to proceed; as, he advanced to greet me.
To increase or make progress in any respect; as, to advance in knowledge, in stature, in years, in price.
To rise in rank, office, or consequence; to be preferred or promoted.
sn.q: Advanced to a level with ancient peers.

cs.cd: In front; before.
Beforehand; before an equivalent is received.
In the state of having advanced money on account; as, A is in advance to B a thousand dollars or pounds.

entry.ety: Cf. F. avance, fr. avancer. See Advance v.

sn.def: The act of advancing or moving forward or upward; progress.
Improvement or progression, physically, mentally, morally, or socially; as, an advance in health, knowledge, or religion; an advance in rank or office.
An addition to the price; rise in price or value; as, an advance on the prime cost of goods.
The first step towards the attainment of a result; approach made to gain favor, to form an acquaintance, to adjust a difference, etc.; an overture; a tender; an offer; -- usually in the plural.
sn.q: He] made the like advances to the dissenters.

sn.def: A furnishing of something before an equivalent is received (as money or goods), towards a capital or stock, or on loan; payment beforehand; the money or goods thus furnished; money or value supplied beforehand.
sn.q: I shall, with pleasure, make the necessary advances.
The account was made up with intent to show what advances had been made.

entry.def: Before in place, or beforehand in time; -- used for advanced; as, an advance guard, or that before the main guard or body of an army; advance payment, or that made before it is due; advance proofs, advance sheets, pages of a forthcoming volume, received in advance of the time of publication.

cs.cd: a detachment of troops which precedes the march of the main body.

sn.def: In the van or front.
In the front or before others, as regards progress or ideas; as, advanced opinions, advanced thinkers.
Far on in life or time.
sn.q: A gentleman advanced in years, with a hard experience written in his wrinkles.

entry.ety: OE. avancement, F. avancement. See Advance v. t.

sn.def: The act of advancing, or the state of being advanced; progression; improvement; furtherance; promotion to a higher place or dignity; as, the advancement of learning.
sn.q: In heaven . . . every one (so well they love each other) rejoiceth and hath his part in each other's advancement.
True religion . . . proposes for its end the joint advancement of the virtue and happiness of the people.

sn.def: An advance of money or value; payment in advance. See Advance, 5.
Property given, usually by a parent to a child, in advance of a future distribution.
Settlement on a wife, or jointure.
One who advances; a promoter.
A second branch of a buck's antler.

entries.entry: Ad*van"cing edge. Aëronautics The front edge (in direction of motion) of a supporting surface; -- contr. with following edge, which is the rear edge.
Ad*van"cing sur"face. Aëronautics The first of two or more surfaces arranged in tandem; -- contr. with following surface, which is the rear surface.

entry.def: Tending to advance.

entry.cs: Advantage ground vantage ground. R Clarendon. To have the advantage ofany one), to have a personal knowledge of one who does not have a reciprocal knowledge. “You have the advantage of me; I don't remember ever to have had the honor.” Sheridan. To take advantage of to profit by; (often used in a bad sense) to overreach, to outwit.
entry.usage: We speak of a thing as a benefit, or as beneficial, when it is simply productive of good; as, the benefits of early discipline; the beneficial effects of adversity. We speak of a thing as an advantage, or as advantageous, when it affords us the means of getting forward, and places us on a “vantage ground” for further effort. Hence, there is a difference between the benefits and the advantages of early education; between a beneficial and an advantageous investment of money.
entry.ety: OE. avantage avauntage, F. avantage, fr. avant before. See Advance, and cf. Vantage

sn.def: Any condition, circumstance, opportunity, or means, particularly favorable to success, or to any desired end; benefit; as, the enemy had the advantage of a more elevated position.
sn.q: Give me advantage of some brief discourse.
The advantages of a close alliance.

sn.def: Superiority; mastery; -- with of or over.
sn.q: Lest Satan should get an advantage of us.

sn.def: Superiority of state, or that which gives it; benefit; gain; profit; as, the advantage of a good constitution.
Interest of money; increase; overplus (as the thirteenth in the baker's dozen).
sn.q: And with advantage means to pay thy love.

sn.def: The first point scored after deuce.

cs.cd: to avail one's self of.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Advantaged; p. pr. & vb. n. Advantaging
entry.ety: F. avantager, fr. avantage. See Advance
entry.def: To give an advantage to; to further; to promote; to benefit; to profit.
entry.q: The truth is, the archbishop's own stiffness and averseness to comply with the court designs, advantaged his adversaries against him.
What is a man advantaged, if he gain the whole world, and lose himself, or be cast away?

entry.def: Advantageous.
Being of advantage; conferring advantage; gainful; profitable; useful; beneficial; as, an advantageous position; trade is advantageous to a nation.
entry.q: Advabtageous comparison with any other country.
You see . . . of what use a good reputation is, and how swift and advantageous a harbinger it is, wherever one goes.

entry.def: Profitably; with advantage.
Profitableness.

entry.ety: L. advenire; ad + venire to come: cf. F. avenir advenir. See Come
entry.def: To accede, or come (to); to be added to something or become a part of it, though not essential.
entry.q: Where no act of the will advenes as a coefficient.

entry.def: Coming from outward causes; superadded.

cs.cd: the first Sunday in the season of Advent, being always the nearest Sunday to the feast of St. Andrew (Now. 30).

entry.ety: L. adventus, fr. advenire adventum: cf. F. avent. See Advene

sn.def: The period including the four Sundays before Christmas.
The first or the expected second coming of Christ.
Coming; any important arrival; approach.
sn.q: Death's dreadful advent.
Expecting still his advent home.

sn.def: any Christian religion that believes the second coming of Christ is imminent.

entry.def: One of a religious body, embracing several branches, who look for the proximate personal coming of Christ; -- called also Second Adventists.

sn.def: the membranous outer covering of an organ or blood vessel.
of or pertaining to adventitia.
Added extrinsically; not essentially inherent; accidental or causal; additional; supervenient; foreign.
sn.q: To things of great dimensions, if we annex an adventitious idea of terror, they become without comparison greater.

sn.def: Out of the proper or usual place; as, adventitious buds or roots.
Accidentally or sparingly spontaneous in a country or district; not fully naturalized; adventive; -- applied to foreign plants.
Acquired, as diseases; accidental.
Accidental.
Adventitious.

entry.def: A thing or person coming from without; an immigrant.
Relating to the season of advent.

cs.cd: a writing setting forth that the goods shipped are at the owner's risk.

entry.ety: OE. aventure aunter anter, F. aventure, fr. LL. adventura, fr. L. advenire adventum, to arrive, which in the Romance languages took the sense of “to happen, befall.” See Advene

sn.def: That which happens without design; chance; hazard; hap; hence, chance of danger or loss.
sn.q: Nay, a far less good to man it will be found, if she must, at all adventures, be fastened upon him individually.

sn.def: Risk; danger; peril.
sn.q: He was in great adventure of his life.

sn.def: The encountering of risks; hazardous and striking enterprise; a bold undertaking, in which hazards are to be encountered, and the issue is staked upon unforeseen events; a daring feat.
sn.q: He loved excitement and adventure.

sn.def: A remarkable occurrence; a striking event; a stirring incident; as, the adventures of one's life.
A mercantile or speculative enterprise of hazard; a venture; a shipment by a merchant on his own account.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adventured; p. pr. & vb. n. Adventuring
entry.ety: OE. aventuren auntren, F. aventurer, fr. aventure. See Adventure n.

sn.def: To risk, or hazard; jeopard; to venture.
sn.q: He would not adventure himself into the theater.

sn.def: To venture upon; to run the risk of; to dare.
sn.q: Yet they adventured to go back.
Discriminations might be adventured.

entry.def: To try the chance; to take the risk.
entry.q: I would adventure for such merchandise.

entry.def: Given to adventure.

sn.def: One who adventures; as, the merchant adventurers ; one who seeks his fortune in new and hazardous or perilous enterprises.
A social pretender on the lookout for advancement.

entry.def: Full of risk; adventurous; venturesome.
A female adventurer; a woman who tries to gain position by equivocal means.

sn.def: recklessness in politics or foreign affairs.
of or pertaining to adventurism.

entry.ety: OE. aventurous aunterous, OF. aventuros, F. aventureux, fr. aventure. See Adventure n.

sn.def: Inclined to adventure; willing to incur hazard; prone to embark in hazardous enterprise; rashly daring; -- applied to persons.
sn.q: Bold deed thou hast presumed, adventurous Eve.

sn.def: Full of hazard; attended with risk; exposing to danger; requiring courage; rash; -- applied to acts; as, an adventurous undertaking, deed, song.
sn.syn: Rash; foolhardy; presumptuous; enterprising; daring; hazardous; venturesome. See Rash.

entry.def: In an adventurous manner; venturesomely; boldly; daringly.
The quality or state of being adventurous; daring; venturesomeness.

entry.ety: L. adverbium; ad + verbum word, verb: cf. F. adverbe
entry.def: A word used to modify the sense of a verb, participle, adjective, or other adverb, and usually placed near it; as, he writes well; paper extremely white.
Of or pertaining to an adverb; of the nature of an adverb; as, an adverbial phrase or form.
The quality of being adverbial.
To give the force or form of an adverb to.
In the manner of an adverb.

entry.ety: L. adversariasc. scripta), neut. pl. of adversarius
entry.def: A miscellaneous collection of notes, remarks, or selections; a commonplace book; also, commentaries or notes.
entry.q: These parchments are supposed to have been St. Paul's adversaria.

entry.def: Hostile.

entries.entry:
Ad`ver*sa*ry
The Adversary The Satan, or the Devil.
Enemy is the only one of these words which necessarily implies a state of personal hostility. Men may be adversaries antagonists, or opponents to each other in certain respects, and yet have no feelings of general animosity. An adversary may be simply one who is placed for a time in a hostile position, as in a lawsuit, an argument, in chess playing, or at fence. An opponent is one who is ranged against another (perhaps passively) on the opposing side; as a political opponent, an opponent in debate. An antagonist is one who struggles against another with active effort, either in a literal fight or in verbal debate. n.; pl.Adversaries. OE. adversarie, direct fr. the Latin, and adversaire, fr. OF. adversier aversier, fr. L. adversariusa.) turned toward, (n.) an adversary. See Adverse
One who is turned against another or others with a design to oppose
or resist them; a member of an opposing or hostile party; an opponent; an antagonist; an enemy; a foe. His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries. Agree with thine adversary quickly. It may be thought that to vindicate the permanency of truth is to dispute without an adversary.
Adversary Enemy Opponent Antagonist.

sn.def: Opposed; opposite; adverse; antagonistic.
Having an opposing party; not unopposed; as, an adversary suit.

entry.def: Expressing contrariety, opposition, or antithesis; as, an adversative conjunction (but however yet, etc. ); an adversative force.
An adversative word.

cs.cd: a possession of real property avowedly contrary to some claim of title in another person.

entry.ety: OE. advers, OF. avers advers, fr. L. adversus, p. p. advertere to turn to. See Advert

sn.def: Acting against, or in a contrary direction; opposed; contrary; opposite; conflicting; as, adverse winds; an adverse party; a spirit adverse to distinctions of caste.
Opposite.
sn.q: Calpe'sadverseheight.

sn.def: In hostile opposition to; unfavorable; unpropitious; contrary to one's wishes; unfortunate; calamitous; afflictive; hurtful; as, adverse fates, adverse circumstances, things adverse .
sn.q: Happy were it for us all if we bore prosperity as well and wisely as we endure an adverse fortune.

entry.def: To oppose; to resist.
In an adverse manner; inimically; unfortunately; contrariwise.
The quality or state of being adverse; opposition.
Having opposite leaves, as plants which have the leaves so arranged on the stem.
A turning towards; attention.

entries.entry:
Ad*ver"si*ty n.; pl.Adversities. OE. adversite, F. adversité, fr. L. adversitas
Opposition; contrariety. Obs
Adversity is not without comforts and hopes. Affliction; distress; misery; disaster; trouble; suffering; trial.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Adverted; p. pr. & vb. n. Adverting
entry.ety: L. advertere, v. t., to turn to; ad + vertere to turn: cf. F. avertir. See Advertise
entry.def: To turn the mind or attention; to refer; to take heed or notice; -- with to; as, he adverted to what was said.
entry.q: I may again advert to the distinction.
entry.syn: - To refer; allude; regard. See Refer.

entry.ety: OF. advertence avertence, LL. advertentia, fr. L. advertens. See Advertent
entry.def: The act of adverting, of the quality of being advertent; attention; notice; regard; heedfulness.
entry.q: To this difference it is right that advertence should be had in regulating taxation.

entry.ety: L. advertens -entis, p. pr. of advertere. See Advert
entry.def: Attentive; heedful; regardful.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Advertised; p. pr. & vb. n. Advertising
entry.ety: F. avertir, formerly also spelt advertir, to warn, give notice to, L. advertere to turn to. The ending was probably influenced by the noun advertisement. See Advert
entry.def: To give notice to; to inform or apprise; to notify; to make known; hence, to warn; -- often followed by of before the subject of information; as, to advertise a man of his loss.
entry.q: I will advertise thee what this people shall do.

sn.def: To give public notice of; to announce publicly, esp. by a printed notice; as, to advertise goods for sale, a lost article, the sailing day of a vessel, a political meeting.
sn.syn: To apprise; inform; make known; notify; announce; proclaim; promulgate; publish.

sn.def: called to public attention.

entry.ety: F. avertisement, formerly also spelled advertissement, a warning, giving notice, fr. avertir

sn.def: The act of informing or notifying; notification.
sn.q: An advertisement of danger.

sn.def: Admonition; advice; warning.
sn.q: Therefore give me no counsel: My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

sn.def: A public notice, especially a paid notice in some public print; anything that advertises; as, a newspaper containing many advertisements .

entry.def: One who, or that which, advertises.

sn.def: a communication publicly promoting some product or service.
the business of advertising; the activity engaged in by professional publicists for pay.
sn.syn: advertizing, publicizing, the advertising profession, the advertising industry

entry.def: same as advertise.

entry.note: ☞ In commercial language, advice usually means information communicated by letter; -- used chiefly in reference to drafts or bills of exchange; as, a letter of advice.
entry.cs: Advice boat a vessel employed to carry dispatches or to reconnoiter; a dispatch boat. To take advice. To accept advice. To consult with another or others.
entry.ety: OE. avis, F. avis; � + OF. vis, fr. L. visum seemed, seen; really p. p. of videre to see, so that vis meant that which has seemed best. See Vision, and cf. Avise Advise

sn.def: An opinion recommended or offered, as worthy to be followed; counsel.

sn.def: Deliberate consideration; knowledge.

sn.def: Information or notice given; intelligence; as, late advices from France; -- commonly in the plural.

sn.syn: Counsel; suggestion; recommendation; admonition; exhortation; information; notice.

sn.def: a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicine used to relieve the pain of arthritis and as an analgesic and antipyretic; Advil and Motrin and Nuprin are trademarks of brands of ibuprofen tablets.

entry.def: The quality of being advisable; advisableness.

entry.def: The quality of being advisable or expedient; expediency; advisability.

sn.def: To take counsel; to consult; -- followed by with; as, to advise with friends.

Circumspectly; deliberately; leisurely.
With deliberate purpose; purposely; by design.

entry.ety: OF. advocatie, LL. advocatia. See Advocate

entry.note: ☞ In the English and American Law, advocate is the same as “counsel,” “counselor,” or “barrister.” In the civil and ecclesiastical courts, the term signifies the same as “counsel” at the common law.
entry.cs: Faculty of advocates Scot the Scottish bar in Edinburgh. Lord advocate Scot the public prosecutor of crimes, and principal crown lawyer. Judge advocate. See under Judge.
entry.ety: OE. avocat avocet, OF. avocat, fr. L. advocatus, one summoned or called to another; properly the p. p. of advocare to call to, call to one's aid; ad + vocare to call. See Advowee Avowee Vocal

sn.def: One who pleads the cause of another. Specifically: One who pleads the cause of another before a tribunal or judicial court; a counselor.

entries.entry: Æ or Ae . A diphthong in the Latin language; used also by the Saxon writers. It answers to the Gr. ai. The Anglo-Saxon short æ was generally replaced by a, the long ǣ by e or ee. In derivatives from Latin words with ae, it is mostly superseded by e. For most words found with this initial combination, the reader will therefore search under the letter E.

a burglar who gains entrance to buildings from the rooftop, sometimes leaping from building to building in the process. A type of second-story man.

entries.entry: A*ë`ri*al rail"way`. A stretched wire or rope elevated above the ground and forming a way along which a trolley may travel, for conveying a load suspended from the trolley. An elevated cableway.

A*ë"ri*al sick"ness. A sickness felt by aëronauts due to high speed of flights and rapidity in changing altitudes, combining some symptoms of mountain sickness and some of seasickness. The nauseous symptoms similar to seasickness experienced by passengers in pressurized aircraft is called air sickness.

entry.ety: OE. aire eire air, nest, also origin, descent, OF. aire, LL. area aera, nest of a bird of prey, perh. fr. L. area an open space (for birds of prey like to build their nests on flat and open spaces on the top of high rocks). Cf. Area
entry.def: The nest of a bird of prey, as of an eagle or hawk; also a brood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence or resting place perched like an eagle's nest.

entry.ety: L. aër air + -ferous: cf. F. aérifère

entry.pos: n. pl., but sing. or pl. in usage

sn.def: physical exercises performed in a sustained and strenuous fashion designed to cause a temporary increase in respiration rate and heart rate, such a running, swimming, walking, or calisthenics. Calisthenic sessions in groups, performed by following a leader in moving to a rhythmic musical accompaniment, are a popular form of aerobics.
a system of physical conditioning relying largely on aerobics exercises.

Related to, or of the nature of, aërobies; as, aërobiotic plants, which live only when supplied with free oxygen.

the resistance caused by a gas to the motion of a solid body moving through it. Studied in aerodynamics.

entry.def: The science which treats of the air and other gaseous bodies under the action of force, and of their mechanical effects.
a heavier-than-air aircraft; same as aeroplane. Contrasted with aerostat.

Acting by the force of air and water; as, an aërohydrodynamic wheel.

entry.ety: F. aéronaute, fr. Gr. � air + � sailor. See Nautical

entry.def: Dread of a current of air.

An instrument, proposed by Edison, for greatly intensifying speech. It consists of a phonograph diaphragm so arranged that its action opens and closes valves, producing synchronous air blasts sufficient to operate a larger diaphragm with greater amplitude of vibration.

entry.ety: Aëro- + Gr. fyto`n plant, fy`ein to grow: cf. F. aérophyte
entry.def: A plant growing entirely in the air, and receiving its nourishment from it; an air plant or epiphyte.

sn.def: A light rigid plane used in aërial navigation to oppose sudden upward or downward movement in the air, as in gliding machines; specif., such a plane slightly inclined and driven forward as a lifting device in some flying machines. Also called airfoil.

hence, a heavier-than-air flying machine using such a device to provide lift. In a modern aeroplane, the airfoils are called the wings, and most of the lift is derived from these surfaces. In contrast to helicopters, the wings are fixed to the passenger compartment (airframe) and do not move relative to the frame; thus such a machine is called a fixed-wing aircraft. These machines are called monoplanes, biplanes, triplanes, or quadruplanes, according to the number of main supporting planes (wings) used in their construction. After 1940 few planes with more than one airfoil were constructed, and these are used by hobbyists or for special purposes. Being heavier than air they depend for their levitation on motion imparted by the thrust from either propellers driven by an engine, or, in a jet plane, by the reaction from a high-velocity stream of gases expelled rearward from a jet engine. They start from the ground by a run on small wheels or runners, and are guided by a steering apparatus consisting of horizontal and vertical movable planes, which usually form part of the wings or tail. There are many varieties of form and construction, which in some cases are known by the names of their inventors. In U.S., an aeroplane is usually called an airplane or plane.

entry.def: One who flies in an aëroplane.
An apparatus designed for collecting spores, germs, bacteria, etc., suspended in the air.

sn.def: To act upon; to produce an effect or change upon.

sn.def: To love; to regard with affection.

sn.def: To show a fondness for; to like to use or practice; to choose; hence, to frequent habitually.

entries.entry:
Af*fin"i*ty n.; pl.Affinities. OF. afinité, F. affinité, L. affinites, fr. affinis. See Affined
Relationship by marriage (as between a husband and his wife's blood relations, or between a wife and her husband's blood relations); -- in contradistinction to consanguinity, or relationship by blood; -- followed by with to, or between. Solomon made affinity with Pharaoh.
Kinship generally; close agreement; relation; conformity; resemblance; connection; as, the affinity of sounds, of colors, or of languages. There is a close affinity between imposture and credulity.
Companionship; acquaintance. Obs About forty years past, I began a happy affinity with William Cranmer.
Chem That attraction which takes place, at an insensible distance, between the heterogeneous particles of bodies, and unites them to form chemical compounds; chemism; chemical or elective affinity or attraction.
Nat. Hist A relation between species or higher groups dependent on resemblance in the whole plan of structure, and indicating community of origin.
Spiritualism A superior spiritual relationship or attraction held to exist sometimes between persons, esp. persons of the opposite sex; also, the man or woman who exerts such psychical or spiritual attraction.

entry.usage: To Affirm Asseverate Aver Protest. We affirm when we declare a thing as a fact or a proposition. We asseverate it in a peculiarly earnest manner, or with increased positiveness as what can not be disputed. We aver it, or formally declare it to be true, when we have positive knowledge of it. We protest in a more public manner and with the energy of perfect sincerity. People asseverate in order to produce a conviction of their veracity; they aver when they are peculiarly desirous to be believed; they protest when they wish to free themselves from imputations, or to produce a conviction of their innocence.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Affirmed -fẽrmd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Affirming

entry.usage: Affliction Sorrow Grief Distress. Affliction and sorrow are terms of wide and general application; grief and distress have reference to particular cases. Affliction is the stronger term. The suffering lies deeper in the soul, and usually arises from some powerful cause, such as the loss of what is most dear -- friends, health, etc. We do not speak of mere sickness or pain as “an affliction,” though one who suffers from either is said to be afflicted; but deprivations of every kind, such as deafness, blindness, loss of limbs, etc., are called afflictions, showing that term applies particularly to prolonged sources of suffering. Sorrow and grief are much alike in meaning, but grief is the stronger term of the two, usually denoting poignant mental suffering for some definite cause, as, grief for the death of a dear friend; sorrow is more reflective, and is tinged with regret, as, the misconduct of a child is looked upon with sorrow. Grief is often violent and demonstrative; sorrow deep and brooding. Distress implies extreme suffering, either bodily or mental. In its higher stages, it denotes pain of a restless, agitating kind, and almost always supposes some struggle of mind or body. Affliction is allayed, grief subsides, sorrow is soothed, distress is mitigated.
entry.ety: F. affliction, L. afflictio, fr. affligere

entry.def: Affright; the state of being frightened; sudden fear or alarm.
entry.q: Passionate words or blows . . . fill the child's mind with terror and affrightment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Affronted; p. pr. & vb. n. Affronting
entry.ety: OF. afronter, F. affronter, to confront, LL. affrontare to strike against, fr. L. ad + frons forehead, front. See Front

sn.def: To front; to face in position; to meet or encounter face to face.
sn.q: All the sea-coasts do affront the Levant.
That he, as 't were by accident, may hereAffront Ophelia.

sn.def: To face in defiance; to confront; as, to affront death; hence, to meet in hostile encounter.
To offend by some manifestation of disrespect; to insult to the face by demeanor or language; to treat with marked incivility.
sn.q: How can any one imagine that the fathers would have dared to affront the wife of Aurelius?
sn.syn: To insult; abuse; outrage; wound; illtreat; slight; defy; offend; provoke; pique; nettle.

entry.usage: An affront is a designed mark of disrespect, usually in the presence of others. An insult is a personal attack either by words or actions, designed to humiliate or degrade. An outrage is an act of extreme and violent insult or abuse. An affront piques and mortifies; an insult irritates and provokes; an outrage wounds and injures.Captious persons construe every innocent freedom into an affront. When people are in a state of animosity, they seek opportunities of offering each other insults. Intoxication or violent passion impels men to the commission of outrages. Crabb.

sn.def: An encounter either friendly or hostile.
sn.q: I walked about, admired of all, and dreaded On hostile ground, none daring my affront.

sn.def: Contemptuous or rude treatment which excites or justifies resentment; marked disrespect; a purposed indignity; insult.
sn.q: Offering an affront to our understanding.

sn.def: An offense to one's self-respect; shame.

entry.def: Face to face, or front to front; facing.
Shamelessly.
One who receives an affront.
One who affronts, or insults to the face.
In an affronting manner.
Tending to affront or offend; offensive; abusive.
entry.q: How affrontive it is to despise mercy.

entry.def: The quality that gives an affront or offense.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Affused -fūzd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Affusing
entry.ety: L. affusus, p. p. of affundere to pour to; ad + fundere. See Fuse
entry.def: To pour out or upon.
entry.q: I first affused water upon the compressed beans.

entries.entry:
Af*fu"sion ăf*fū"zhŭn n. Cf. F. affusion
The act of pouring upon, or sprinkling with a liquid, as water upon a child in baptism. Specifically: Med The act of pouring water or other fluid on the whole or a part of the body, as a remedy in disease.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Affied; p. pr. Affying
entry.ety: OF. afier, LL. affidare. Cf. Affiance

sn.def: To confide (one's self to, or in); to trust.
To betroth or espouse; to affiance.
To bind in faith.

entry.def: To trust or confide.
Of or pertaining to Afghanistan.

sn.def: A native of Afghanistan.
A kind of worsted blanket or wrap.
a native or inhabitant of Afghanistan.
a mountainous country in central Asia.
of or pertaining to Afghanis.
a native or inhabitant of Afghanistan.
To, in, or on the field.
sn.q: We droveafield.
How jocund did they drive their team afield!

sn.def: Out of the way; astray.
sn.q: Why should he wander afield at the age of fifty-five!

entry.def: On fire.
the American Football League.
the combined organizations of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
In flames; glowing with light or passion; ablaze.
Level with the ground; flat.
In a flaunting state or position.
In a flickering state.

sn.def: Borne on the water; floating; on board ship.
sn.q: On such a full sea are we now afloat.

sn.def: Moving; passing from place to place; in general circulation; as, a rumor is afloat .
Unfixed; moving without guide or control; adrift; as, our affairs are all afloat .
Covered with water bearing floating articles; flooded; as, the decks are afloat .

entry.def: Flowing.
entry.q: Their founts aflow with tears.

entry.def: In a flushed or blushing state.
On a level.
entry.q: The bank is . . . aflush with the sea.

entry.def: In a flutter; agitated.
In a foaming state; as, the sea is all afoam .
American Federation of Labor.

sn.def: On foot.
sn.q: We 'll walk afoot a while.

sn.def: Fig.: In motion; in action; astir; in progress.
sn.q: The matter being afoot.

entry.ety: OE. afore aforn, AS. onforan or ætforan; pref. a- + fore

sn.def: Before.
sn.q: If he have never drunk wine afore.

sn.def: In the fore part of a vessel.

cs.cd: among the common sailors; -- a phrase used to distinguish the ship's crew from the officers.

sn.def: Before (in all its senses).
Before; in front of; farther forward than; as, afore the windlass.

entry.def: Named or quoted before.
Goīng before; foregoing.
Beforehand; in anticipation.
entry.q: She is come aforehand to anoint my body.

entry.def: Prepared; previously provided; -- opposed to behindhand.
entry.q: Aforehand in all matters of power.

entry.def: Previously mentioned; before-mentioned.
Named before.
Said before, or in a preceding part; already described or identified.
Premeditated; prepense; previously in mind; designed; as, malice aforethought, which is required to constitute murder.
Premeditation.
In time past; formerly.
entry.q: He prayed . . . as he didaforetime.

entries.entry: A for`ti*o"ri A for`ti*o"ri. L Logic & Math With stronger reason.

cs.cd: to run against or come into collision with, especially so as to become entangled or to cause injury.

entry.def: In collision; entangled.

entry.note: ☞ This word expresses a less degree of fear than terrified or frightened. It is followed by of before the object of fear, or by the infinitive, or by a dependent clause; as, to be afraid of death. “I am afraid to die.” “I am afraid he will chastise me.” “Be not afraid that I your hand should take.” Shak. I am afraid is sometimes used colloquially to soften a statement; as, I am afraid I can not help you in this matter.
entry.ety: OE. afrayed affraide, p. p. of afraien to affray. See Affray, and cf. Afeard
entry.def: Impressed with fear or apprehension; in fear; apprehensive.
entry.mark: Afraid comes after the noun it limits
entry.q: Back they recoiled,afraid.

entry.def: Same as Afrit.
Anew; again; once more; newly.
entry.q: They crucify . . . the Son of God afresh.

entry.def: African.

cs.cd: a fiber prepared from the leaves of the Sanseviera Guineensis, a plant found in Africa and India.
a tropical American plant (Tagetes erecta).
a timber furnished by Oldfieldia Africana, used in ship building.

entry.cs: African violet .African-American see African-American.
entry.ety: L. Africus Africanus, fr. Afer African
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Africa.
A native of Africa; also one ethnologically belonging to an African race.

sn.def: of or pertaining to or characteristic of Americans of African ancestry or their history or culture
an American whose ancestors were born in Africa, especially a United States citizen of African descent.

entry.def: One born in Africa, the offspring of a white father and a “colored” mother. Also, and now commonly in Southern Africa, a native born of European settlers.
same as African wild dog.
A word, phrase, idiom, or custom peculiar to Africa or Africans.

entry.def: A powerful evil jinnee, demon, or monstrous giant.

sn.def: an American whose ancestors were born in Africa.
of or pertaining to or characteristic of Americans of African ancestry or their history or culture.
of or relating to the nations of Africa and Asia or their peoples.
dioecious evergreen trees or shrubs; equatorial to S and SE Africa: yellowwood2; similar to trees or genus Podocarpus.

entry.def: In front; face to face.

sn.def: an African fowl genus; both sexes are brightly colored.
a wig that gives the appearance of an afro hairdo.

entry.ety: AS. æftan behind; orig. superl. of of off. See After
entry.def: Near or towards the stern of a vessel; astern; abaft.

entry.note: ☞ In this sense the word is sometimes needlessly combined with the following noun, by means of a hyphen, as, after-ages, after-act, after-days, after-life. For the most part the words are properly kept separate when after has this meaning.
It is often combined with its noun; as, after-bowlines, after-braces, after-sails, after-yards, those on the mainmasts and mizzenmasts.

cs.cd: the part of a ship abaft the dead flat, or middle part.

entry.ety: AS. æfter after, behind; akin to Goth. aftaro aftra, backwards, Icel. aptr, Sw. and Dan. efter, OHG. aftar behind, Dutch and LG. achter, Gr. 'apwte`rw further off. The ending -ter is an old comparative suffix, in E. generally -theras in other), and after is a compar. of of off. √194. See Of; cf. Aft

sn.def: Next; later in time; subsequent; succeeding; as, an after period of life.
Hinder; nearer the rear.
To ward the stern of the ship; -- applied to any object in the rear part of a vessel; as the after cabin, after hatchway.

cs.cd: to name like and reference to.

entry.cs: After all when everything has been considered; upon the whole. Afterwith the same noun preceding and following), as, wave after wave, day after day, several or many (waves, etcsuccessively. One after another successively. To be after to be in pursuit of in order to reach or get; as, he is after money.

sn.def: Behind in place; as, men in line one after another.
sn.q: Shut doorsafteryou.

sn.def: Below in rank; next to in order.
sn.q: Codrus after Ph�bus sings the best.

sn.def: Later in time; subsequent; as, after supper, after three days. It often precedes a clause. Formerly that was interposed between it and the clause.
sn.q: After I am risen again, I will go before you into Galilee.

sn.def: Subsequent to and in consequence of; as, after what you have said, I shall be careful.
Subsequent to and notwithstanding; as, after all our advice, you took that course.
Moving toward from behind; following, in search of; in pursuit of.
sn.q: Ye shall not go after other gods.
After whom is the king of Israel come out?

sn.def: Denoting the aim or object; concerning; in relation to; as, to look after workmen; to inquire after a friend; to thirst after righteousness.
In imitation of; in conformity with; after the manner of; as, to make a thing after a model; a picture after Rubens; the boy takes after his father.
sn.q: Our eldest son was named George after his uncle.

sn.def: According to; in accordance with; in conformity with the nature of; as, he acted after his kind.
sn.q: He shall not judge after the sight of his eyes.
They that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh.

sn.def: According to the direction and influence of; in proportion to; befitting.
sn.q: He takes greatness of kingdoms according to bulk and currency, and not after their intrinsic value.

entry.note: ☞ After is prefixed to many words, forming compounds, but retaining its usual signification. The prefix may be adverbial, prepositional, or adjectival; as in after- described, after-dinner, after-part. The hyphen is sometimes needlessly used to connect the adjective after with its noun. See Note under After a., 1.
entry.def: Subsequently in time or place; behind; afterward; as, he follows after .
entry.q: It was about the space of three hours after.

entry.def: The placenta and membranes with which the fetus is connected, and which come away after delivery.
A throw of dice after the game in ended; hence, anything done too late.
An unexpected subsequent event; something disagreeable happening after an affair is supposed to be at an end.
A second crop or harvest in the same year.

entries.entry: Aft"er damp`.An irrespirable gas, remaining after an explosion of fire damp in mines; choke damp. See Carbonic acid.

entry.def: The time just after dinner.
entry.q: Anafter-dinner'ssleep.

def2.def: Following dinner; post-prandial; as, an after-dinner nap.

entry.def: Aftergrass.
To look after.

cs.cd: an ancient game very nearly resembling backgammon.

entry.def: A second game; hence, a subsequent scheme or expedient.
A glow of refulgence in the western sky after sunset.
The grass that grows after the first crop has been mown; aftermath.
A second growth or crop, or (metaphorically) development.
The seaman or seamen stationed on the poop or after part of the ship, to attend the after-sails.
The impression of a vivid sensation retained by the retina of the eye after the cause has been removed; also extended to impressions left of tones, smells, etc.
The last milk drawn in milking; strokings.
A second moving; the grass which grows after the first crop of hay in the same season; rowen.
Mentioned afterwards; as, persons after-mentionedin a writing.

entry.ety: OE. eftemest, AS. æftemest, akin to Gothic aftumist and aftuma, the last, orig. a superlative of of, with the superlative endings -te -me -st

sn.def: Hindmost; -- opposed to foremost.
Nearest the stern; most aft.

entry.def: The part of the day which follows noon, between noon and evening.
One of the small notes occur on the unaccented parts of the measure, taking their time from the preceding note.
The pains which succeed childbirth, as in expelling the afterbirth.

sn.def: A piece performed after a play, usually a farce or other small entertainment.
The heel of a rudder.

entry.def: The sails on the mizzenmast, or on the stays between the mainmast and mizzenmast.

sn.def: outside regular school hours.

entry.def: A sensation or sense impression following the removal of a stimulus producing a primary sensation, and reproducing the primary sensation in positive, negative, or complementary form. The aftersensation may be continuous with the primary sensation or follow it after an interval.
The hypoptilum.

sn.def: having an aftershaft (a small feather at the base of some feathers

entry.def: A taste which remains in the mouth after eating or drinking.

sn.def: Reflection after an act; later or subsequent thought.
an action taken after another action and related to the first action, which would normally or optimally be done along with the first action;as, to do something as an afterthought .
a feature or part added to a device, not thought of in its original design.

entry.ety: AS. æfteweard, a., behind. See Aft, and -wardsuffix). The final s in afterwards is adverbial, orig. a genitive ending
entry.def: At a later or succeeding time.
Wise after the event; wise or knowing, when it is too late.
Wisdom or perception that comes after it can be of use.
entry.q: After-witcomes too late when the mischief is done.

entry.def: Characterized by after-wit; slow-witted.
Nearest the stern.
Toward the stern.

entry.def: In Turkey, a commander or chief officer. It is used also as a title of respect.

cs.cd: more than once; often; repeatedly.
now and then; occasionally.
to and fro.

entry.note: ☞ Again was formerly used in many verbal combinations, as, again-witness, to witness against; again-ride, to ride against; again-come, to come against, to encounter; again-bring, to bring back, etc.
entry.ety: OE. agein agayn, AS. ongegn ongeán, against, again; on + geán, akin to Ger. gegewn against, Icel. gegn. Cf. Gainsay

sn.def: In return, back; as, bring us word again .
Another time; once more; anew.
sn.q: If a man die, shall he live again?

sn.def: Once repeated; -- of quantity; as, as large again, half as much again .
In any other place.
On the other hand.
sn.q: The one is my sovereign . . . the otheragainis my kinsman.

sn.def: Moreover; besides; further.
sn.q: Again, it is of great consequence to avoid, etc.

entry.def: Against; also, towards (in order to meet).
entry.q: Albeit that it is again his kind.

entry.def: To redeem.
To gainsay.

cs.cd: in a direction contrary to that in which the sun appears to move.

entry.ety: OE. agens ageynes, AS. ongegn. The s is adverbial, orig. a genitive ending. See Again

sn.def: Abreast; opposite to; facing; towards; as, against the mouth of a river; -- in this sense often preceded by over.
sn.q: Jacob saw the angels of God come against him.

sn.def: From an opposite direction so as to strike or come in contact with; in contact with; upon; as, hail beats against the roof.

In opposition to, whether the opposition is of sentiment or of action; on the other side; counter to; in contrariety to; hence, adverse to; as, against reason; against law; to run a race against time.
sn.q: The gate would have been shut against her.
An argument against the use of steam.

sn.def: By of before the time that; in preparation for; so as to be ready for the time when.

Back again.
