Lacking milk to suckle with.
Same as Agar-agar.

entry.ety: Gr. a`ga`llochon, of Eastern origin: cf. Skr. aguru, Heb. pl. ahālīm
entry.def: A soft, resinous wood (Aquilaria Agallocha) of highly aromatic smell, burnt by the orientals as a perfume. It is called also agalwood and aloes wood. The name is also given to some other species.

entry.ety: Gr. 'a`galma 'a`galmatos, image, statue + -lite: cf. F. agalmatolithe
entry.def: A soft, compact stone, of a grayish, greenish, or yellowish color, carved into images by the Chinese, and hence called figure stone, and pagodite. It is probably a variety of pinite.

entries.entry: Ag"a*ma Ag"a*ma ăg"ȧ*mȧ n.; pl.Agamas ăg"ȧ*mȧz. From the Caribbean name of a species of lizard Zoöl A genus of lizards, one of the few which feed upon vegetable substances; also, one of these lizards.

Ag"a*mi Ag"a*mi ăg"ȧ*mē n.; pl.Agamis ăg"ȧ*mēz. F. agami, fr. the native name Zoöl A South American bird (Psophia crepitans), allied to the cranes, and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold-breasted trumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.

entry.def: Produced without sexual union; as, agamic or unfertilized eggs.
Not having visible organs of reproduction, as flowerless plants; agamous.
In an agamic manner.
An unmarried person; also, one opposed to marriage.
Reproduction without the union of parents of distinct sexes: asexual reproduction.
Reproducing or produced without sexual union.
entry.q: All known agamogenetic processes end in a complete return to the primitive stock.

entry.def: Having no visible sexual organs; asexual.
cryptogamous.
Without ganglia.
Gaping, as with wonder, expectation, or eager attention.
entry.q: Dazzles the crowd and sets them all agape.

entries.entry:
Ag"a*pe Ag"a*pe n.; pl.Agapæ #. Gr. 'aga`ph love, pl. 'aga`pai
The love feast of the primitive Christians, being a meal partaken of in connection with the communion.

sn.def: common shortened form of agar-agar{2.

any culture medium that uses agar as the gelling agent; -- used especially with a modifying prefix, as, EMB agar . The term is applied both to the dehydrated medium powder containing agar and to the gelatinous medium prepared from it.

entry.note: In composition it is predominantly a polysaccharide, and is not degraded by most bacteria. It thus almost completely replaced the earlier protein-based gelatins used for fixing bacterial colonies on culture plates, as the gelatins were often dissolved by the proteolytic enzymes common in bacteria.

sn.def: A fucus or seaweed much used in the East for soups and jellies; Ceylon moss (Gracilaria lichenoides).

A gelatinlike substance, or a solution of it, prepared from certain seaweeds containing gelose (such as Ceylon moss, Gracilaria lichenoides or other seaweeds of the genera Gelidium Ceramium Pterocladia, and Eucheuma), and used for solidifying growth media in the artificial cultivation of bacteria, or as a gelling agent in foods; -- usually called simply agar, by abbreviation.

entry.note: ☞ The “female agaric” (Polyporus officinalis) was renowned as a cathartic; the “male agaric” (Polyporus igniarius) is used for preparing touchwood, called punk or German tinder.

cs.cd: a light, chalky deposit of carbonate of lime, sometimes called rock milk, formed in caverns or fissures of limestone.

entry.ety: L. agaricum, Gr. �, said to be fr. Agara, a town in Sarmatia

sn.def: A fungus of the genus Agaricus, of many species, of which the common mushroom is an example.
An old name for several species of Polyporus, corky fungi growing on decaying wood.

entry.def: In a state of gasping.
To affright; to terrify.
See Aghast.

sn.def: giant hyssop; Mexican hyssop.

entry.def: Having to stomach, or distinct digestive canal, as the tapeworm.
On the way; agoing; as, to be agate; to set the bells agate.

entry.note: ☞ The fortification agate, or Scotch pebble, the moss agate, the clouded agate, etc., are familiar varieties.
☞ This line is printed in the type called agate.
entry.ety: F. agate, It. agata, L. achates, fr. Gr. �

sn.def: A semipellucid, uncrystallized variety of quartz, presenting various tints in the same specimen. Its colors are delicately arranged in stripes or bands, or blended in clouds.
A kind of type, larger than pearl and smaller than nonpareil; in England called ruby.
A diminutive person; so called in allusion to the small figures cut in agate for rings and seals.
A tool used by gold-wire drawers, bookbinders, etc.; -- so called from the agate fixed in it for burnishing.

entry.def: Containing or producing agates.
Pertaining to, or like, agate.
To convert into agate; to make resemble agate.
Of the nature of agate, or containing agate.

sn.def: a natural family of chiefly tropical and xerophytic plants: includes Dracenaceae (Dracaenaceae); comprises plants that in some classifications are divided between the Amaryllidaceae and the Liliaceae.
sn.syn: family Agavaceae, agave family, sisal family.

entry.ety: L. Agave, prop. name, fr. Gr. �, fem. of � illustrious, noble
entry.def: A genus of plants (order Amaryllidaceæ) of which the chief species is the maguey or century plant (Agave Americana), wrongly called Aloe. It is from ten to seventy years, according to climate, in attaining maturity, when it produces a gigantic flower stem, sometimes forty feet in height, and perishes. The fermented juice is the pulque of the Mexicans; distilled, it yields mescal. A strong thread and a tough paper are made from the leaves, and the wood has many uses.

sn.def: looking intently; -- used of eyes.

entry.ety: Only in p. p.; another spelling for aghast
entry.def: Gazing with astonishment; amazed.
entry.q: The whole army stood agazed on him.

sn.def: Asiatic epithet for Rhea or Cybele.

entry.note: In the United States, both males and females are of age when twenty-one years old. Some rights, such as that of voting in elections, are conferred earlier.

Archeological ages are designated as three: The Stone agethe early and the later stone age, called paleolithic and neolithic), the Bronze age, and the Iron age. During the Age of Stone man is supposed to have employed stone for weapons and implements.

The geologic ages are as follows: 1. The Archæan, including the time when was no life and the time of the earliest and simplest forms of life. 2. The age of Invertebrates, or the Silurian, when the life on the globe consisted distinctively of invertebrates. 3. The age of Fishes, or the Devonian, when fishes were the dominant race. 4. The age of Coal Plants, or Acrogens, or the Carboniferous age. 5. The Mesozoic or Secondary age, or age of Reptiles, when reptiles prevailed in great numbers and of vast size. 6. The Tertiary age, or age of Mammals, when the mammalia, or quadrupeds, abounded, and were the dominant race. 7. The Quaternary age, or age of Man, or the modern era.

cs.cd: the time from the origin of a tide in the South Pacific Ocean to its arrival at a given place.
the time that has elapsed since the last preceding conjunction of the sun and moon.

entry.note: ☞ Age is used to form the first part of many compounds; as, agelasting, age-adorning, age-worn, age-enfeebled, agelong.
entry.ety: OF. aage eage, F. âge, fr. L. aetas through a supposed LL. aetaticum. L. aetas is contracted fr. aevitas, fr. aevum lifetime, age; akin to E. aye ever. Cf. Each

sn.def: The whole duration of a being, whether animal, vegetable, or other kind; lifetime.
sn.q: Mine age is as nothing before thee.

sn.def: That part of the duration of a being or a thing which is between its beginning and any given time; as, what is the present age of a man, or of the earth?
The latter part of life; an advanced period of life; seniority; state of being old.
sn.q: Nor wrong mine age with this indignity.

sn.def: One of the stages of life; as, the age of infancy, of youth, etc.
Mature age; especially, the time of life at which one attains full personal rights and capacities; as, to come of age; he (or she) is of age .
The time of life at which some particular power or capacity is understood to become vested; as, the age of consent; the age of discretion.
A particular period of time in history, as distinguished from others; as, the golden age, the age of Pericles.
sn.q: The spirit of theage.
Truth, in some age or other, will find her witness.
sn.see: See Augustan Brazen Golden Heroic Middle.

sn.def: A great period in the history of the Earth.
A century; the period of one hundred years.
sn.q: Fleury . . . apologizes for these five ages.

sn.def: The people who live at a particular period; hence, a generation.
sn.q: Agesyet unborn.
The way which the age follows.
Lo! where the stage, the poor, degraded stage, Holds its warped mirror to a gaping age.

sn.def: A long time.
sn.q: He made minutes anage.

sn.def: the right belonging to the player to the left of the dealer to pass the first round in betting, and then to come in last or stay out; also, the player holding this position; the eldest hand.
sn.syn: Time; period; generation; date; era; epoch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aged; p. pr. & vb. n. Aging
entry.def: To grow aged; to become old; to show marks of age; as, he grew fat as he aged .
entry.q: They live one hundred and thirty years, and never age for all that.
I am aging; that is, I have a whitish, or rather a light-colored, hair here and there.

entry.def: To cause to grow old; to impart the characteristics of age to; as, grief ages us.

sn.def: Old; having lived long; having lived almost to or beyond the usual time allotted to that species of being; as, an aged man; an aged oak.
Belonging to old age.
sn.q: Agedcramps.

sn.def: Having a certain age; at the age of; having lived; as, a man aged forty years.

entry.note: As a result of having been aged, the product may be said to be mature or ripevs. green).

sn.def: of very long duration
having reached a desired or final condition as a result of standing for a period of time; -- of wines, whiskey, fruit, or cheeses.

entry.def: In the manner of an aged person.
The quality of being aged; oldness.
entry.q: Custom without truth is but agedness of error.

sn.def: having lived for a relatively long (or a specified) time; not young; -- used especially of persons. Opposite of young.

entry.def: same as aging.

sn.def: discrimination against middle-aged and elderly people.

entry.def: A genus of birds including the red-winged blackbirds.
Without old age limits of duration; as, fountains of ageless youth.
lasting through all time; unending; as, The agelong struggle for freedom.
See Again.

entries.entry:
a"gen*cy ā"j�n*s� n.; pl.Agencies ā"j�n*sĭz.
agentia, fr. L. agens agentis: cf. F. agence. See Agent
The faculty of acting or of exerting power; the state of being in action; action; instrumentality. The superintendence and agency of Providence in the natural world.
The office of an agent, or factor; the relation between a principal and his agent; business of one intrusted with the concerns of another.
The place of business of am agent. Action; operation; efficiency; management.

entry.def: See Agendum.
a temporally organized plan for matters to be attended to.

sn.def: A list of matters to be discussed (as at a meeting).
A motive or set of goals; as, to have one's own agenda ;
a secret motive; also called hidden agenda; as, some of the news commentators themselves have an agenda .
sn.syn: goal, hidden motive, secret motive, hidden agenda.

entries.entry:
A*gen"dum A*gen"dum ȧ*jĕn"dŭm n.; pl.Agenda ȧ*jĕn"dȧ. L., neut. of the gerundive of agere to act
Something to be done; in the pl., a memorandum book; also, a list of items to be considered. See agenda.
A church service; a ritual or liturgy. [In this sense, usually Agenda

entry.def: Characterized by sterility; infecund.
Any imperfect development of the body, or any anomaly of organization.
Impotence; sterility.

entry.ety: L. agens agentis, p. pr. of agere to act; akin to Gr. � to lead, Icel. aka to drive, Skr. aj. √2
entry.def: Acting; -- opposed to patient, or sustaining, action.
entry.q: The bodyagent.

sn.def: One who exerts power, or has the power to act; an actor.
sn.q: Heaven made us agents, free to good or ill.

sn.def: One who acts for, or in the place of, another, by authority from him; one intrusted with the business of another; a substitute; a deputy; a factor.
An active power or cause; that which has the power to produce an effect, such as a physical, chemical, or medicinal agent; as, heat is a powerful agent .
a chemical substance having biological effects; a drug.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an agent or an agency.
Agency.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'agh`raton a sort of plant; 'a priv. + gh`ras old age
entry.def: A genus of plants, one species of which (Ageratum Mexicanum) has lavender-blue flowers in dense clusters.

entry.ety: L. aggenerare to beget in addition. See Generate
entry.def: The act of producing in addition.

entry.ety: L., a mound, fr. aggerere to bear to a place, heap up; ad + gerere to bear
entry.def: An earthwork; a mound; a raised work.

entry.ety: L. aggeratus, p. p. of aggerare. See Agger
entry.def: To heap up.
A heaping up; accumulation; as, aggerations of sand.
In heaps; full of heaps.

entry.ety: L. aggestus, p. p. of aggerere. See Agger
entry.def: To heap up.
entry.q: The violence of the waters aggested the earth.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Agglomerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Agglomerating
entry.ety: L. agglomeratus, p. p. of agglomerare; ad + glomerare to form into a ball. See Glomerate
entry.def: To wind or collect into a ball; hence, to gather into a mass or anything like a mass.
entry.q: Where he builds the agglomerated pile.

entry.def: To collect in a mass.

sn.def: Collected into a ball, heap, or mass.
Collected into a rounded head of flowers.
A collection or mass.
A mass of angular volcanic fragments united by heat; -- distinguished from conglomerate.
clustered together but not coherent.
The act or process of collecting in a mass; a heaping together.
sn.q: An excessive agglomeration of turrets.

sn.def: State of being collected in a mass; a mass; cluster.

entry.def: Having a tendency to gather together, or to make collections.
entry.q: Taylor is eminently discursive, accumulative, and (to use one of his own wordsagglomerative.

entry.ety: L. agglutinans -antis, p. pr. of agglutinare
entry.def: Uniting, as glue; causing, or tending to cause, adhesion.

def2.def: Any viscous substance which causes bodies or parts to adhere.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Agglutinated; p. pr. & vb. n. Agglutinating
entry.ety: L. agglutinatus, p. p. of agglutinare to glue or cement to a thing; ad + glutinare to glue; gluten glue. See Glue
entry.def: To unite, or cause to adhere, as with glue or other viscous substance; to unite by causing an adhesion of substances.

sn.def: United with glue or as with glue; cemented together.
Consisting of root words combined but not materially altered as to form or meaning; as, agglutinate forms, languages, etc. See Agglutination, 2.
The act of uniting by glue or other tenacious substance; the state of being thus united; adhesion of parts.
Combination in which root words are united with little or no change of form or loss of meaning. See Agglutinative, 2.
Pertaining to agglutination; tending to unite, or having power to cause adhesion; adhesive.
Formed or characterized by agglutination, as a language or a compound.
sn.q: In agglutinative languages the union of words may be compared to mechanical compounds, in inflective languages to chemical compounds.
Cf. man-kind heir-loom war-like, which are agglutinative compounds. The Finnish, Hungarian, Turkish, the Tamul, etc., are agglutinative languages.
Agglutinative languages preserve the consciousness of their roots.

entry.ety: Pref. a- + grace: cf. It. aggraziare, LL. aggratiare. See Grace
entry.def: To favor; to grace.
entry.q: That knight so muchaggraced.

entry.def: Grace; favor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aggraded; p. pr. & vb. n. Aggrading
entry.def: To bring, or tend to bring, to a uniform grade, or slope, by addition of material; as, streams aggrade their beds by depositing sediment.
Capable of being aggrandized.
Aggrandizement.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aggrandized; p. pr. & vb. n. Aggrandizing
entry.ety: F. agrandir; àL. ad) + grandir to increase, L. grandire, fr. grandis great. See Grand, and cf. Finish

sn.def: To make great; to enlarge; to increase; as, to aggrandize our conceptions, authority, distress.
To make great or greater in power, rank, honor, or wealth; -- applied to persons, countries, etc.
sn.q: His scheme for aggrandizing his son.

sn.def: To make appear great or greater; to exalt.

entry.def: To increase or become great.
entry.q: Follies, continued till old age, do aggrandize.

entry.def: The act of aggrandizing, or the state of being aggrandized or exalted in power, rank, honor, or wealth; exaltation; enlargement; as, the emperor seeks only the aggrandizement of his own family.
entry.syn: Augmentation; exaltation; enlargement; advancement; promotion; preferment.

entry.def: One who aggrandizes, or makes great.

entry.ety: It. aggratare, fr. L. ad + gratus pleasing. See Grate a.
entry.def: To please.
entry.q: Each one sought his lady to aggrate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aggravated; p. pr. & vb. n. Aggravating
entry.ety: L. aggravatus, p. p. of aggravare. See Aggrieve

sn.def: To make heavy or heavier; to add to; to increase.
sn.q: Toaggravatethy store.

sn.def: To make worse, or more severe; to render less tolerable or less excusable; to make more offensive; to enhance; to intensify.
sn.q: Toaggravatemy woes.
To aggravate the horrors of the scene.
The defense made by the prisoner's counsel did rather aggravate than extenuate his crime.

sn.def: To give coloring to in description; to exaggerate; as, to aggravate circumstances.
To exasperate; to provoke; to irritate.
sn.q: If both were to aggravate her parents, as my brother and sister do mine.
sn.syn: To heighten; intensify; increase; magnify; exaggerate; provoke; irritate; exasperate.

sn.def: made more severe or intense, especially in law; as, aggravated assault.
incited, especially deliberately, to anger.
Making worse or more heinous; as, aggravating circumstances.
Exasperating; provoking; irritating.
sn.q: A thing at once ridiculous and aggravating.

entry.def: In an aggravating manner.

sn.def: The act of aggravating, or making worse; -- used of evils, natural or moral; the act of increasing in severity or heinousness; something additional to a crime or wrong and enhancing its guilt or injurious consequences.
Exaggerated representation.
sn.q: By a little aggravation of the features changed it into the Saracen's head.

sn.def: An extrinsic circumstance or accident which increases the guilt of a crime or the misery of a calamity.
Provocation; irritation.

entry.def: Tending to aggravate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aggregated; p. pr. & vb. n. Aggregating
entry.ety: L. aggregatus, p. p. of aggregare to lead to a flock or herd; ad + gregare to collect into a flock, grex flock, herd. See Gregarious

sn.def: To bring together; to collect into a mass or sum. “The aggregated soil.”
To add or unite, as, a person, to an association.
sn.q: It is many times hard to discern to which of the two sorts, the good or the bad, a man ought to be aggregated.

sn.def: To amount in the aggregate to; as, ten loads, aggregating five hundred bushels.
sn.syn: To heap up; accumulate; pile; collect.

entry.cs: Corporation aggregate. Law See under Corporation.

sn.def: Formed by a collection of particulars into a whole mass or sum; collective.
sn.q: The aggregate testimony of many hundreds.

sn.def: Formed into clusters or groups of lobules; as, aggregate glands.
Composed of several florets within a common involucre, as in the daisy; or of several carpels formed from one flower, as in the raspberry.
Having the several component parts adherent to each other only to such a degree as to be separable by mechanical means.
United into a common organized mass; -- said of certain compound animals.

entry.note: ☞ In an aggregate the particulars are less intimately mixed than in a compound.

cs.cd: collectively; together.

sn.def: A mass, assemblage, or sum of particulars; as, a house is an aggregate of stone, brick, timber, etc.
A mass formed by the union of homogeneous particles; -- in distinction from a compound, formed by the union of heterogeneous particles.

entry.def: Collectively; in mass.
The act of aggregating, or the state of being aggregated; collection into a mass or sum; a collection of particulars; an aggregate.
entry.q: Each genus is made up by aggregation of species.
A nation is not an idea only of local extent and individual momentary aggregation, but . . . of continuity, which extends in time as well as in numbers, and in space.

sn.def: Taken together; collective.
Gregarious; social.
tending to gather into a mass.

entry.def: One who aggregates.
To make heavy; to aggravate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aggressed; p. pr. & vb. n. Aggressing
entry.ety: L. aggressus, p. p. of aggredi to go to, approach; ad + gradi to step, go, gradus step: cf. OF. aggresser. See Grade
entry.def: To commit the first act of hostility or offense; to begin a quarrel or controversy; to make an attack; -- with on.

sn.def: take the initiative and go on the offensive, as in a game.

entry.def: To set upon; to attack.
Aggression.
entry.q: Their military aggresses on others.

entry.ety: L. aggressio, fr. aggredi: cf. F. agression
entry.def: The first attack, or act of hostility; the first act of injury, or first act leading to a war or a controversy; unprovoked attack; assault; as, a war of aggression . “Aggressions of power.”

entry.note: Narrower related terms: bellicose, combative, pugnacious, scrappy, truculent ; hard-hitting, high-pressure ; hostileused of attempts to buy or take control of a business: "hostile takeover"; "hostile tender offer"); predatory, rapacious, raptorial, ravening, vulturine, vulturous . See also: assertive, hostile, offensive.

sn.def: Tending or disposed to aggress; having or showing determination and energetic pursuit of one's own ends at the expense of others or mindless of others' needs or desires; characterized by aggression; making assaults; unjustly attacking; as, an aggressive policy, war, person, nation; an aggressive businessman; an aggressive basketball player; he was aggressive and imperious in his convictions; aggressive drivers. Opposite of unaggressive.
sn.q: No aggressive movement was made.

sn.def: marked by self-confident ambition, competitiveness, energy and initiative; as, an aggressive young executive.

entry.sn: 1 Med., Biol tending to spread quickly an aggressive tumorNarrower terms: invasive (vs. noninvasive fast-growing(prenominal

sn.def: characteristic of an enemy or one eager to fight

entry.def: The person who first attacks or makes an aggression; he who begins hostility or a quarrel; an assailant.
entry.q: The insolence of the aggressor is usually proportioned to the tameness of the sufferer.

entry.ety: OF. agrevance, fr. agrever. See Aggrieve
entry.def: Oppression; hardship; injury; grievance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aggrieved; p. pr. & vb. n. Aggrieving
entry.ety: OE. agreven, OF. agrever; aL. ad) + grever to burden, injure, L. gravare to weigh down, fr. gravis heavy. See Grieve, and cf. Aggravate
entry.def: To give pain or sorrow to; to afflict; hence, to oppress or injure in one's rights; to bear heavily upon; -- now commonly used in the passive TO be aggrieved.
entry.q: Aggrieved by oppression and extortion.

entry.def: To grieve; to lament.

sn.def: subjected to an injustice.
aggravation or aggression.
sn.illu: I skipped it because it was too much aggro

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aggrouped; p. pr. & vb. n. Aggrouping
entry.ety: F. agrouper; àL. ad) + groupe group. See Group.
entry.def: To bring together in a group; to group.
Arrangement in a group or in groups; grouping.
Applied to a kind of variegated glass beads of ancient manufacture; as, aggry beads are found in Ashantee and Fantee in Africa.
See Agast v. t.

entry.ety: OE. agast agasted, p. p. of agasten to terrify, fr. AS. pref. ā-cf. Goth. us-, G. er-, orig. meaning out) + g�stan to terrify, torment: cf. Goth. usgaisjan to terrify, primitively to fix, to root to the spot with terror; akin to L. haerere to stick fast, cling. See Gaze Hesitate
entry.def: Terrified; struck with amazement; showing signs of terror or horror.
entry.q: Aghast he waked; and, starting from his bed, Cold sweat in clammy drops his limbs o'erspread.
The commissioners read and stood aghast.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. agibilis, fr. L. agere to move, do
entry.def: Possible to be done; practicable.
entry.q: Fit foragiblethings.

entry.ety: F. agile, L. agilis, fr. agere to move. See Agent
entry.def: Having the faculty of quick motion in the limbs; apt or ready to move; nimble; active; as, an agile boy; an agile tongue.
entry.q: Shaking it with agile hand.
entry.syn: Active; alert; nimble; brisk; lively; quick.

entry.def: In an agile manner; nimbly.
Agility; nimbleness.

entry.ety: F. agilié, L. agilitas, fr. agilis

sn.def: The quality of being agile; the power of moving the limbs quickly and easily; nimbleness; activity; quickness of motion; as, strength and agility of body.
sn.q: They . . . trust to the agility of their wit.
Wheeling with the agility of a hawk.

sn.def: Activity; powerful agency.
sn.q: The agility of the sun's fiery heat.

sn.def: a battle in which English longbowmen under Henry V decisively defeated a much larger French army in 1415. It was named for the site at which it occurred.

entry.def: the process by which objects or materials acquire desirable qualities by being left undisturbed for some time under specific conditions. It is used mostly for foods snd beverages, but also for other materials.

entries.entry: Ag"i*o n.; pl.Agios. It. aggio exchange, discount, premium, the same word as agio ease. See Ease Com The premium or percentage on a better sort of money when it is given in exchange for an inferior sort. The premium or discount on foreign bills of exchange is sometimes called agio.

entry.ety: F. agiotage, fr. agioter to practice stockjobbing, fr. agio
entry.def: Exchange business; also, stockjobbing; the maneuvers of speculators to raise or lower the price of stocks or public funds.
entry.q: Vanity and agiotage are to a Parisian the oxygen and hydrogen of life.

entry.def: discrimination against middle-aged and elderly people.

entry.ety: OF. agister; àL. ad) + gister to assign a lodging, fr. giste lodging, abode, F. gîte, LL. gistum gista, fr. L. jacitum, p. p. of jac�re to lie: cf. LL. agistare adgistare. See Gist
entry.def: To take to graze or pasture, at a certain sum; -- used originally of the feeding of cattle in the king's forests, and collecting the money for the same.
See Agister.
Formerly, an officer of the king's forest, who had the care of cattle agisted, and collected the money for the same; -- hence called gisttaker, which in England is corrupted into guest-taker.
Now, one who agists or takes in cattle to pasture at a certain rate; a pasturer.
Formerly, the taking and feeding of other men's cattle in the king's forests.
The taking in by any one of other men's cattle to graze at a certain rate.
The price paid for such feeding.
A charge or rate against lands; as, an agistment of sea banks, i. e., charge for banks or dikes.
Capable of being agitated, or easily moved.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Agitated; p. pr. & vb. n. Agitating
entry.ety: L. agitatus, p. p. of agitare to put in motion, fr. agere to move: cf. F. agiter. See Act Agent

sn.def: To move with a violent, irregular action; as, the wind agitates the sea; to agitate water in a vessel.
sn.q: Winds . . .agitatethe air.

sn.def: To move or actuate.
To stir up; to disturb or excite; to perturb; as, he was greatly agitated .
sn.q: The mind of man is agitated by various passions.

sn.def: To discuss with great earnestness; to debate; as, a controversy hotly agitated .
To revolve in the mind, or view in all its aspects; to contrive busily; to devise; to plot; as, politicians agitate desperate designs.
sn.syn: To move; shake; excite; rouse; disturb; distract; revolve; discuss; debate; canvass.

entry.note: Narrower terms are: demoniac, demoniacal ; distraught, overwrought; disturbed, jolted, shaken; feverish, hectic; frantic, frenetic, phrenetic, frenzied; psychedelic ; rampageous, raging, frenzied ; wild-eyed .
Narrower terms are: churning, churned-up, roiling, roiled, roily, turbulent ; stirred

sn.def: troubled emotionally and usually deeply. Opposite of unagitated.
sn.see: Also See: discomposed excited impatient tense unquiet unsteady.

sn.def: throwing oneself from side to side.
physically disturbed or set in motion; as, the agitated mixture foamed and bubbled. Opposite of unagitated and left alone allowed to stand.

entry.def: In an agitated manner.

sn.def: The act of agitating, or the state of being agitated; the state of being moved with violence, or with irregular action; commotion; as, the sea after a storm is in agitation .
A stirring up or arousing; disturbance of tranquillity; disturbance of mind which shows itself by physical excitement; perturbation; as, to cause any one agitation .
Excitement of public feeling by discussion, appeals, etc.; as, the antislavery agitation; labor agitation.
sn.q: Religiousagitations.

sn.def: Examination or consideration of a subject in controversy, or of a plan proposed for adoption; earnest discussion; debate.
sn.q: A logical agitation of the matter.
The project now in agitation.
sn.syn: Emotion; commotion; excitement; trepidation; tremor; perturbation. See Emotion.

sn.def: causing or tending to cause anger or resentment.

entry.def: Tending to agitate.
Sung or played in a restless, hurried, and spasmodic manner.

sn.def: One who agitates; one who stirs up or excites others; as, political reformers and agitators .
One of a body of men appointed by the army, in Cromwell's time, to look after their interests; -- called also adjutators.
An implement for shaking or mixing.
agitation and propaganda; -- used especially for such activities carried out on behalf of communist activists.
a person who disseminates messages calculated to assist some cause or some government; one disseminating agitprop{1. Also called agitpropist.

entry.def: same as agitprop{2.
a genus of snakes comprising the copperheads.

sn.def: a genus of epiphytic ferns of tropical Asia.
a genus of Indo-Malayan climbing herbs having thick fleshy oblong leaves and naked unisexual flowers: Chinese evergreen.

entry.def: Gleaming; as, faces agleam .

entry.ety: F. aiguillette point, tagged point, dim. of aiguilee needle, fr. LL. acucula for acicula, dim. of L. acus needle, pin; cf. OF. agleter to hook on. See Acute, and cf. Aiguillette

sn.def: A tag of a lace or of the points, braids, or cords formerly used in dress. They were sometimes formed into small images. Hence, “aglet baby” (Shak.), an aglet image.
A round white staylace.

entry.def: Aside; askew.
In a glimmering state.
Glittering; in a glitter.
Without tongue; tongueless.
In a glow; glowing; as, cheeks aglow; the landscape all aglow.

entry.ety: Pref. a- not + L. glutire to swallow
entry.def: Inability to swallow.

entry.ety: L. agminalis; agmen agminis, a train
entry.def: Pertaining to an army marching, or to a train.

entry.ety: L. agmen agminis, a train, crowd
entry.def: Grouped together; as, the agminated glands of Peyer in the small intestine.

entry.ety: AS. angnægl; ange vexation, trouble + nægel nail. Cf. Hangnail

sn.def: A corn on the toe or foot.
An inflammation or sore under or around the nail; also, a hangnail.

entry.ety: L. agnatus, p. p. of agnasci to be born in addition to; ad + nascifor gnasci) to be born. Cf. Adnate

sn.def: Related or akin by the father's side; also, sprung from the same male ancestor; as, agnate brother: a brother having the same father, but a different mother; in ths sense it is a correlative of uterine.
Allied; akin.
sn.q: Agnatewords.
Assume more or less of a fictitious character, but congenial and agnate with the former.

entry.def: A relative whose relationship can be traced exclusively through males.
a class of eel-shaped chordates with a cartilaginous skeleton lacking jaws, scales, and pelvic fins. Among these are the lampreys and hagfishes. There are some extinct forms.

sn.def: an eel-shaped vertebrate without jaws or paired appendages; a member of the Agnatha. The group includes the cyclostomes and some extinct forms.

entry.def: Pertaining to descent by the male line of ancestors.
entry.q: Theagnaticsuccession.

sn.def: Consanguinity by a line of males only, as distinguished from cognation.
be fully aware or cognizant of.

entry.ety: L. agnitio, fr. agnoscere. See Notion
entry.def: Acknowledgment.

entry.ety: Formed like recognize, fr. L. agnoscere
entry.def: To recognize; to acknowledge.
entry.q: I do agnize a natural and prompt alacrity.

entry.def: The doctrine concerning those things of which we are necessarily ignorant.

sn.def: An additional or fourth name given by the Romans, on account of some remarkable exploit or event; as, Publius Caius Scipio Africanus .
An additional name, or an epithet appended to a name; as, Aristides the Just .

entry.def: To name.

sn.def: A surname.
Paronomasia; also, alliteration; annomination.

entry.def: Professing ignorance; involving no dogmatic; pertaining to or involving agnosticism.

One who professes ignorance, or denies that we have any knowledge, save of phenomena; one who supports agnosticism, neither affirming nor denying the existence of a personal Deity, a future life, etc.

sn.def: of or pertaining to agnosticism; agnostic.

entry.def: That doctrine which, professing ignorance, neither asserts nor denies.

The doctrine that the existence of a personal Deity, an unseen world, etc., can be neither proved nor disproved, because of the necessary limits of the human mind (as sometimes charged upon Hamilton and Mansel), or because of the insufficiency of the evidence furnished by physical and physical data, to warrant a positive conclusion (as taught by the school of Herbert Spencer); -- opposed alike dogmatic skepticism and to dogmatic theism.

entries.entry: Ag"nus Ag"nus n.; pl. E. Agnuses; L. Agni. L., a lamb Agnus Dei.

Ag"nus cas"tus Ag"nus cas"tus. Gr. � a willowlike tree, used at a religious festival; confused with � holy, chaste Bot A species of Vitex Vitex agnus castus); the chaste tree. And wreaths of agnus castus others bore.

Ag"nus De"i Ag"nus De"i. L., lamb of God R. C. Ch A figure of a lamb bearing a cross or flag. A cake of wax stamped with such a figure. It is made from the remains of the paschal candles and blessed by the Pope. A triple prayer in the sacrifice of the Mass, beginning with the words “Agnus Dei.”
Ag"nus Scyth"i*cus Ag"nus Scyth"i*cus. L., Scythian lamb Bot The Scythian lamb, a kind of woolly-skinned rootstock. See Barometz.

entry.ety: OE. ago agon, p. p. of agon to go away, pass by, AS. āgān to pass away; ā-cf. Goth. us-, Ger. er-, orig. meaning out) + gān to go. See Go
entry.def: Past; gone by; since; as, ten years ago; gone long ago.

entry.ety: Cf. F. gogue fun, perhaps of Celtic origin
entry.def: In eager desire; eager; astir.
entry.q: All agog to dash through thick and thin.

entry.ety: Pref. a- + p. pr. of go
entry.def: In motion; in the act of going; as, to set a mill agoing .

entries.entry: Ag"on Ag"on n.; pl.Agones. Gr. �, fr. � to lead Gr. Antiq A contest for a prize at the public games.

entry.def: Ago.
entry.q: Three days agone I fell sick.

entry.def: Agonic line.

cs.cd: an imaginary line on the earth's surface passing through those places where the magnetic needle points to the true north; the line of no magnetic variation. There is one such line in the Western hemisphere, and another in the Eastern hemisphere.

entry.ety: Gr. � without angles; 'a priv. + � an angle
entry.def: Not forming an angle.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to contend for a prize, fr. �. See Agon
entry.def: Contention for a prize; a contest.
One who contends for the prize in public games.
Pertaining to violent contests, bodily or mental; pertaining to athletic or polemic feats; athletic; combative; hence, strained; unnatural.
entry.q: As a scholar, he [Dr. Parr] was brilliant, but he consumed his power in agonistic displays.

entry.def: In an agonistic manner.
The science of athletic combats, or contests in public games.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Agonized; p. pr. & vb. n. Agonizing
entry.ety: F. agoniser, LL. agonizare, fr. Gr. �. See Agony

sn.def: To writhe with agony; to suffer violent anguish.
sn.q: To smart and agonize at every pore.

sn.def: To struggle; to wrestle; to strive desperately.

entry.def: To cause to suffer agony; to subject to extreme pain; to torture.
entry.q: He agonized his mother by his behavior.

sn.def: expressing pain or agony.

entry.def: causing agony. Opposite to painless.
With extreme anguish or desperate struggles.
An officer who presided over the great public games in Greece.
Pertaining to the office of an agonothete.

entries.entry:
Ag"o*ny
Agony Anguish Pang. These words agree in expressing extreme pain of body or mind. Agony denotes acute and permanent pain, usually of the whole system., and often producing contortions. Anguish denotes severe pressure, and, considered as bodily suffering, is more commonly local (as anguish of a wound), thus differing from agony. A pang is a paroxysm of excruciating pain. It is severe and transient. The agonies or pangs of remorse; the anguish of a wounded conscience. “Oh, sharp convulsive pangs of agonizing pride!” n.; pl.Agonies. L. agonia, Gr. �, orig. a contest, fr. �: cf. F. agonie. See Agon
Violent contest or striving. The world is convulsed by the agonies of great nations.
Pain so extreme as to cause writhing or contortions of the body, similar to those made in the athletic contests in Greece; and hence, extreme pain of mind or body; anguish; paroxysm of grief; specifically, the sufferings of Christ in the garden of Gethsemane. Being in an agony he prayed more earnestly.
Paroxysm of joy; keen emotion. With cries and agonies of wild delight.
The last struggle of life; death struggle. Anguish; torment; throe; distress; pangs; suffering.

entry.def: In earnest; heartily.
entry.q: I made her weepagood.

entry.def: An assembly; hence, the place of assembly, especially the market place, in an ancient Greek city.
The crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus), found in the tropical parts of America.
A small insectivorous mammal (Solenodon paradoxus), allied to the moles, found only in Haiti.

entry.ety: F. agouti acouti, Sp. aguti, fr. native name

sn.def: A rodent of the genus Dasyprocta, about the size of a rabbit, peculiar to South America and the West Indies. The most common species is the Dasyprocta agouti.
the color of the agouti{1}, a grayish-brown of grizzled texture; -- used especially to describe the color of the fur of a strain of mice. Also used attributively.

entry.def: See Aggrace.

entry.ety: F. agrafe, formerly agraffe, OF. agrappe. See Agrappes

sn.def: A hook or clasp.
sn.q: The feather of an ostrich, fastened in her turban by an agraffe set with brilliants.

sn.def: A hook, eyelet, or other device by which a piano wire is so held as to limit the vibration.

entry.ety: Gr. � illiterate; 'a priv. + � letters, fr. � to write
entry.def: A illiterate person.
The absence or loss of the power of expressing ideas by written signs. It is one form of aphasia.
Characterized by agraphia.

entry.ety: OF. agrappe, F. agrafe; a + grappesee Grape) fr. OHG. krāpfo hook
entry.def: Hooks and eyes for armor, etc.

sn.def: Pertaining to fields, or lands, or their tenure; esp., relating to an equal or equitable division of lands; as, the agrarian laws of Rome, which distributed the conquered and other public lands among citizens.
sn.q: His Grace's landed possessions are irresistibly inviting to an agrarian experiment.

sn.def: Wild; -- said of plants growing in the fields.
One in favor of an equal division of landed property.
An agrarian law.
sn.q: An equal agrarian is perpetual law.

entry.def: An equal or equitable division of landed property; the principles or acts of those who favor a redistribution of land.
To distribute according to, or to imbue with, the principles of agrarianism.
In good part; kindly.

entry.note: ☞ The auxiliary forms of to be are often employed with the participle agreed. “The jury were agreed.” Macaulay. “Can two walk together, except they be agreed ?” Amos iii. 3. The principal intransitive uses were probably derived from the transitive verb used reflexively. “I agree me well to your desire.” Ld. Berners.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Agreed; p. pr. & vb. n. Agreeing
entry.ety: F. agréer to accept or receive kindly, fr. à gré; àL. ad) + gré good will, consent, liking, fr. L. gratus pleasing, agreeable. See Grateful

sn.def: To harmonize in opinion, statement, or action; to be in unison or concord; to be or become united or consistent; to concur; as, all parties agree in the expediency of the law.
sn.q: If music and sweet poetry agree.
Their witness agreed not together.
The more you agree together, the less hurt can your enemies do you.

sn.def: To yield assent; to accede; -- followed by to; as, to agree to an offer, or to opinion.
To make a stipulation by way of settling differences or determining a price; to exchange promises; to come to terms or to a common resolve; to promise.
sn.q: Agree with thine adversary quickly.
Didst not thou agree with me for a penny ?

sn.def: To be conformable; to resemble; to coincide; to correspond; as, the picture does not agree with the original; the two scales agree exactly.
To suit or be adapted in its effects; to do well; as, the same food does not agree with every constitution.
To correspond in gender, number, case, or person.
sn.syn: To assent; concur; consent; acquiesce; accede; engage; promise; stipulate; contract; bargain; correspond; harmonize; fit; tally; coincide; comport.

sn.def: To make harmonious; to reconcile or make friends.
To admit, or come to one mind concerning; to settle; to arrange; as, to agree the fact; to agree differences.
Easiness of disposition.
The quality of being, or making one's self, agreeable; agreeableness.
Pleasing, either to the mind or senses; pleasant; grateful; as, agreeable manners or remarks; an agreeable person; fruit agreeable to the taste.
sn.q: A train of agreeable reveries.

sn.def: Willing; ready to agree or consent.
sn.q: These Frenchmen give unto the said captain of Calais a great sum of money, so that he will be but content and agreeable that they may enter into the said town.

sn.def: Agreeing or suitable; conformable; correspondent; concordant; adapted; -- followed by to, rarely by with.
sn.q: That which is agreeable to the nature of one thing, is many times contrary to the nature of another.

sn.def: In pursuance, conformity, or accordance; -- in this sense used adverbially for agreeably; as, agreeable to the order of the day, the House took up the report.
sn.syn: Pleasing; pleasant; welcome; charming; acceptable; amiable. See Pleasant.

sn.def: The quality of being agreeable or pleasing; that quality which gives satisfaction or moderate pleasure to the mind or senses.
sn.q: That author . . . has an agreeableness that charms us.

sn.def: The quality of being agreeable or suitable; suitableness or conformity; consistency.
sn.q: The agreeableness of virtuous actions to human nature.

sn.def: Resemblance; concordance; harmony; -- with to or between.
sn.q: The agreeableness between man and the other parts of the universe.

sn.def: In an agreeably manner; in a manner to give pleasure; pleasingly.
sn.q: Agreeablyentertained.

sn.def: In accordance; suitably; consistently; conformably; -- followed by to and rarely by with. See Agreeable, 4.
sn.q: The effect of which is, that marriages grow less frequent, agreeably to the maxim above laid down.

sn.def: Alike; similarly.
sn.q: Both clad in shepherds' weeds agreeably.

sn.def: in agreement; of the same mind; having the same opinion.
expressing agreement or consent.

entry.def: In an agreeing manner (to); correspondingly; agreeably.

sn.def: State of agreeing; harmony of opinion, statement, action, or character; concurrence; concord; conformity; as, a good agreement subsists among the members of the council.
sn.q: What agreement hath the temple of God with idols ?
Expansion and duration have this further agreement.

sn.def: Concord or correspondence of one word with another in gender, number, case, or person.

sd.def: A concurrence in an engagement that something shall be done or omitted; an exchange of promises; mutual understanding, arrangement, or stipulation; a contract.
The language, oral or written, embodying reciprocal promises.

entry.def: One who agrees.
Pertaining to fields or the country, in opposition to the city; rural; rustic; unpolished; uncouth.
entry.q: Agresticbehavior.

entry.def: Agrestic.
Agriculture.
A cultivator of the soil; an agriculturist.

entry.ety: L., fr. ager field + cultor cultivator
entry.def: An agriculturist; a farmer.

cs.cd: a species of ant which gathers and stores seeds of grasses, for food. The remarkable species (Myrmica barbata) found in Texas clears circular areas and carefully cultivates its favorite grain, known as ant rice.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to agriculture; connected with, or engaged in, tillage; as, the agricultural class; agricultural implements, wages, etc.
An agriculturist (which is the preferred form

entry.ety: L. agricultura; ager field + cultura cultivation: cf. F. agriculture. See Acre and Culture
entry.def: The art or science of cultivating the ground, including the harvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of live stock; tillage; husbandry; farming.
Agriculture.
One engaged or skilled in agriculture; a husbandman.
entry.q: The farmer is always a practitioner, the agriculturist may be a mere theorist.

entry.def: In grief; amiss.

entry.note: ☞ The Agrimonia eupatoria, or common agrimony, a perennial herb with a spike of yellow flowers, was once esteemed as a medical remedy, but is now seldom used.
entry.ety: OE. agremoyne, OF. aigremoine, L. agrimonia for argemonia, fr. Gr. �
entry.def: A genus of plants of the Rose family.
The name is also given to various other plants; as, hemp agrimony Eupatorium cannabinum); water agrimony Bidens).
In the act of grinning.
entry.q: His visage allagrin.

entry.def: One versed or engaged in agriology.
Description or comparative study of the customs of savage or uncivilized tribes.

entry.ety: AS. āgrīsan to dread; ā-cf. Goth. us-, Ger. er-, orig. meaning out) + grīsan, for gr�sanonly in comp.), akin to OHG. gr�is�n, G. grausen, to shudder. See Grisly
entry.def: To shudder with terror; to tremble with fear.

sn.def: To shudder at; to abhor; to dread; to loathe.
To terrify; to affright.
sn.q: His manly face that did his foes agrise.

entry.def: of or pertaining to agrology.

sn.def: the science of soils in relation to crops.

entry.def: A disease occurring in Bengal and other parts of the East Indies, in which the tongue chaps and cleaves.
Pertaining to agronomy, of the management of farms.

sn.def: of or pertaining to agronomy.

entry.def: The science of the distribution and management of land.
One versed in agronomy; a student of agronomy.

entry.ety: Gr. � rural; as a noun, an overseer of the public lands; � field + � usage, � to deal out, manage: cf. F. agronomie
entry.def: The management of land; rural economy; agriculture.
In the act of groping.

sn.def: a genus comprising the corncockles.

entry.def: A genus of grasses, including species called in common language bent grass. Some of them, as redtop (Agrostis vulgaris), are valuable pasture grasses.
Pertaining to agrostography.
A description of the grasses.
Pertaining to agrostology.
One skilled in agrostology.
That part of botany which treats of the grasses.
On the ground; stranded; -- a nautical term applied to a ship when its bottom lodges on the ground.
See Aggroupment.

entry.ety: Gr. � sleepless; � to chase, search for + � sleep: cf. F. agrypnotique
entry.def: Anything which prevents sleep, or produces wakefulness, as strong tea or coffee.

entry.ety: Sp., contr. of agua ardiente burning water (L. aqua water + ardens burning)

sn.def: A inferior brandy of Spain and Portugal.
A strong alcoholic drink, especially pulque.

cs.cd: an enlargement of the spleen produced by ague.
a solution of the arsenite of potassa used for ague.
a fit of the ague.
a spell or charm against ague.
the sassafras, -- sometimes so called from the use of its root formerly, in cases of ague.

entry.ety: OE. agu ague, OF. agu, F. aigu, sharp, OF. fem. ague, LL. (febrisacuta, a sharp, acute fever, fr. L. acutus sharp. See Acute

sn.q: Brenningagues.

The cold fit or rigor of the intermittent fever; as, fever and ague .
A chill, or state of shaking, as with cold.

To dress; to attire; to adorn.
entry.q: Above all knights ye goodly seem aguised.

sn.def: Productive of, or affected by, ague; as, the aguish districts of England.

entry.def: In a gushing state.
Without female organs; male.

entry.ety: OE. a: cf. OF. a, F. ah, L. ah, Gr. �, Sk. ā, Icel. æ, OHG. ā, Lith. á áá
entry.def: An exclamation, expressive of surprise, pity, complaint, entreaty, contempt, threatening, delight, triumph, etc., according to the manner of utterance.
An exclamation expressing, by different intonations, triumph, mixed with derision or irony, or simple surprise.
A sunk fence. See Ha-ha.

entry.cs: To go ahead. To go in advance. To go on onward. To push on in an enterprise. Colloq To get ahead of. To get in advance of. To surpass; to get the better of. Colloq

sn.def: In or to the front; in advance; onward.
sn.q: The island bore but a little ahead of us.

sn.def: Headlong; without restraint.

Aloft; on high.
entry.q: Look upaheight.

entry.def: An exclamation to call one's attention; hem.
Hey; ho.
On high.
Near the wind; as, to lay a ship ahold .
On horseback.

The Evil Principle or Being of the ancient Persians; the Prince of Darkness as opposer to Ormuzd, the King of Light.
The Asiatic gazelle.
With the sails furled, and the helm lashed alee; -- applied to ships in a storm. See Hull n.
Pinched with hunger; very hungry.

entries.entry:
A"i n.; pl.Ais. Braz. aï haï, from the animal's cry: cf. F. aï
Zoöl The three-toed sloth (Bradypus tridactylus) of South America. See Sloth.

entry.def: Perhaps; possibly.

entries.entry: Aich's met"al. A kind of gun metal, containing copper, zinc, and iron, but no tin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aided; p. pr. & vb. n. Aiding
entry.ety: F. aider, OF. aidier, fr. L. adjutare to help, freq. of adjuvare to help; ad + juvare to help. Cf. Adjutant
entry.def: To support, either by furnishing strength or means in coöperation to effect a purpose, or to prevent or to remove evil; to help; to assist.
entry.q: You speedy helpers . . . Appear and aid me in this enterprise.
entry.syn: To help; assist; support; sustain; succor; relieve; befriend; coöperate; promote. See Help.

cs.cd: a proceeding by which a defendant beseeches and claims assistance from some one who has a further or more permanent interest in the matter in suit.
to beseech and claim such assistance.

entry.ety: F. aide, OF. aïde aïe, fr. the verb. See Aid v. t.

sn.def: Help; succor; assistance; relief.
sn.q: An unconstitutional mode of obtaining aid.

sn.def: The person or thing that promotes or helps in something done; a helper; an assistant.
sn.q: It is not good that man should be alone; let us make unto him an aid like unto himself.

sn.def: A subsidy granted to the king by Parliament; also, an exchequer loan.
A pecuniary tribute paid by a vassal to his lord on special occasions.
An aid-de-camp, so called by abbreviation; as, a general's aid .

entry.def: Aid.
entry.q: Aidance 'gainst the enemy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. aidant, p. pr. of aider to help
entry.def: Helping; helpful; supplying aid.

entries.entry: Aid"-de-camp` n.; pl.Aids-de-camp. . F. aide de campliterally) camp assistant Mil An officer selected by a general to carry orders, also to assist or represent him in correspondence and in directing movements.

entry.def: One who, or that which, aids.
Helpful.
Helpless; without aid.
The adjutant of a regiment.
See Ayle.
Same as Aglet.
Sour.
Charcoal prepared for making powder.

entry.ety: F., a sort of white heron, with a tuft of feathers on its head; a tuft of feathers; dim. of the same word as heron. See Heron, and cf. Egret Egrette

sn.def: The small white European heron. See Egret.
A plume or tuft for the head composed of feathers, or of gems, etc.
A tuft like that of the egret.
A feathery crown of seed; egret; as, the aigrette or down of the dandelion or the thistle.
A needle-shaped peak.
An instrument for boring holes, used in blasting.
A point or tag at the end of a fringe or lace; an aglet.
One of the ornamental tags, cords, or loops on some military and naval uniforms.

entry.def: See Aglet.

entry.note: ☞ It is never used to express a specific disease. We do not say, a fever ails him; but, something ails him.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ailed āld; p. pr. & vb. n. Ailing
entry.ety: OE. eilen ailen, AS. eglan to trouble, pain; akin to Goth. us-agljan to distress, agls troublesome, irksome, aglo aglitha, pain, and prob. to E. awe. √3
entry.def: To affect with pain or uneasiness, either physical or mental; to trouble; to be the matter with; -- used to express some uneasiness or affection, whose cause is unknown; as, what ails the man? I know not what ails him.
entry.q: What aileth thee, Hagar?

entry.def: To be affected with pain or uneasiness of any sort; to be ill or indisposed or in trouble.
entry.q: When he ails ever so little . . . he is so peevish.

entry.def: Indisposition or morbid affection.
Same as Ailantus.

entry.ety: From aylanto, i. e., tree of heaven, the name of the tree in the Moluccas
entry.def: A genus of beautiful trees, natives of the East Indies. The tree imperfectly diœcious, and the staminate or male plant is very offensive when blossom.

sn.def: A half gable, as at the end of a penthouse or of the aisle of a church.
A small plane or surface capable of being manipulated by the pilot of a flying machine to control lateral balance; a hinged wing tip; a lateral stabilizing or balancing plane.

entry.ety: F. ailette, dim. of aile wing, L. ala
entry.def: A small square shield, formerly worn on the shoulders of knights, -- being the prototype of the modern epaulet.
sick; unhealthy. Opposite of well or healthy.
Indisposition; morbid affection of the body; -- not applied ordinarily to acute diseases.
entry.q: Littleailments.

entry.def: A group of the Carnivora, which includes the cats, civets, and hyenas.

sn.def: in some classifications considered the family comprising the giant pandas.
a genus comprising the lesser pandas.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aimed; p. pr. & vb. n. Aiming
entry.ety: OE. amen aimen eimen, to guess at, to estimate, to aim, OF. esmer asmer, fr. L. aestimare to estimate; or perh. fr. OF. aesmer; � (L. ad) + esmer. See Estimate

sn.def: To point or direct a missile weapon, or a weapon which propels as missile, towards an object or spot with the intent of hitting it; as, to aim at a fox, or at a target.
To direct the indention or purpose; to attempt the accomplishment of a purpose; to try to gain; to endeavor; -- followed by at, or by an infinitive; as, to aim at distinction; to aim to do well.
sn.q: Aim'st thou at princes?

sn.def: To guess or conjecture.

entry.def: To direct or point, as a weapon, at a particular object; to direct, as a missile, an act, or a proceeding, at, to, or against an object; as, to aim a musket or an arrow, the fist or a blow (at something); to aim a satire or a reflection (at some person or vice).

cs.cd: to encourage.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. esme estimation, fr. esmer. See Aim v. i.

sn.def: The pointing of a weapon, as a gun, a dart, or an arrow, in the line of direction with the object intended to be struck; the line of fire; the direction of anything, as a spear, a blow, a discourse, a remark, towards a particular point or object, with a view to strike or affect it.
sn.q: Each at the head leveled his deadly aim.

sn.def: The point intended to be hit, or object intended to be attained or affected.
sn.q: To be the aim of every dangerous shot.

sn.def: Intention; purpose; design; scheme.
sn.q: How oft ambitious aims are crossed!

sn.def: Conjecture; guess.
sn.q: What you would work me to, I have some aim.
sn.syn: End; object; scope; drift; design; purpose; intention; scheme; tendency; aspiration.

entry.def: One who aims, directs, or points.
Without aim or purpose; as, an aimless life.

sn.def: belonging to or on behalf of a specified person especially one's self; preceded by a possessive.

entry.ety: Said to be the native name for man
entry.def: same as Ainu.

entry.ety: Said to be the native name for man
entry.def: One of a peculiar race found primarily in Hokkaido, in the northern part of the empire of Japan, the Kurile Islands, and nearby. They are believed to be the native inhabitants of the Japanese islands. The Ainus are stout and short, with hairy bodies. Also called Aino and hairy Ainu.

entries.entry: Ain't. A contraction for are not and am not; also used for is not. Colloq. or illiterate speech. See An't.

entry.def: a French garlic-flavored mayonnaise. It is often served with fish and other seafood, and sometimes with vegetables.

entry.note: ☞ By the ancient philosophers, air was regarded as an element; but modern science has shown that it is essentially a mixture of oxygen and nitrogen, with a small amount of carbon dioxide, the average proportions being, by volume: oxygen, 20.96 per cent.; nitrogen, 79.00 per cent.; carbon dioxide, 0.04 per cent. These proportions are subject to a very slight variability. Air also always contains some vapor of water.

☞ Air is much used adjectively or as the first part of a compound term. In most cases it might be written indifferently, as a separate limiting word, or as the first element of the compound term, with or without the hyphen; as, air bladder, air-bladder, or airbladder; air cell, air-cell, or aircell; air-pump, or airpump.
entry.cs: Air balloon. See Balloon. Air bath. An apparatus for the application of air to the body. An arrangement for drying substances in air of any desired temperature. Air castle. See Castle in the air, under Castle. Air compressor a machine for compressing air to be used as a motive power. Air crossing a passage for air in a mine. Air cushion an air-tight cushion which can be inflated; also, a device for arresting motion without shock by confined air. Air fountain a contrivance for producing a jet of water by the force of compressed air. Air furnace a furnace which depends on a natural draft and not on blast. Air line a straight line; a bee line. Hence Air-line adj.; as, air-line road. Air lock Hydr. Engin an intermediate chamber between the outer air and the compressed-air chamber of a pneumatic caisson. Knight. Air port Nav a scuttle or porthole in a ship to admit air. Air spring a spring in which the elasticity of air is utilized. Air thermometer a form of thermometer in which the contraction and expansion of air is made to measure changes of temperature. Air threads gossamer. Air trap a contrivance for shutting off foul air or gas from drains, sewers, etc.; a stench trap. Air trunk a pipe or shaft for conducting foul or heated air from a room. Air valve a valve to regulate the admission or egress of air; esp. a valve which opens inwardly in a steam boiler and allows air to enter. Air way a passage for a current of air; as the air way of an air pump; an air way in a mine. In the air. Prevalent without traceable origin or authority, as rumors. Not in a fixed or stable position; unsettled. Mil Unsupported and liable to be turned or taken in flank; as, the army had its wing in the air . on the air currently transmitting; live; -- used of radio and television broadcasts, to indicate that the images and sounds being picked up by cameras and microphones are being broadcast at the present moment. In call-in programs where individuals outside a radio or television studio have telephoned into the station, when their voice is being directly broadcast, the host of the program commonly states “You're on the air.” as a warning that the conversation is not private. To take air to be divulged; to be made public. To take the air to go abroad; to walk or ride out.
entry.ety: OE. air eir, F. air, L. aër, fr. Gr. 'ah`r, air, mist, for 'aϝhr, fr. root 'aϝ to blow, breathe, probably akin to E. wind. In sense 10 the French has taking a meaning fr. It. aria atmosphere, air, fr. the same Latin word; and in senses 11, 12, 13 the French meaning is either fr. L. aria, or due to confusion with F. aire, in an older sense of origin, descent. Cf. Aëry Debonair Malaria Wind

sn.def: The fluid which we breathe, and which surrounds the earth; the atmosphere. It is invisible, inodorous, insipid, transparent, compressible, elastic, and ponderable.

entry.sn: Symbolically: Something unsubstantial, light, or volatile. Charm ache withair. He was still all air and fire. Air and fire being the finer and quicker elements as opposed to earth and water Macaulay.

sn.def: A particular state of the atmosphere, as respects heat, cold, moisture, etc., or as affecting the sensations; as, a smoky air, a damp air, the morning air, etc.
Any aëriform body; a gas; as, oxygen was formerly called vital air .
Air in motion; a light breeze; a gentle wind.
sn.q: Let vernal airs through trembling osiers play.

sn.def: Odoriferous or contaminated air.
That which surrounds and influences.
sn.q: The keen, the wholesome air of poverty.

sn.def: Utterance abroad; publicity; vent.
sn.q: You gave it air before me.

sn.def: Intelligence; information.

sd.def: A musical idea, or motive, rhythmically developed in consecutive single tones, so as to form a symmetrical and balanced whole, which may be sung by a single voice to the stanzas of a hymn or song, or even to plain prose, or played upon an instrument; a melody; a tune; an aria.
In harmonized chorals, psalmody, part songs, etc., the part which bears the tune or melody -- in modern harmony usually the upper part -- is sometimes called the air.

sn.def: The peculiar look, appearance, and bearing of a person; mien; demeanor; as, the air of a youth; a heavy air; a lofty air.
sn.q: His veryair.

sn.def: Peculiar appearance; apparent character; semblance; manner; style.
sn.q: It was communicated with the air of a secret.

sn.def: An artificial or affected manner; show of pride or vanity; haughtiness; as, it is said of a person, he puts on airs .

sd.def: The representation or reproduction of the effect of the atmospheric medium through which every object in nature is viewed.
Carriage; attitude; action; movement; as, the head of that portrait has a good air .

sn.def: The artificial motion or carriage of a horse.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aired ârd; p. pr. & vb. n. Airing
entry.ety: See Air n., and cf. Aërate

sn.def: To expose to the air for the purpose of cooling, refreshing, or purifying; to ventilate; as, to air a room.
sn.q: It were good wisdom . . . that the jail were aired.
Were you but riding forth to air yourself.

sn.def: To expose for the sake of public notice; to display ostentatiously; as, to air one's opinion.
sn.q: Airing a snowy hand and signet gem.

sn.def: To expose to heat, for the purpose of expelling dampness, or of warming; as, to air linen; to air liquors.

entry.def: A throw at the basket that completely misses, not even hitting the rim. Compare swoosh and nothing but net.

entries.entry: air"bed` air" bed` . A sack or mattress inflated with air, and used as a bed. air mattress, air-bed

air" blad`der. Anat An air sac, sometimes double or variously lobed, in the visceral cavity of many fishes. It originates in the same way as the lungs of air-breathing vertebrates, and in the adult may retain a tubular connection with the pharynx or esophagus.
A sac or bladder full of air in an animal or plant; also an air hole in a casting.

sn.def: conveyed by or through air, as dust or pollen; as, a clean room is needed to avoid airborne contaminants.
in flight; flying; -- said of an airplane.
carried directly to the site of battle by aircraft; -- said of combat troops, as, an airborne division.

entries.entry: Air" brake`. Mach A railway brake powered by compressed air. airbrake.

a vehicular brake that operates by compressed air; especially for heavy vehicles. Same as air brake.
an atomizer to spray by means of compressed air.

entries.entry: airbrush air brush . A kind of atomizer for applying liquid coloring matter, such as paint, in a spray by compressed air.

sn.def: to alter or remove by use of an airbrush.

entries.entry:
Air" cell`. Bot A cavity in the cellular tissue of plants, containing air only.
Anat A receptacle of air in various parts of the system; as, a cell or minute cavity in the walls of the air tubes of the lungs; the air sac of birds; a dilatation of the air vessels in insects.

Air" cham`ber. A chamber or cavity filled with air, in an animal or plant.
A cavity containing air to act as a spring for equalizing the flow of a liquid in a pump or other hydraulic machine.
Air" cock`. A faucet to allow escape of air.

Air cooling
Air"-cooled` a. . In devices generating heat, such as gasoline-engine motor vehicles, the cooling of the device by increasing its radiating surface by means of ribs or radiators, and placing it so that it is exposed to a current of air. Cf. Water cooling.

entry.def: Any vehicle, such as an airplane, helicopter, balloon, etc., for floating in, or flying through, the air.

entries.entry: Air gap. Physics An air-filled gap in a magnetic or electric circuit; specif., in a dynamo or motor, the space between the field-magnet poles and the armature; clearance.

air"gun` air" gun`
gŭn`. A kind of gun in which the elastic force of condensed air is used to discharge the ball. The air is powerfully compressed into a reservoir attached to the gun, by a condensing pump, and is controlled by a valve actuated by the trigger. The common BB gun is a type of air gun.
Air hammer. a hammer powered by compressed air so as to be able to provide powerful repeated strokes; a pneumatic hammer.

entries.entry:
Air" hole` âr" hōl`. A hole to admit or discharge air; specifically, a spot in the ice not frozen over.

entry.usage: Alarm Fright Terror Consternation. These words express different degrees of fear at the approach of danger. Fright is fear suddenly excited, producing confusion of the senses, and hence it is unreflecting. Alarm is the hurried agitation of feeling which springs from a sense of immediate and extreme exposure. Terror is agitating and excessive fear, which usually benumbs the faculties. Consternation is overwhelming fear, and carries a notion of powerlessness and amazement. Alarm agitates the feelings; terror disorders the understanding and affects the will; fright seizes on and confuses the sense; consternation takes possession of the soul, and subdues its faculties. See Apprehension.

entries.entry:
Al*bi"no ☞ The term was originally applied by the Portuguese to negroes met with on the coast of Africa, who were mottled with white spots. ?; 277 n.; pl.Albinos. Sp. or Pg. albino, orig. whitish, fr. albo white, L. albus
A person, whether negro, Indian, or white, in whom by some defect of organization the substance which gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes is deficient or in a morbid state. An albino has a skin of a milky hue, with hair of the same color, and eyes with deep red pupil and pink or blue iris. The term is also used of the lower animals, as white mice, elephants, etc.; and of plants in a whitish condition from the absence of chlorophyll.

entry.def: The state or condition of being an albino; albinism.
Affected with albinism.

A blank book, in which to insert autographs, sketches, memorial writing of friends, photographs, etc.
