entry.def: A fabric made from the wool of the Angora goat.

entries.entry: An*go"la pea`. Bot A tropical plant (Cajanus indicus) and its edible seed, a kind of pulse; -- so called from Angola in Western Africa. Called also pigeon pea and Congo pea.

sn.def: a member of the Bantu tribes resident in Angola.

entry.def: Great anxiety accompanied by painful constriction at the upper part of the belly, often with palpitation and oppression.

cs.cd: a variety of the domestic cat with very long and silky hair, generally of the brownish white color. Called also Angola cat. See Cat.
a variety of the domestic goat, reared for its long silky hair, which is highly prized for manufacture.

entry.def: A city of Asia Minor (or Anatolia) which has given its name to a goat, a cat, etc.

entries.entry:
An`gos*tu"ra An`gos*tu"ra bark"
äṉ`gŏs*t�"rȧ bärk`. From Angostura, in Venezuela A bitter aromatic bark, obtained from a South American tree of the rue family (Galipea cuspariaorGalipea officinalis). It is used used as a tonic, in medicines, liqueurs and bitters.

An`gou`mois" moth" An`gou`mois" moth" ?; 115. So named from Angoumois in France Zoöl A small moth (Gelechia cerealella) which is very destructive to wheat and other grain. The larva eats out the interior of the grain, leaving only the shell.

sn.def: a genus of tropical Old World epiphytic orchids with showy flowers sometimes grotesque.
any of various spectacular orchids of the genus Angraecum having 2-ranked dark green leathery leaves and usually nocturnally scented white or ivory flowers.

entry.def: In an angry manner; under the influence of anger.
The quality of being angry, or of being inclined to anger.
entry.q: Such an angriness of humor that we take fire at everything.

sn.def: Troublesome; vexatious; rigorous.
sn.q: God had provided a severe and angry education to chastise the forwardness of a young spirit.

sn.def: Inflamed and painful, as a sore.
Touched with anger; under the emotion of anger; feeling resentment; enraged; -- followed generally by with before a person, and at before a thing.
sn.q: Be not grieved, nor angry with yourselves.
Wherefore should God be angry at thy voice?

sn.def: Showing anger; proceeding from anger; acting as if moved by anger; wearing the marks of anger; as, angry words or tones; an angry sky; angry waves.
sn.q: Anangrycountenance.

sn.def: Red.
sn.q: Sweet rose, whose hue, angry and brave.

sn.def: Sharp; keen; stimulated.
sn.q: I never ate with angrier appetite.
sn.syn: Passionate; resentful; irritated; irascible; indignant; provoked; enraged; incensed; exasperated; irate; hot; raging; furious; wrathful; wroth; choleric; inflamed; infuriated.

entry.def: a family comprising the alligator lizards.
Snake-shaped.

sn.def: a British colony, comprising an island in the Caribbean Sea, east of Puerto Rico, with a total area of 91 sq km. Its population in 1996 was estimated at 10,424. The official language is English.
the type genus of the Anguillidae: eels.
a native or inhabitant of the island of Anguilla in the West Indies.
of or pertaining to Anguilla; as, Anguillan sea food specialties.
of, pertaining to, or characteristic of Anguillans or Anguilla; as, The Anguillan population of the islands.

entry.def: a natural family of eels that live in fresh water as adults but return to the sea to spawn.

entry.note: ☞ The “Anguillæformes” of Cuvier are fishes related to thee eel.
entry.ety: L. anguilla eel (dim. of anguis snake) + -form
entry.def: Eel-shaped.

sn.def: an order of elongate fishes with pelvic fins and girdle absent or reduced.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a snake or serpent.
entry.q: Theanguineor snakelike reptiles.

entry.def: Anguineous.
Snakelike.

entry.note: Rarely used in the plural:Ye miserable people, you must go to God in anguishes, and make your prayer to him. Latimer.
entry.ety: OE. anguishe anguise angoise, F. angoisse, fr. L. angustia narrowness, difficulty, distress, fr. angustus narrow, difficult, fr. angere to press together. See Anger
entry.def: Extreme pain, either of body or mind; excruciating distress.
entry.q: But they hearkened not unto Moses for anguish of spirit, and for cruel bondage.
Anguish as of her that bringeth forth her first child.
entry.syn: Agony; pang; torture; torment. See Agony.

entry.ety: Cf. F. angoisser, fr. L. angustiare
entry.def: To distress with extreme pain or grief.
suffering anguish; experiencing extreme pain, distress, or anxiety

entry.cs: Angular aperture Angular distance . See Aperture Distance. Angular motion the motion of a body about a fixed point or fixed axis, as of a planet or pendulum. It is equal to the angle passed over at the point or axis by a line drawn to the body. Angular point the point at which the sides of the angle meet; the vertex. Angular velocity the ratio of anuglar motion to the time employed in describing.
entry.ety: L. angularis, fr. angulus angle, corner. See Angle

sn.def: Relating to an angle or to angles; having an angle or angles; forming an angle or corner; sharp-cornered; pointed; as, an angular figure.
Measured by an angle; as, angular distance.
Fig.: Lean; lank; raw-boned; ungraceful; sharp and stiff in character; as, remarkably angular in his habits and appearance; an angular female.

entry.def: A bone in the base of the lower jaw of many birds, reptiles, and fishes.
The quality or state of being angular; angularness.
In an angular manner; with of at angles or corners.
The quality of being angular.

entry.ety: L. angulatus, p. p. of angulare to make angular
entry.def: Having angles or corners; angled; as, angulate leaves.
To make angular.
A making angular; angular formation.

entries.entry: An"gu*lo-den"tate a.. L. angulus angle + dens dentis, tooth Bot Angularly toothed, as certain leaves.

entry.def: An instrument for measuring external angles.
Angulous.
A state of being angulous or angular.
Angular; having corners; hooked.
entry.q: Held together by hooks and angulous involutions.

entry.def: Narrow; strait.

entry.ety: L. angustatus, p. p. of angustare to make narrow
entry.def: Narrowed.
The act of making narrow; a straitening or contacting.

entry.ety: L. angustus narrow + clavus a nail, a stripe
entry.def: A narrow stripe of purple worn by the equites on each side of the tunic as a sign of rank.

entry.ety: L. angustus narrow (see Anguish) + folium leaf
entry.def: Having narrow leaves.

entries.entry: An`gus*tu"ra bark`. See Angostura bark.

entry.def: A small lemuroid mammal (Arctocebus Calabarensis) of Africa. It has only a rudimentary tail.
To hang.

entry.cs: The anharmonic function or anharmonic ratio of four points abcd on a straight line is the quantity ac/ad):(bc/bd , where the segments are to be regarded as plus or minus, according to the order of the letters.
entry.ety: F. anharmonique, fr. Gr. 'an priv. + � harmonic
entry.def: Not harmonic.

entry.ety: L. anhelatio, fr. anhelare to pant; anperh. akin to E. on) + halare to breathe: cf. F. anhélation
entry.def: Short and rapid breathing; a panting; asthma.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. aneler anheler. See Anhelation
entry.def: To pant; to be breathlessly anxious or eager (for).
entry.q: They anhele . . . for the fruit of our convocation.

entry.def: Anhelous; panting.
Short of breath; panting.
A South American aquatic bird; the horned screamer or kamichi (Palamedea cornuta). See Kamichi.
a family of aquatic birds of South America. They are called screamers due to their harsh trumpeting call.
An aquatic bird of the southern United States (Platus anhinga); the darter, or snakebird.

entry.ety: Gr. 'an priv. + "isto`s web, tissue: cf. F. anhiste
entry.def: Without definite structure; as, an anhistous membrane.
Ahungered; longing.
An oxide of a nonmetallic body or an organic radical, capable of forming an acid by uniting with the elements of water; -- so called because it may be formed from an acid by the abstraction of water.
A mineral of a white or a slightly bluish color, usually massive. It is anhydrous sulphate of lime, and differs from gypsum in not containing water (whence the name).
Destitute of water; as, anhydrous salts or acids.
A black bird of tropical America, the West Indies and Florida (Crotophaga ani), allied to the cuckoos, having a compressed, bladelike bill and remarkable for communistic nesting.
A dam or mole made in the course of a stream for the purpose of regulating the flow of a system of irrigation.
Not idiomatic.
To frustrate; to bring to naught; to annihilate.
Nigh.
In the night time; at night.
entry.q: Does he hawk anights still?

entry.ety: F. anil, Sp. anīl, or Pg. anil; all fr. Ar. an-nīl, for al-nīl the indigo plant, fr. Skr. nīla dark blue, nīlī indigo, indigo plant. Cf. Lilac
entry.def: A West Indian plant (Indigofera anil), one of the original sources of indigo; also, the indigo dye.

entry.ety: L. anilis, fr. anus an old woman
entry.def: Old-womanish; imbecile.
entry.q: Anileideas.

entry.def: Anility.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, anil; indigotic; -- applied to an acid formed by the action of nitric acid on indigo.
One of a class of compounds which may be regarded as amides in which more or less of the hydrogen has been replaced by phenyl.

An organic base belonging to the phenylamines. It may be regarded as ammonia in which one hydrogen atom has been replaced by the radical phenyl. It is a colorless, oily liquid, originally obtained from indigo by distillation, but now largely manufactured from coal tar or nitrobenzene as a base from which many brilliant dyes are made.
Made from, or of the nature of, aniline.
A disease due to inhaling the poisonous fumes present in the manufacture of aniline.
The state of being and old woman; old-womanishness; dotage.
entry.q: Marks ofanility.

entry.def: The faculty of perceiving; a percipient.

entry.ety: L. animadversio, fr. animadvertere: cf. F. animadversion. See Animadvert

sn.def: The act or power of perceiving or taking notice; direct or simple perception.
sn.q: The soul is the sole percipient which hath animadversion and sense, properly so called.

sn.def: Monition; warning.
Remarks by way of criticism and usually of censure; adverse criticism; reproof; blame.
sn.q: He dismissed their commissioners with severe and sharp animadversions.

sn.def: Judicial cognizance of an offense; chastisement; punishment.
sn.syn: Stricture; criticism; censure; reproof; blame; comment.

entry.def: Having the power of perceiving; percipient.
entry.q: I do not mean there is a certain number of ideas glaring and shining to the animadversive faculty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Animadverted; p. pr. & vb. n. Animadverting
entry.ety: L. animadvertere; animus mind + advertere to turn to; ad to + vertere to turn

sn.def: To take notice; to observe; -- commonly followed by that.
To consider or remark by way of criticism or censure; to express censure; -- with on or upon.
sn.q: I should not animadvert on him . . . if he had not used extreme severity in his judgment of the incomparable Shakespeare.

sn.def: To take cognizance judicially; to inflict punishment.

entry.def: One who animadverts; a censurer; also Obs, a chastiser.

entry.ety: L., fr. anima breath, soul: cf. F. animal. See Animate

sn.def: An organized living being endowed with sensation and the power of voluntary motion, and also characterized by taking its food into an internal cavity or stomach for digestion; by giving carbonic acid to the air and taking oxygen in the process of respiration; and by increasing in motive power or active aggressive force with progress to maturity.
One of the lower animals; a brute or beast, as distinguished from man; as, men and animals .

entry.cs: Animal magnetism. See Magnetism and Mesmerism. Animal electricity the electricity developed in some animals, as the electric eel, torpedo, etc. Animal flower Zoöl a name given to certain marine animals resembling a flower, as any species of actinia or sea anemone, and other Anthozoa, hydroids, starfishes, etc. Animal heat Physiol the heat generated in the body of a living animal, by means of which the animal is kept at nearly a uniform temperature. Animal spirits. See under Spirit. Animal kingdom the whole class of beings endowed with animal life. It embraces several subkingdoms, and under these there are Classes, Orders, Families, Genera, Species, and sometimes intermediate groupings, all in regular subordination, but variously arranged by different writers.
entry.note:
The following are the grand divisions, or subkingdoms, and the principal classes under them, generally recognized at the present time:
Vertebrata , including Mammalia or Mammals Aves or Birds Reptilia Amphibia Pisces or Fishes Marsipobranchiata Craniota); and Leptocardia Acrania). Tunicata , including the Thaliacea, and Ascidioidea or Ascidians. Articulata or Annulosa , including Insecta Myriapoda Malacapoda Arachnida Pycnogonida Merostomata Crustacea Arthropoda); and Annelida Gehyrea Anarthropoda).
Helminthes or Vermes , including Rotifera Chætognatha Nematoidea Acanthocephala Nemertina Turbellaria Trematoda Cestoidea Mesozea.
Molluscoidea , including Brachiopoda and Bryozoa. Mollusca , including Cephalopoda Gastropoda Pteropoda Scaphopoda Lamellibranchiata or Acephala. Echinodermata , including Holothurioidea Echinoidea Asterioidea Ophiuroidea, and Crinoidea. Cœlenterata , including Anthozoa or Polyps Ctenophora, and Hydrozoa or Acalephs. Spongiozoa or Porifera , including the sponges.
Protozoa , including Infusoria and Rhizopoda. For definitions, see these names in the Vocabulary.

sn.def: Of or relating to animals; as, animal functions.
Pertaining to the merely sentient part of a creature, as distinguished from the intellectual, rational, or spiritual part; as, the animal passions or appetites.
Consisting of the flesh of animals; as, animal food.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, animalcules.
entry.q: Animalcularlife.

entry.note: ☞ Many of the so-called animalcules have been shown to be plants, having locomotive powers something like those of animals. Among these are Volvox, the Desmidiacæ, and the siliceous Diatomaceæ.
entry.cs: Spermatic animalcules. See Spermatozoa.
entry.ety: As if fr. a L. animalculum, dim. of animal

sn.def: A small animal, as a fly, spider, etc.
An animal, invisible, or nearly so, to the naked eye. See Infusoria.
The theory which seeks to explain certain physiological and pathological phenomena by means of animalcules.
The theory that the spermatozoön and not the ovum contains the whole of the embryo; spermatism; -- opposed to ovism.
One versed in the knowledge of animalcules.
A believer in the theory of animalculism.

entries.entry:
An`i*mal"cu*lum An`i*mal"cu*lum ☞ Animalculæ, as if from a Latin singular animalcula, is a barbarism. n.; pl.Animalcula. NL. See Animalcule
An animalcule.

sn.def: an act that makes people cruel or lacking normal human qualities.

entry.def: Like an animal.
The state, activity, or enjoyment of animals; mere animal life without intellectual or moral qualities or objectives; preoccupation with sensual, physical, or carnal pleasures.

sn.def: of or pertaining to animalism.

entry.def: Animal existence or nature.

sn.def: The act of animalizing; the giving of animal life, or endowing with animal properties.
Conversion into animal matter by the process of assimilation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Animalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Animalizing

sn.def: To endow with the properties of an animal; to represent in animal form.
To convert into animal matter by the processes of assimilation.
To render animal or sentient; to reduce to the state of a lower animal; to sensualize.
sn.q: The unconscious irony of the Epicurean poet on the animalizing tendency of his own philosophy.

entry.def: Physically.
Animality.
Pertaining to mind or spirit; spiritual.
Psychology.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Animated; p. pr. & vb. n. Animating
entry.ety: L. animatus, p. p. of animare, fr. anima breath, soul; akin to animus soul, mind, Gr. � wind, Skr. an to breathe, live, Goth. us-anan to expire (us- out), Icel. önd breath, anda to breathe, OHG. ando anger. Cf. Animal

sn.def: To give natural life to; to make alive; to quicken; as, the soul animates the body.
To give powers to, or to heighten the powers or effect of; as, to animate a lyre.
To give spirit or vigor to; to stimulate or incite; to inspirit; to rouse; to enliven.
sn.q: The more to animate the people, he stood on high . . . and cried unto them with a loud voice.
sn.syn: To enliven; inspirit; stimulate; exhilarate; inspire; instigate; rouse; urge; cheer; prompt; incite; quicken; gladden.

entry.def: Endowed with life; alive; living; animated; lively.
entry.q: The admirable structure of animate bodies.

entry.def: Endowed with life; full of life or spirit; indicating animation; lively; vigorous.
entry.q: Animatedsounds.
Animatedbust.
Animateddescriptions.

entry.def: With animation.
One who animates.
Causing animation; life-giving; inspiriting; rousing.
entry.q: Animatingcries.

cs.cd: temporary suspension of the vital functions, as in persons nearly drowned.

sn.def: The act of animating, or giving life or spirit; the state of being animate or alive.
sn.q: The animation of the same soul quickening the whole frame.
Perhaps an inanimate thing supplies me, while I am speaking, with whatever I possess of animation.

sn.def: The state of being lively, brisk, or full of spirit and vigor; vivacity; spiritedness; as, he recited the story with great animation .
sn.syn: Liveliness; vivacity; spirit; buoyancy; airiness; sprightliness; promptitude; enthusiasm; ardor; earnestness; energy. See Liveliness.

entry.def: Having the power of giving life or spirit.
One who, or that which, animates; an animater.
Of a different tincture from the animal itself; -- said of the eyes of a rapacious animal.

entry.ety: F. animé animated (from the insects that are entrapped in it); or native name
entry.def: A resin exuding from a tropical American tree (Hymenæa courbaril), and much used by varnish makers.

entry.ety: Cf. F. animisme, fr. L. anima soul. See Animate

sn.def: The doctrine, taught by Stahl, that the soul is the proper principle of life and development in the body.

The belief that inanimate objects and the phenomena of nature are endowed with personal life or a living soul; also, in an extended sense, the belief in the existence of soul or spirit apart from matter.

entry.def: One who maintains the doctrine of animism.
Of or pertaining to animism.

entry.ety: L. animosus, fr. animus soul, spirit, courage
entry.def: Full of spirit; hot; vehement; resolute.
Vehemence of temper.

entries.entry:
An`i*mos"i*ty n.; pl.Animosities. F. animosité, fr. L. animositas. See Animose Animate v. t.
Mere spiritedness or courage. Obs Such as give some proof of animosity, audacity, and execution, those she [the crocodile] loveth.
Violent hatred leading to active opposition; active enmity; energetic dislike. Enmity; hatred; opposition.Animosity Enmity. Enmity be dormant or concealed; animosity is active enmity, inflamed by collision and mutual injury between opposing parties. The animosities which were continually springing up among the clans in Scotland kept that kingdom in a state of turmoil and bloodshed for successive ages. The animosities which have been engendered among Christian sects have always been the reproach of the church. Such [writings] as naturally conduce to inflame hatreds and make enmities irreconcilable. These] factions . . . never suspended their animosities till they ruined that unhappy government.

An"i*mus
nimus furandi L Law intention of stealing.
n.; pl.Animi. L., mind Animating spirit; intention; temper.

entry.ety: Gr. �, neut. �, p. pr. of � to go up; � up + � to go
entry.def: An electro-negative atom or group of atoms, or the element which, in electro-chemical decompositions, is evolved at the anode; -- opposed to cation.

sn.def: having the character of an anion; negatively charged; containing anions; -- of atoms, molecules, and groups of atoms. Contrasted with cationic.
of or pertaining to anions. Contrasted with cationic
a class of synthetic detergents in which the molecules do not ionize in aqueous solutions.

entry.ety: OE. anys, F. anis, L. anisum anethum, fr. Gr. 'a`nison 'a`nhqon

sn.def: An umbelliferous plant (Pimpinella anisum) growing naturally in Egypt, and cultivated in Spain, Malta, etc., for its carminative and aromatic seeds.
The fruit or seeds of this plant.

entry.def: The seed of the anise; also, a cordial prepared from it.
entry.q: Oil ofaniseed.

sn.def: a visual defect in which the shape and size of an ocular image differ in the two eyes.
of or pertaining to aniseikonia.

entry.def: A French cordial or liqueur flavored with anise seeds.
Of or derived from anise; as, anisic acid; anisic alcohol.
Inequality of the pupils of the eye.

entry.ety: NL. anisodactyla, fr. Gr. 'a`nisos unequal ('an priv. + 'i`sos equal) + da`ktylos finger
entry.def: A group of herbivorous mammals characterized by having the hoofs in a single series around the foot, as the elephant, rhinoceros, etc.
A group of perching birds which are anisodactylous.
Characterized by unequal toes, three turned forward and one backward, as in most passerine birds.

sn.def: reproduction by the union or fusion of two differing gametes (especially differing in size).

entry.def: Methyl phenyl ether, C6H5.O.CH3, got by distilling anisic acid or by the action of methide on potassium phenolate.
Not isomeric; not made of the same components in the same proportions.
Having the number of floral organs unequal, as four petals and six stamens.
Not isometric; having unsymmetrical parts; -- said of crystals with three unequal axes.
Unequal refractive power in the two eyes.
Having unequal petals.
Having unequal leaves.
A primary division of gastropods, including those having spiral shells. The two sides of the body are unequally developed.
A division of Crustacea, which, in some its characteristics, is intermediate between Amphipoda and Isopoda.
A sexual spore in which the sexes differ in size; -- opposed to isospore.

entry.ety: Gr. � unequal + � warp, thread; � to stand
entry.def: Having unequal stamens; having stamens different in number from the petals.
Of unequal strength.

entry.ety: Gr. � unequal + � a turning, � to turn
entry.def: Not isotropic; having different properties in different directions; thus, crystals of the isometric system are optically isotropic, but all other crystals are anisotropic.
Anisotropic.
The univalent radical, CH3.O.C6H4-, of which anisol is the hydride.
The univalent radical CH3.O.C6H4.CH2-; as, anisyl alcohol.
The univalent radical CH3.O.C6H4.CO-, of anisic acid.

entries.entry: A*ni"to A*ni"to n.; pl. -tos # . Sp In Guam and the Philippines, an idol, fetich, or spirit.

entry.ety: D. anker: cf. LL. anceria ancheria
entry.def: A liquid measure in various countries of Europe. The Dutch anker, formerly also used in England, contained about 10 of the old wine gallons, or 81/2 imperial gallons.

entry.ety: So called from Prof. Anker of Austria: cf. F. ankérite, G. ankerit
entry.def: A mineral closely related to dolomite, but containing iron.

sn.def: A tau cross with a loop at the top, used as an attribute or sacred emblem, symbolizing generation or enduring life. Called also crux ansata.
an amulet or piece of jewelry shaped like an ankh{1}.

cs.cd: the bone of the ankle; the astragalus.

entry.ety: OE. ancle anclow, AS. ancleow; akin to Icel. ökkla ökli, Dan. and Sw. ankel, D. enklaauw enkel, G. enkel, and perh. OHG. encha ancha thigh, shin: cf. Skr. anga limb, anguri finger. Cf. Haunch
entry.def: The joint which connects the foot with the leg; the tarsus.
Having ankles; -- used in composition; as, well-ankled .

sn.def: An ornament or a fetter for the ankle; an ankle ring.
see anklets.
socks that reach just above the ankle.

entry.def: An elephant goad with a sharp spike and hook, resembling a short-handled boat hook.
Same as Anchylose.
Same as Anchylosis.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Ankylostoma, var. of Agchylostoma, generic name of one genus of the parasitic nematodes
entry.def: A disease due to the presence of the parasites Agchylostoma duodenale Uncinariasubgenus Necator americana, or allied nematodes, in the small intestine. When present in large numbers they produce a severe anæmia by sucking the blood from the intestinal walls. Called also miner's anæmia tunnel disease brickmaker's anæmia Egyptian chlorosis.
A broad dagger formerly worn at the girdle.

cs.cd: initially; when initial; -- used of sounds.

entry.def: An initial sound, as of a word or syllable.

entry.ety: LL. annata income of a year, also, of half a year, fr. L. annus year: cf. F. annate annats
entry.def: A half years's stipend, over and above what is owing for the incumbency, due to a minister's heirs after his decease.
An East Indian money of account, the sixteenth of a rupee, or about 2� cents.
See Annals.
A writer of annals.
entry.q: The monks . . . were the only annalists in those ages.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or after the manner of, an annalist; as, the dry annalistic style .
entry.q: A stiff annalisticmethod.

entry.def: To record in annals.

entry.ety: L. annalissc. liber), and more frequently in the pl. annalessc. libri), chronicles, fr. annus year. Cf. Annual

sn.def: A relation of events in chronological order, each event being recorded under the year in which it happened.
sn.q: Annalsthe revolution.
Theannalsof our religion.

sn.def: Historical records; chronicles; history.
sn.q: The short and simple annals of the poor.
It was one of the most critical periods in our annals.

sn.def: The record of a single event or item.
sn.q: In deathlessannal.

sn.def: A periodic publication, containing records of discoveries, transactions of societies, etc.; as “Annals of Science.”
wife of Siva and a benevolent aspect of Devi: goddess of plenty.
a mountain in Nepal, 26,504 feet high.

entry.def: The first year's profits of a spiritual preferment, anciently paid by the clergy to the pope; first fruits. In England, they now form a fund for the augmentation of poor livings.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Annealed; p. pr. & vb. n. Annealing
entry.ety: OE. anelen to heat, burn, AS. an�lan; an on + �lan to burn; also OE. anelen to enamel, prob. influenced by OF. neeler nieler, to put a black enamel on gold or silver, F. nieller, fr. LL. nigellare to blacken, fr. L. nigellus blackish, dim. of niger black. Cf. Niello Negro

sn.def: To subject to great heat, and then cool slowly, as glass, cast iron, steel, or other metal, for the purpose of rendering it less brittle; to temper; to toughen.
To heat, as glass, tiles, or earthenware, in order to fix the colors laid on them.

entry.def: One who, or that which, anneals.

sn.def: The process used to render glass, iron, etc., less brittle, performed by allowing them to cool very gradually from a high heat.
The burning of metallic colors into glass, earthenware, etc.

entry.ety: L. annectere to tie or bind to. See Annex
entry.def: Connecting; annexing.

entry.ety: F. annélide, fr. anneler to arrange in rings, OF. anel a ring, fr. L. anellus a ring, dim. of annulus a ring
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Annelida.

A division of the Articulata, having the body formed of numerous rings or annular segments, and without jointed legs. The principal subdivisions are the Chætopoda, including the Oligochæta or earthworms and Polychæta or marine worms; and the Hirudinea or leeches. See Chætopoda.
Of the nature of an annelid.
See Annelida.
An animal resembling an annelid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Annexed; p. pr. & vb. n. Annexing
entry.ety: F. annexer, fr. L. annexus, p. p. of annectere to tie or bind to; ad + nectere to tie, to fasten together, akin to Skr. nah to bind

sn.def: To join or attach; usually to subjoin; to affix; to append; -- followed by to.
sn.q: Heannexeda codicil to a will.

sn.def: To join or add, as a smaller thing to a greater.
sn.q: He annexed a province to his kingdom.

sn.def: To attach or connect, as a consequence, condition, etc.; as, to annex a penalty to a prohibition, or punishment to guilt.
sn.syn: To add; append; affix; unite; coalesce. See Add.

entry.def: To join; to be united.

entry.ety: F. annexe, L. annexus, neut. annexum, p. p. of annectere
entry.def: Something annexed or appended; as, an additional stipulation to a writing, a subsidiary building to a main building; a wing.

entry.ety: Cf. F. annexation. See Annex v. t.

sn.def: The act of annexing; process of attaching, adding, or appending; the act of connecting; union; as, the annexation of Texas to the United States, or of chattels to the freehold.

sd.def: The union of property with a freehold so as to become a fixture. Bouvier. Scots Law The appropriation of lands or rents to the crown.

entry.def: One who favors annexation.
One who annexes.

entry.ety: L. annexio a tying to, connection: cf. F. annexion
entry.def: Annexation.
An annexationist.
The act of annexing, or the thing annexed; appendage.
Capable of being annihilated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Annihilated; p. pr. & vb. n. Annihilating
entry.ety: L. annihilare; ad + nihilum nihil, nothing, ne hilum filum) not a thread, nothing at all. Cf. File, a row

sn.def: To reduce to nothing or nonexistence; to destroy the existence of; to cause to cease to be.
sn.q: It impossible for any body to be utterly annihilated.

sn.def: To destroy the form or peculiar distinctive properties of, so that the specific thing no longer exists; as, to annihilate a forest by cutting down the trees.
sn.q: Toannihilatethe army.

sn.def: To destroy or eradicate, as a property or attribute of a thing; to make of no effect; to destroy the force, etc., of; as, to annihilate an argument, law, rights, goodness.

entry.def: Annihilated.

sn.def: destroyed completely.

entry.def: criticising vehemently and effectively; making light of; as, afire with annihilating invective.

sn.def: The act of reducing to nothing, or nonexistence; or the act of destroying the form or combination of parts under which a thing exists, so that the name can no longer be applied to it; as, the annihilation of a corporation.
The state of being annihilated.

entry.def: One who believes that eternal punishment consists in annihilation or extinction of being; a destructionist.
Serving to annihilate; destructive.
One who, or that which, annihilates; as, a fire annihilator .
Annihilative.
Annually.

entry.cs: Anniversary day R. C. Ch. See Anniversary n., 2. Anniversary week that week in the year in which the annual meetings of religious and benevolent societies are held in Boston and New York. Eastern U. S
entry.ety: L. anniversarius; annus year + vertere versum, to turn: cf. F. anniversaire
entry.def: Returning with the year, at a stated time; annual; yearly; as, an anniversary feast.

entries.entry:
An`ni*ver"sa*ry n.; pl. Anniversaries. Cf. F. anniversaire
The annual return of the day on which any notable event took place, or is wont to be celebrated; as, the anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.
R. C. Ch The day on which Mass is said yearly for the soul of a deceased person; the commemoration of some sacred event, as the dedication of a church or the consecration of a pope.
The celebration which takes place on an anniversary day.

entry.ety: L. anni versus the turning of a year
entry.def: Anniversary.

entry.ety: L. ad to + nodus a knot
entry.def: Curved somewhat in the form of the letter S.

entries.entry: An"no Dom"i*ni An"no Dom"i*ni. L., in the year of [our] Lord [Jesus Christ]; usually abbrev. a. d. In the year of the Christian era; as, a. d. 1887.

entry.def: To name.

sn.def: Paronomasia; punning.
Alliteration.
a family of chiefly tropical trees or shrubs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Annotated; p. pr. & vb. n. Annotating
entry.ety: L. annotatus; p. p. of annotare to annotate; ad + notare to mark, nota mark. See Note n.
entry.def: To explain or criticize by notes; as, to annotate the works of Bacon.
To make notes or comments; -- with on or upon.

sn.def: the act of adding notes.

entry.def: A note, added by way of comment, or explanation; -- usually in the plural; as, annotations on ancient authors, or on a word or a passage.
An annotator.
Characterized by annotations; of the nature of annotation.
A writer of annotations; a commentator.
Pertaining to an annotator; containing annotations.
A bird one year old, or that has once molted.
A year old; in Yearly growths.

A red or yellowish-red dyeing material, prepared from the pulp surrounding the seeds of a tree (Bixa orellana) belonging to the tropical regions of America. It is used for coloring cheese, butter, etc.

entry.usage: To Publish Announce Proclaim Promulgate. We publish what we give openly to the world, either by oral communication or by means of the press; as, to publish abroad the faults of our neighbors. We announce what we declare by anticipation, or make known for the first time; as, to announce the speedy publication of a book; to announce the approach or arrival of a distinguished personage. We proclaim anything to which we give the widest publicity; as, to proclaim the news of victory. We promulgate when we proclaim more widely what has before been known by some; as, to promulgate the gospel.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Announced; p. pr. & vb. n. Announcing
entry.ety: OF. anoncier, F. annoncer, fr. L. annuntiare; ad + nuntiare to report, relate, nuntius messenger, bearer of news. See Nuncio, and cf. Annunciate

sn.def: To give public notice, or first notice of; to make known; to publish; to proclaim.
sn.q: Her [Q. Elizabeth's] arrival was announced through the country by a peal of cannon from the ramparts.

sn.def: To pronounce; to declare by judicial sentence.
sn.q: Publish laws, announce Or life or death.
sn.syn: To proclaim; publish; make known; herald; declare; promulgate.

sn.def: stated publicly; as, their announced intentions.

entry.def: The act of announcing, or giving notice; that which announces; proclamation; publication.
One who announces.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Annoyed ăn*noid"; p. pr. & vb. n. Annoying
entry.ety: OE. anoien anuien, OF. anoier anuier, F. ennuyer, fr. OF. anoi anui enui, annoyance, vexation, F. ennui. See Annoy n.
entry.def: To disturb or irritate, especially by continued or repeated acts; to tease; to ruffle in mind; to vex; as, I was annoyed by his remarks.
entry.q: Say, what can more our tortured souls annoy Than to behold, admire, and lose our joy?

sn.def: To molest, incommode, or harm; as, to annoy an army by impeding its march, or by a cannonade.
sn.syn: To molest; vex; trouble; pester; embarrass; perplex; tease.

entry.ety: OE. anoi anui, OF. anoi anui enui, fr. L. in odio hatred (esse alicui in odio, Cic.). See Ennui Odium Noisome Noy
entry.def: A feeling of discomfort or vexation caused by what one dislikes; also, whatever causes such a feeling; as, to work annoy .
entry.q: Worse than Tantalus' is her annoy.

sn.def: The act of annoying, or the state of being annoyed; molestation; vexation; annoy.
sn.q: A deep clay, giving much annoyance to passengers.
For the further annoyance and terror of any besieged place, they would throw into it dead bodies.

sn.def: That which annoys.
sn.q: A grain, a dust, a gnat, a wandering hair, Any annoyance in that precious sense.

sn.def: aroused to impatience or anger; as, feeling annoyed by the constant teasing.
troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances.

entry.def: One who, or that which, annoys.
Annoying.
That annoys; molesting; vexatious.
Troublesome; annoying.

entry.ety: OE. annuel, F. annuel, fr. L. annualis, fr. annus year. Cf. Annals

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a year; returning every year; coming or happening once in the year; yearly.
sn.q: The annual overflowing of the river [Nile].

sn.def: Performed or accomplished in a year; reckoned by the year; as, the annual motion of the earth.
sn.q: A thousand pound a year, annual support.

sn.def: Lasting or continuing only one year or one growing season; requiring to be renewed every year; as, an annual plant; annual tickets.
A thing happening or returning yearly; esp. a literary work published once a year.
Anything, especially a plant, that lasts but one year or season; an annual plant.
sn.q: Oaths . . . in some sense almost annuals; . . . and I myself can remember about forty different sets.

sn.def: A Mass for a deceased person or for some special object, said daily for a year or on the anniversary day.

entry.def: One who writes for, or who edits, an annual.
Yearly; year by year.
Annual.
A priest employed in saying annuals, or anniversary Masses.

entry.ety: L. annuens, p. pr. of annuere; ad + nuere to nod
entry.def: Nodding; as, annuent muscles (used in nodding.
One who receives, or its entitled to receive, an annuity.

entries.entry:
An*nu"i*ty n.; pl.Annuities. LL. annuitas, fr. L. annus year: cf. F. annuité
A sum of money, payable yearly, to continue for a given number of years, for life, or forever; an annual allowance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Annulled; p. pr. & vb. n. Annulling
entry.ety: F. annuler, LL. annullare annulare, fr. L. ad to + nullus none, nullum, neut., nothing. See Null a.

sn.def: To reduce to nothing; to obliterate.
sn.q: Light, the prime work of God, to me's extinct. And all her various objects of delightAnnulled.

sn.def: To make void or of no effect; to nullify; to abolish; to do away with; -- used appropriately of laws, decrees, edicts, decisions of courts, or other established rules, permanent usages, and the like, which are made void by component authority.
sn.q: Do they mean to annul laws of inestimable value to our liberties?
sn.syn: To abolish; abrogate; repeal; cancel; reverse; rescind; revoke; nullify; destroy. See Abolish.

cs.cd: an eclipse of the sun in which the moon at the middle of the eclipse conceals the central part of the sun's disk, leaving a complete ring of light around the border.

entry.ety: L. annularis, fr. annulis ring: cf. F. annulaire

sn.def: Pertaining to, or having the form of, a ring; forming a ring; ringed; ring-shaped; as, annular fibers.
Banded or marked with circles.

entry.def: Annular condition or form; as, the annularity of a nebula.
In an annular manner.
Having the form of a ring; annular.

entry.ety: Neut. pl., fr. L. annulatus ringed
entry.def: A class of articulate animals, nearly equivalent to Annelida, including the marine annelids, earthworms, Gephyrea, Gymnotoma, leeches, etc. See Annelida.
One of the Annulata.

sn.def: Furnished with, or composed of, rings; ringed; surrounded by rings of color.
Of or pertaining to the Annulata.

entry.def: A circular or ringlike formation; a ring or belt.

sn.def: A little ring.
A small, flat fillet, encircling a column, etc., used by itself, or with other moldings. It is used, several times repeated, under the Doric capital.
A little circle borne as a charge.
A narrow circle of some distinct color on a surface or round an organ.

entry.def: That may be Annulled.
One who annuls.
The act of annulling; abolition; invalidation.
Of or pertaining to the Annuloida.
A division of the Articulata, including the annelids and allied groups; sometimes made to include also the helminths and echinoderms.
A division of the Invertebrata, nearly equivalent to the Articulata. It includes the Arthoropoda and Anarthropoda. By some zoölogists it is applied to the former only.
One of the Annulosa.

sn.def: Furnished with, or composed of, rings or ringlike segments; ringed.
Of or pertaining to the Annulosa.

entries.entry:
An"nu*lus An"nu*lus n.; pl.Annuli. L
A ring; a ringlike part or space.
Geom
A space contained between the circumferences of two circles, one within the other.
The solid formed by a circle revolving around a line which is the plane of the circle but does not cut it.
Zoöl Ring-shaped structures or markings, found in, or upon, various animals.

entry.ety: L. annumeratus, p. p. of annumerare. See Numerate
entry.def: To add on; to count in.
Addition to a former number.
That may be announced or declared; declarable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Annunciated; p. pr. & vb. n. Annunciating
entry.def: To announce.
Foretold; preannounced.

sn.def: The act of announcing; announcement; proclamation; as, the annunciation of peace.

sd.def: The announcement of the incarnation, made by the angel Gabriel to the Virgin Mary.
The festival celebrated (March 25th) by the Church of England, of Rome, etc., in memory of the angel's announcement, on that day; Lady Day.

entries.entry: An*nun`ci*a"tion lil"y. Bot The common white lily (Lilium candidum). So called because it is usually introduced by painters in pictures of the Annunciation.

entry.def: Pertaining to annunciation; announcing.

sn.def: One who announces. Specifically: An officer in the church of Constantinople, whose business it was to inform the people of the festivals to be celebrated.
An indicator (as in a hotel) which designates the room where attendance is wanted.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or containing, announcement; making known.

sn.def: the other world; land of fairies.
the other world; land of fairies.

entry.def: A small wild ox of Celebes (Anoa depressicornis), allied to the buffalo, but having long nearly straight horns.

sn.def: the family comprising the deathwatch beetles.
of or at or relating to an anode. Contrastive to cathodic.

entry.def: The positive pole of an electric battery, or more strictly the electrode by which the current enters the electrolyte on its way to the other pole; -- opposed to cathode.

sn.def: to coat a metal with an oxide coat by electrolytic action at an anode; -- used especially to coat aluminum.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � toothless; 'an priv. + �, �, a tooth
entry.def: A genus of fresh-water bivalves, having no teeth at the hinge.
a genus of thin-shelled freshwater mussels.

entry.note: ☞ “The word [in a medical sense] in chiefly applied to the different preparations of opium, belladonna, hyoscyamus, and lettuce.” Am. Cyc.
entry.ety: L. anodynus, Gr. � free from pain, stilling pain; 'an priv. + � pain: cf. F. anodin
entry.def: Serving to assuage pain; soothing.
entry.q: The anodyne draught of oblivion.

entry.def: Any medicine which allays pain, as an opiate or narcotic; anything that soothes disturbed feelings.
Anodyne.

sn.def: Unthinkable.
Not subject to conscious attention; having an indefinite, relatively passive, conscious being; characteristic of the “fringe” or “margin” of consciousness.
sn.q: Presentation considered as having an existence relatively independent of thought, may be called sentience, or anoetic consciousness. Thought and sentience are fundamentally distinct mental functions.

entry.def: To anoint with oil.

cs.cd: Christ or the Messiah; also, a Jewish or other king by “divine right.”

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Anointed; p. pr. & vb. n. Anointing
entry.ety: OF. enoint, p. p. of enoindre, fr. L. inungere; in + ungere unguere, to smear, anoint. See Ointment Unguent

sn.def: To smear or rub over with oil or an unctuous substance; also, to spread over, as oil.
sn.q: And fragrant oils the stiffened limbs anoint.
He anointed the eyes of the blind man with the clay.

sn.def: To apply oil to or to pour oil upon, etc., as a sacred rite, especially for consecration.
sn.q: Then shalt thou take the anointing oil, and pour it upon his [Aaron's] head and anoint him.
Anoint Hazael to be king over Syria.

entry.def: Anointed.
One who anoints.
The act of anointing, or state of being anointed; also, an ointment.

sn.def: A small arboreal tropical American insectivorous lizard (Anolis carolinensis) with the ability to change skin color.

entry.ety: In the Antilles, anoli anoalli, a lizard
entry.def: A genus of lizards which belong to the family Iguanidæ. They take the place in the New World of the chameleons in the Old, and in America are often called chameleons.
Anything anomalous.

entry.ety: L. anomalus irregular + pes pedis, foot
entry.def: Having anomalous feet.
One of a group of perching birds, having the middle toe more or less united to the outer and inner ones.
An anomaly; a deviation from rule.

entry.cs:
Anomalistic month. See under Month. Anomalistic revolution the period in which a planet or satellite goes through the complete cycles of its changes of anomaly, or from any point in its elliptic orbit to the same again.
Anomalistic, or Periodical year . See under Year.

sn.def: Irregular; departing from common or established rules.
Pertaining to the anomaly, or angular distance of a planet from its perihelion.

entry.def: With irregularity.

entry.ety: L. anomalus irregular + flos floris, flower
entry.def: Having anomalous flowers.

sn.def: a natural family comprising the flashlightfishes.

entry.def: a fish having a luminous organ beneath eye; it inhabits warm waters of the West Pacific and Puerto Rico. It is called also flashlight fish.

sn.def: the smallest moa (Anomalopteryx oweni); it is a slender moa about the size of a large turkey.

entry.ety: L. anomalus, Gr. � uneven, irregular; 'an priv. + � even, � same. See Same, and cf. Abnormal
entry.def: Deviating from a general rule, method, or analogy; abnormal; irregular; as, an anomalous proceeding.
In an anomalous manner.
Quality of being anomalous.

entries.entry:
A*nom"a*ly n.; pl.Anomalies. L. anomalia, Gr. �. See Anomalous
Deviation from the common rule; an irregularity; anything anomalous. We are enabled to unite into a consistent whole the various anomalies and contending principles that are found in the minds and affairs of men. As Professor Owen has remarked, there is no greater anomaly in nature than a bird that can not fly.
Astron
The angular distance of a planet from its perihelion, as seen from the sun. This is the true anomaly. The eccentric anomaly is a corresponding angle at the center of the elliptic orbit of the planet. The mean anomaly is what the anomaly would be if the planet's angular motion were uniform.
The angle measuring apparent irregularities in the motion of a planet.
Nat. Hist Any deviation from the essential characteristics of a specific type.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � irregular; 'a priv. + no'mos law
entry.def: A genus of bivalve shells, allied to the oyster, so called from their unequal valves, of which the lower is perforated for attachment.
Having leaves irregularly placed.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � lawless + o'yra` tail
entry.def: A group of decapod Crustacea, of which the hermit crab in an example.
Irregular in the character of the tail or abdomen; as, the anomural crustaceans.
One of the Anomura.
Disregard or violation of law.

cs.cd: at once; right off.
now and then; frequently; often.

entry.ety: OE. anoon anon anan, lit., in one (moment), fr. AS. on in + ān one. See On and One

sn.def: Straightway; at once.
sn.q: The same is he that heareth the word, and anon with joy receiveth it.

sn.def: Soon; in a little while.
sn.q: As it shall better appear anon.

sn.def: At another time; then; again.
sn.q: Sometimes he trots, . . . anon he rears upright.
A pouncet box, which ever and anon He gave his nose.

entry.def: A genus of tropical or subtropical plants of the natural order Anonaceæ, including the soursop.
Pertaining to the order of plants including the soursop, custard apple, etc.

sn.def: One who is anonymous; also sometimes used for “pseudonym.”
A notion which has no name, or which can not be expressed by a single English word.

entry.def: The quality or state of being anonymous; anonymousness; also, that which anonymous.
entry.q: He rigorously insisted upon the rights of anonymity.

entry.ety: Gr. � without name; 'an priv. + �, Eol. for � name. See Name
entry.def: Nameless; of unknown name; also, of unknown or unavowed authorship; as, an anonymous benefactor; an anonymous pamphlet or letter.
In an anonymous manner; without a name.
The state or quality of being anonymous.

A genus of mosquitoes which are secondary hosts of the malaria parasites, and whose bite is the usual, if not the only, means of infecting human beings with malaria. Several species are found in the United States. They may be distinguished from the ordinary mosquitoes of the genus Culex by the long slender palpi, nearly equaling the beak in length, while those of the female Culex are very short. They also assume different positions when resting, Culex usually holding the body parallel to the surface on which it rests and keeping the head and beak bent at an angle, while Anopheles holds the body at an angle with the surface and the head and beak in line with it. Unless they become themselves infected by previously biting a subject affected with malaria, the insects cannot transmit the disease.

entry.ety: Gr. 'a`nw upward (fr. 'ana` up) + fyto`n a plant, fy`ein to grow
entry.def: A moss or mosslike plant which cellular stems, having usually an upward growth and distinct leaves.
One of the two orders of Nemerteans. See Nemertina.

entry.ety: From Gr. 'a`noplos unarmed ('an priv. + 'o`plon an implement, weapon) + qhri`on beast
entry.def: A genus of extinct quadrupeds of the order Ungulata, whose were first found in the gypsum quarries near Paris; characterized by the shortness and feebleness of their canine teeth (whence the name).

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'an priv. + 'o`plon weapon, sting + o'yra` tail
entry.def: A group of insects which includes the lice.
Want or defect of sight; blindness.
Want of appetite, without a loathing of food.

sn.def: causing loss of appetite; as, an anorectic (or anorexigenic) drug.

entry.def: Not according to rule; abnormal.

entry.ety: OF. aörner aöurner, fr. L. adornare to adorn. The form a-ourne was corrupted into anourne
entry.def: To adorn.
Having unequal oblique axes; as, anorthic crystals.

entry.ety: Gr. 'an priv. + � straight (� sc. � right angle); not in a right angle
entry.def: A mineral of the feldspar family, commonly occurring in small glassy crystals, also a constituent of some igneous rocks. It is a lime feldspar. See Feldspar.
A feldspar closely related to orthoclase, but triclinic. It is chiefly a silicate of sodium, potassium, and aluminium. Sp. gr., 2.57 -- 2.60.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � priv. + ortho- + Gr. �, �, the eye
entry.def: Distorted vision, in which straight lines appear bent.
An optical toy for producing amusing figures or pictures by means of two revolving disks, on one of which distorted figures are painted.

entry.ety: F. anorthose triclinic feldspar (fr. Gr. � priv. + � straight) + -ite
entry.def: A granular igneous rock composed almost exclusively of a soda-lime feldspar, usually labradorite.
Loss of the sense of smell.

sn.def: of or pertaining to anosmia.
an order of small aquatic crustaceans lacking a carapace: fairy shrimps; brine shrimps.

entry.note: ☞ As a pronoun another may have a possessive another's, pl. others, poss. pl. other'. It is much used in opposition to one; as, one went one way, another another. It is also used with one, in a reciprocal sense; as, “love one another,” that is, let each love the other or others. “These two imparadised in one another's arms.”

sn.def: One more, in addition to a former number; a second or additional one, similar in likeness or in effect.
sn.q: Another yet! -- a seventh! I 'll see no more.
Would serve to scale another Hero's tower.

sn.def: Not the same; different.
sn.q: He winks, and turns his lips another way.

sn.def: Any or some; any different person, indefinitely; any one else; some one else.
sn.q: Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth.
While I am coming, another steppeth down before me.

entry.def: Of another kind.

entry.ety: Another + gate, or gait, way. Cf. Algates
entry.def: Of another sort.
entry.q: Another-gatesadventure.

entry.def: Of another sort.
entry.q: It used to go in another-guess manner.

entry.def: See Annotto.
See Anura.
See Anurous.

entry.ety: NL.; Gr. 'an priv. + oxygen + Gr. � blood
entry.def: An abnormal condition due to deficient aëration of the blood, as in balloon sickness, mountain sickness.
a physiological state in which insufficient oxygen reaches the tissues of the body, especially when of sufficient severity to cause permanent damage.

sn.def: of, pertaining to, or suffering from, anoxia.
greatly deficient in, or totally lacking, oxygen.

entries.entry: An"sa An"sa ăn"sȧ n.; pl.Ansæ ăn"sǣ. L., a handle Astron A name given to either of the projecting ends of Saturn's ring.

entry.ety: L. ansatus, fr. ansa a handle
entry.def: Having a handle.
Having the extremities terminate in the heads of eagles, lions, etc.; as, an anserated cross.
A Linnæan order of aquatic birds swimming by means of webbed feet, as the duck, or of lobed feet, as the grebe. In this order were included the geese, ducks, auks, divers, gulls, petrels, etc.
A division of birds including the geese, ducks, and closely allied forms.

sn.def: a family name used in some classifications for the swans.

entry.ety: L. anserinus, fr. anser a goose

sn.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, a goose, or the skin of a goose.
Pertaining to the Anseres.

entry.def: Resembling a goose; silly; simple.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Answered ăn"sẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Answering
entry.ety: OE. andswerien, AS. andswerian andswarian, to answer, fr. andswaru, n., answer. See Answer n.

sn.def: To speak in defense against; to reply to in defense; as, to answer a charge; to answer an accusation.
To speak or write in return to, as in return to a call or question, or to a speech, declaration, argument, or the like; to reply to (a question, remark, etc.); to respond to.
sn.q: She answers him as if she knew his mind.
So spake the apostate angel, though in pain: . . . And him thus answered soon his bold compeer.

sn.def: To respond to satisfactorily; to meet successfully by way of explanation, argument, or justification, and the like; to refute.
sn.q: No man was able to answer him a word.
These shifts refuted, answer thine appellant.
The reasoning was not and could not be answered.

sn.def: To be or act in return or response to.

sd.def: To be or act in compliance with, in fulfillment or satisfaction of, as an order, obligation, demand; as, he answered my claim upon him; the servant answered the bell.
sd.q: This proud king . . . studies day and night To answer all the debts he owes unto you.

sd.def: To render account to or for.
sd.q: I will . . . send him to answer thee.

sd.def: To atone; to be punished for.
sd.q: And grievously hath Cæzar answered it.

sd.def: To be opposite to; to face.
sd.q: The windows answering each other, we could just discern the glowing horizon them.

sd.def: To be or act an equivalent to, or as adequate or sufficient for; to serve for; to repay.
To be or act in accommodation, conformity, relation, or proportion to; to correspond to; to suit.
sd.q: Weapons must needs be dangerous things, if they answered the bulk of so prodigious a person.

sn.def: To speak or write by way of return (originally, to a charge), or in reply; to make response.
sn.q: There was no voice, nor any that answered.

sn.def: To make a satisfactory response or return.
To render account, or to be responsible; to be accountable; to make amends; as, the man must answer to his employer for the money intrusted to his care.
sn.q: Let his neck answer for it, if there is any martial law.

sn.def: To be or act in return.

sd.def: To be or act by way of compliance, fulfillment, reciprocation, or satisfaction; to serve the purpose; as, gypsum answers as a manure on some soils.
sd.q: Do the strings answer to thy noble hand?

sd.def: To be opposite, or to act in opposition.
To be or act as an equivalent, or as adequate or sufficient; as, a very few will answer .
To be or act in conformity, or by way of accommodation, correspondence, relation, or proportion; to conform; to correspond; to suit; -- usually with to.
sd.q: That the time may have all shadow and silence in it, and the place answer to convenience.
If this but answer to my just belief, I 'll remember you.
As in water face answereth to face, so the heart of man to man.

entry.ety: OE. andsware, AS. andswaru; and against + swerian to swear. √177, 196. See Anti-, and Swear, and cf. 1st un-

sn.def: A reply to a charge; a defense.
sn.q: At my first answer no man stood with me.

sn.def: Something said or written in reply to a question, a call, an argument, an address, or the like; a reply.
sn.q: A soft answer turneth away wrath.
I called him, but he gave me no answer.

sn.def: Something done in return for, or in consequence of, something else; a responsive action.
sn.q: Great the slaughter is Here made by the Roman; great the answer be Britons must take.

sn.def: A solution, the result of a mathematical operation; as, the answer to a problem.

A counter-statement of facts in a course of pleadings; a confutation of what the other party has alleged; a responsive declaration by a witness in reply to a question. In Equity, it is the usual form of defense to the complainant's charges in his bill.

Obliged to answer; liable to be called to account; liable to pay, indemnify, or make good; accountable; amenable; responsible; as, an agent is answerable to his principal; to be answerable for a debt, or for damages.
sn.q: Will any man argue that . . . he can not be justly punished, but is answerable only to God?

sn.def: Capable of being answered or refuted; admitting a satisfactory answer.
sn.q: The argument, though subtle, is yet answerable.

sn.def: Correspondent; conformable; hence, comparable.
sn.q: What wit and policy of man is answerable to their discreet and orderly course?
This revelation . . . was answerable to that of the apostle to the Thessalonians.

sn.def: Proportionate; commensurate; suitable; as, an achievement answerable to the preparation for it.
Equal; equivalent; adequate.
sn.q: Had the valor of his soldiers been answerable, he had reached that year, as was thought, the utmost bounds of Britain.

entry.def: The quality of being answerable, liable, responsible, or correspondent.
In an answerable manner; in due proportion or correspondence; suitably.
One who answers.
Having no answer, or impossible to be answered.

entries.entry:
An 't. An it, that is, and it or if it. See An conj.
Obs
An't. A contraction for are and am not; also used for is not; -- now usually written ain't. Colloq. & illiterate speech
Ant-. See Anti- prefix.

-ant. F. -ant, fr. L. -antem or -entem, the pr. p. ending; also sometimes directly from L. -antem
A suffix sometimes marking the agent for action; as, merchant, covenant, servant, pleasant, etc. Cf. -ent.

entry.note: ☞ Among ants, as among bees, there are neuter or working ants, besides the males and females; the former are without wings. Ants live together in swarms, usually raising hillocks of earth, variously chambered within, where they maintain a perfect system of order, store their provisions, and nurture their young. There are many species, with diverse habits, as agricultural ants carpenter ants honey ants foraging ants amazon ants, etc. The white ants or Termites belong to the Neuroptera.

cs.cd: one of a very extensive group of South American birds (Formicariidæ), which live on ants. The family includes many species, some of which are called ant shrikes ant thrushes, and ant wrens.
a species of grass (Aristida oligantha) cultivated by the agricultural ants of Texas for the sake of its seed.

entry.ety: OE. ante amete emete, AS. æmete akin to G. ameise. Cf. Emmet
entry.def: A hymenopterous insect of the Linnæan genus Formica, which is now made a family of several genera; an emmet; a pismire.

entries.entry: An"ta An"ta ☞ Porches, when columns stand between two antæ, are called in Latin in antis. n.; pl.Antæ. L Arch A species of pier produced by thickening a wall at its termination, treated architecturally as a pilaster, with capital and base.

entry.def: A remedy for acidity of the stomach, as an alkali or absorbent.
Corrective of acrimony of the humors.
Pertaining to Antæus, a giant athlete slain by Hercules.

entry.note: ☞ We speak of antagonism between two things, to or against a thing, and sometimes with a thing.
entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to struggle against; � against + � to contend or struggle, � contest: cf. F. antagonisme. See Agony
entry.def: Opposition of action; counteraction or contrariety of things or principles.

entry.ety: L. antagonista, Gr. �; � against + � combatant, champion, fr. �: cf. F. antagoniste. See Antagonism

sn.def: One who contends with another, especially in combat; an adversary; an opponent.
sn.q: Antagonist of Heaven's Almigthy King.
Our antagonists in these controversies.

sn.def: A muscle which acts in opposition to another; as a flexor, which bends a part, is the antagonist of an extensor, which extends it.
A medicine which opposes the action of another medicine or of a poison when absorbed into the blood or tissues.
sn.syn: Adversary; enemy; opponent; foe; competitor. See Adversary.

entry.def: Antagonistic; opposing; counteracting; as, antagonist schools of philosophy.
Opposing in combat, combating; contending or acting against; as, antagonistic forces.
entry.q: They were distinct, adverse, even antagonistic.

sn.def: muscles having opposite effects; the contraction of one neutralizes the contraction of the other.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Antagonized; p. pr. & vb. n. Antagonozing
entry.def: To contend with; to oppose actively; to counteract.
To act in opposition.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � + � contest: cf. F. (16th centuryantagonie. See Antagonism
entry.def: Contest; opposition; antagonism.
entry.q: Antagony that is between Christ and Belial.

entry.ety: Pref. anti- + Gr. � pain: cf. F. antalgique
entry.def: Alleviating pain.

def2.def: A medicine to alleviate pain; an anodyne.

entry.def: Anything that neutralizes, or that counteracts an alkaline tendency in the system.
Of power to counteract alkalies.
Away from the ambulacral region.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � + � a bending back and breaking. See Anaclastic
entry.def: A figure which consists in repeating the same word in a different sense; as, Learn some craft when young, that when old you may live without craft.
A repetition of words beginning a sentence, after a long parenthesis; as, Shall that heart (which not only feels them, but which has all motions of life placed in them), shall that heart, etc.
A figure which consists in answering the charge of an adversary, by a counter charge.
Capable of blunting the venereal appetite.

def2.def: Anything that quells the venereal appetite.

entry.ety: Pref. anti- + Gr. � Aphrodite: cf. F. antaphroditique

sn.def: Antaphrodisiac.
Antisyphilitic.

entry.def: An antaphroditic medicine.
Good against apoplexy.
Opposition to government in general.
One who opposes all government.
Opposed to all human government.

entry.ety: OE. antartik, OF. antartique, F. antarctique, L. antarcticus, fr. Gr. �; � + � bear. See Arctic
entry.def: Opposite to the northern or arctic pole; relating to the southern pole or to the region near it, and applied especially to a circle, distant from the pole 23° 28′. Thus we say the antarctic pole, circle, ocean, region, current, etc.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � similar to + � Mars. It was thought to resemble Mars in color
entry.def: The principal star in Scorpio: -- called also the Scorpion's Heart.
Counteracting or alleviating gout.
Opposing, or fitted to relieve, asthma.
An edentate animal of tropical America (the Tamanoir), living on ants. It belongs to the genus Myrmecophaga.
See Ant bird, under Ant n.
Various kinds of plant lice or aphids tended by ants for the sake of the honeydew which they secrete; plural of ant cow. See Aphips.

entries.entry: Ant cow. Zoöl Any aphid from which ants obtain honeydew. The plural form is ant cattle.

An"te- ăn"t�-. A Latin preposition and prefix; akin to Gr. 'anti`, Skr. anti, Goth. and- anda-only in comp.), AS. and- ond-, (only in comp.: cf. Answer Along), G. ant- ent-in comp.). The Latin ante is generally used in the sense of before, in regard to position, order, or time, and the Gr. 'anti` in that of opposite, or in the place of.

entry.def: Each player's stake, which is put into the pool before (ante) the game begins.
To put up (an ante).
A preceding act.
Being before, or in front.
One of several species of edentates and monotremes that feed upon ants. See Ant-bear Pangolin Aard-vark, and Echidna.

sn.def: belonging to a period before a war, especially the American Civil War.

entry.def: Antecedent; preceding in time.
entry.q: Capable ofantecedaneousproof.

entry.ety: L. antecedere; ante + cedere to go. See Cede
entry.def: To go before in time or place; to precede; to surpass.

sn.def: The act or state of going before in time; precedence.
An apparent motion of a planet toward the west; retrogradation.

entry.def: The state or condition of being antecedent; priority.

entry.ety: L. antecedens -entis, p. pr. of antecedere: cf. F. antécédent

sn.def: Going before in time; prior; anterior; preceding; as, an event antecedent to the Deluge; an antecedent cause.
Presumptive; as, an antecedent improbability.
That which goes before in time; that which precedes.
sn.q: The Homeric mythology, as well as the Homeric language, has surely its antecedents.

sn.def: One who precedes or goes in front.
sn.q: My antecedent, or my gentleman usher.

sn.def: The earlier events of one's life; previous principles, conduct, course, history.
sn.q: If the troops . . . prove worthy of their antecedents, the victory is surely ours.

sn.def: The noun to which a relative refers; as, in the sentence “Solomon was the prince who built the temple,” prince is the antecedent of who .

sd.def: The first or conditional part of a hypothetical proposition; as, If the earth is fixed, the sun must move.
The first of the two propositions which constitute an enthymeme or contracted syllogism; as, Every man is mortal; therefore the king must die.

sn.def: The first of the two terms of a ratio; the first or third of the four terms of a proportion. In the ratio a:ba is the antecedent, and b the consequent.

entry.def: Previously; before in time; at a time preceding; as, antecedently to conversion.

entry.ety: L., fr. antecedere antecessum. See Antecede Ancestor

sn.def: One who goes before; a predecessor.
sn.q: The successor seldom prosecuting his antecessor's devices.

sn.def: An ancestor; a progenitor.
A chamber or apartment before the chief apartment and leading into it, in which persons wait for audience; an outer chamber. See Lobby.
A space viewed as the outer chamber or the entrance to an interior part.
sn.q: The mouth, the antechamber to the digestive canal.

entry.def: The outer part of the west end of a collegiate or other chapel.
A space inclosed or reserved at the entrance to the choir, for the clergy and choristers.
Where a choir is divided, as in some Spanish churches, that division of it which is the farther from the sanctuary.
See Antœcians.
A name given to that part of the Anglican liturgy for the communion, which precedes the consecration of the elements.

entry.ety: L., fr. antecurrere to run before; ante + currere to run
entry.def: A forerunner; a precursor.

sn.def: Prior date; a date antecedent to another which is the actual date.
Anticipation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Antedated; p. pr. & vb. n. Antedating

sn.def: To date before the true time; to assign to an earlier date; ; thus, to antedate a deed or a bond is to give it a date anterior to the true time of its execution.
To precede in time.
To anticipate; to make before the true time.
sn.q: And antedate the bliss above.
Who rather rose the day to antedate.

entry.def: Before the flood, or Deluge, in Noah's time.
Of or relating to the period before the Deluge in Noah's time; hence, antiquated; as, an antediluvian vehicle.

def2.def: One who lived before the Deluge.

entry.def: A genus formerly called genus Comatula.
A natural family of feather stars; formerly called family Comatulidae.
Something done before another act.

entries.entry: An"te*fix` n.; pl. E. Antefixes; L. Antefixa. L. ante + fixus fixed Arch An ornament fixed upon a frieze. An ornament at the eaves, concealing the ends of the joint tiles of the roof. An ornament of the cymatium of a classic cornice, sometimes pierced for the escape of water.

entry.def: A displacement forward of an organ, esp. the uterus, in such manner that its axis is bent upon itself.

entries.entry: Ant" egg`. One of the small white egg-shaped pupæ or cocoons of the ant, often seen in or about ant-hills, and popularly supposed to be eggs.

entry.note: ☞ The common or bezoar antelope of India is Antilope bezoartica. The chamois of the Alps, the gazelle, the addax, and the eland are other species. See Gazelle. The pronghorn antelope (Antilocapra Americana) is found in the Rocky Mountains. See Pronghorn.
entry.ety: OF. antelop, F. antilope, from Gr. 'anqo`lops -lopos, Eustathius, “Hexaëm.,” p. 36, the origin of which is unknown
entry.def: One of a group of ruminant quadrupeds, intermediate between the deer and the goat. The horns are usually annulated, or ringed. There are many species in Africa and Asia.
entry.q: The antelope and wolf both fierce and fell.

entry.def: Held or being before light; -- a word applied to assemblies of Christians, in ancient times of persecution, held before light in the morning.
entry.q: Antelucanworship.

entry.ety: L. antemeridianus; ante + meridianus belonging to midday or noon. See Meridian
entry.def: Being before noon; in or pertaining to the forenoon. (Abbrev. a. m.
Tending to check vomiting.

def2.def: A remedy to check or allay vomiting.

entries.entry: An`te mor"tem An`te mor"tem ☞ The ante-mortem statement, or dying declaration made in view of death, by one injured, as to the cause and manner of the injury, is often receivable in evidence against one charged with causing the death.. L Before death; -- generally used adjectively; as, an ante-mortem statement; ante-mortem examination.

entry.def: Being before the time of Moses.
Being or occurring before the creation of the world.

entry.ety: L. antemurale: ante + murus wall. See Mural
entry.def: An outwork of a strong, high wall, with turrets, in front of the gateway (as of an old castle), for defending the entrance.
Before birth.
Of or in the Christian church or era, anterior to the first council of Nice, held a. d. 325; as, antenicene faith.

entries.entry:
An*ten"na n.; pl.Antennæ. L. antenna sail-yard; NL., a feeler, horn of an insect
Zoöl A movable, articulated organ of sensation, attached to the heads of insects and Crustacea. There are two in the former, and usually four in the latter. They are used as organs of touch, and in some species of Crustacea the cavity of the ear is situated near the basal joint. In insects, they are popularly called horns, and also feelers. The term in also applied to similar organs on the heads of other arthropods and of annelids.
Electronics A metallic device, variously shaped, designed for the purpose of either transmitting or receiving radio waves, as for radio or television broadcasting, or for transmitting communication signals. Some types are: whip antenna antenna tower horn antenna dish antenna directional antenna and rabbit ears. See transmitter receiver.

entry.def: Belonging to the antennæ.
Bearing or having antennæ.
Shaped like antennæ.
A small antenna; -- applied to the smaller pair of antennæ or feelers of Crustacea.
A number that precedes another.
Preceding marriage; as, an antenuptial agreement.
Same as Antorbital.
Pertaining to the time before the Passover, or before Easter.

entry.ety: Pref. ante- + L. pastus pasture, food. Cf. Repast
entry.def: A foretaste.
entry.q: Antepasts of joy and comforts.

entry.ety: LL., fr. L. ante + pendere to hang
entry.def: The hangings or screen in front of the altar; an altar cloth; the frontal.

entry.ety: L. antepaenultimasc. syllaba) antepenultimate; ante before + paenultimus the last but one; paene almost + ultimus last
entry.def: The last syllable of a word except two, as -syl- in monosyllable.
Of or pertaining to the last syllable but two.
Good against nightmare.
Good against epilepsy.
To put before; to prefer.
An outer port, gate, or door.
An outer porch or vestibule.
The placing of a before another, which, by ordinary rules, ought to follow it.
Preceding dinner.
A prerequisite to a clear understanding of the predicaments and categories, such as definitions of common terms.

entry.note: ☞ In comparative anatomy, anterior often signifies at or toward the head, cephalic; and in human anatomy it is often used for ventral.
entry.ety: L. anterior, comp. of ante before

sn.def: Before in time; antecedent.
sn.q: Antigonus, who was anterior to Polybius.

sn.def: Before, or toward the front, in place; as, the anterior part of the mouth; -- opposed to posterior.
sn.syn: Antecedent; previous; precedent; preceding; former; foregoing.

entry.def: The state of being anterior or preceding in time or in situation; priority.
In an anterior manner; before.
A room before, or forming an entrance to, another; a waiting room.

entries.entry: An"te*ro-. A combining form meaning anterior front; as antero-posterior, front and back; antero-lateral, front side, anterior and at the side.

entry.def: Antæ. See Anta.
A small intrenchment or work of palisades, or of sacks of earth.
A cavity which leads into the stomach, as in birds.
The portico, or narthex in an ancient temple or church.

entry.ety: Pref. ante- + L. vertere versum, to turn
entry.def: A displacement of an organ, esp. of the uterus, in such manner that its whole axis is directed further forward than usual.

entry.ety: L. antevertere; ante + vertere to turn

sn.def: To prevent.
To displace by anteversion.

entries.entry: Ant*hel"ion ?; 277, 106 n.; pl.Anthelia. Pref. anti + Gr. � sun Meteor A halo opposite the sun, consisting of a colored ring or rings around the shadow of the spectator's own head, as projected on a cloud or on an opposite fog bank.

entry.def: Same as Antihelix.

entry.ety: Pref. anti- + Gr. "e`lmins -inqos, worm, esp. a tapeworm, or mawworm. See also helminth
entry.def: capable of expelling or destroying parasitic worms.

entry.ety: OE. antym antefne, AS. antefen, fr. LL. antiphona, fr. Gr. 'anti`fwna, neut. pl. of 'anti`fwnon antiphon, or anthem, n. neut., from 'anti`fwnos sounding contrary, returning a sound; 'anti` over against + fwnh` sound, voice: the anthem being sung by the choristers alternately, one half-choir answering the other: cf. OF. anthaine anteine antieune, F. antienne. See Antiphon

sn.def: Formerly, a hymn sung in alternate parts, in present usage, a selection from the Psalms, or other parts of the Scriptures or the liturgy, set to sacred music.
A song or hymn of praise or devotion; as, a national anthem .

entry.def: To celebrate with anthems.
entry.q: Sweet birds antheming the morn.

entries.entry: An*the"mi*on An*the"mi*on fr. Gr. 'anqemi`s flower A floral ornament. See Palmette .

entry.ety: Gr. 'anqemi`s, equiv. to 'a`nqos flower; an herb like our chamomile
entry.def: Chamomile; a genus of composite, herbaceous plants.

Any one of several fungus diseases, caused by parasitic species of the series Melanconiales, attacking the bean, grape, melon, cotton, and other plants. In the case of the grape, brown concave spots are formed on the stem and fruit, and the disease is called bird's-eye rot.

It may be transmitted to man by inoculation. The spleen becomes greatly enlarged and filled with bacteria. Called also splenic fever.

entries.entry: An"thrax vac"cine. Veter A fluid vaccine obtained by growing a bacterium (Bacillus anthracis, formerly Bacterium anthracis) in beef broth. It is used to immunize animals, esp. cattle.

That branch of anthropology which treats of the actual distribution of the human race in its different divisions, as distinguished by physical character, language, institutions, and customs, in contradistinction to ethnography, which treats historically of the origin and filiation of races and nations.

entry.note: In certain “autoimmune” diseases, the immune system of an organism may produce antibodies to parts of the organism's own structure, and can cause considerable damage and even death as a result.

The soluble antibodies present in serum are complex globins (proteins) with both constant and variable regions in the polypeptide chains, the variable region being responsible for the reaction of the antibody with its specific antigen. Typically, antibodies of more than one structure may react with a given antigen, and any given antigen may stimulate production of more than one antibody. Methods have been developed to grow cells in tissue culture which produce predominantly only one specific antibody, and such antibodies thus produced (called monoclonal antibodies) are highly specific in their reactions to molecular strucures, and are used as valuable reagents in biochemical technology.

sn.def: Any of various bodies or substances in the blood which act in antagonism to harmful foreign bodies, as toxins or the bacteria producing the toxins. Normal blood serum apparently contains various antibodies, and the introduction of toxins or of foreign cells also stimulates production of their specific antibodies by the immune system.

more narrowly, any of the immunoglobulins present in the blood serum or other body fluids of an animal, which reacts with a specific antigenic substance, whether the antibody was produced as a consequence of the stimulus provided by the antigen, or was pre-existing prior to exposure of the organism to the antigen.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the antibrachium, or forearm.

entry.ety: L. anticipans, p. pr. of anticipare
entry.def: Anticipating; expectant; -- with of.
entry.q: Wakening guilt, anticipant of hell.

entry.usage: To Anticipate Expect. These words, as here compared, agree in regarding some future event as about to take place. Expect is the stringer. It supposes some ground or reason in the mind for considering the event as likely to happen. Anticipate is, literally, to take beforehand, and here denotes simply to take into the mind as conception of the future. Hence, to say, “I did not anticipate a refusal,” expresses something less definite and strong than to say, “ did not expect it.” Still, anticipate is a convenient word to be interchanged with expect in cases where the thought will allow.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Anticipated; p. pr. & vb. n. Anticipating
entry.ety: L. anticipatus, p. p. of anticipare to anticipate; ante + capere to make. See Capable

sn.def: To be before in doing; to do or take before another; to preclude or prevent by prior action.
sn.q: To anticipate and prevent the duke's purpose.
He would probably have died by the hand of the executioner, if indeed the executioner had not been anticipated by the populace.

sn.def: To take up or introduce beforehand, or before the proper or normal time; to cause to occur earlier or prematurely; as, the advocate has anticipated a part of his argument.
To foresee (a wish, command, etc.) and do beforehand that which will be desired.

sn.syn: To prevent; obviate; preclude; forestall; expect.
sn.q: Good with badExpect to hear; supernal grace contending With sinfulness of men.

rightfully expected.
