entry.note: ☞ It is of tin-white color, brittle, laminated or crystalline, fusible, and vaporizable at a rather low temperature. It is used in some metallic alloys, as type metal and bell metal, and also for medical preparations, which are in general emetics or cathartics. By ancient writers, and some moderns, the term is applied to native gray ore of antimony, or stibnitethe stibium of the Romans, and the sti`mmi of the Greeks, a sulphide of antimony, from which most of the antimony of commerce is obtained. Cervantite senarmontite, and valentinite are native oxides of antimony.
entry.def: An elementary substance, resembling a metal in its appearance and physical properties, but in its chemical relations belonging to the class of nonmetallic substances. Atomic weight, 120. Symbol, Sb.

sn.def: one of several antibiotic substances produced by several species of Streptomyces, active against various fungi. They are used only experimentally, not in medicine. The two best-known antimycins are antimycin A1C28H40N2O9) and antimycin A3C26H36N2O9). They are notable for their mechanism of action, interference with the proton pumping mechanism of fungi.

entry.def: Antagonistic to one's country or nation, or to a national government.
Counteracting, or deemed of use in, diseases of the kidneys.
The antiparticle of a neutrino. Each type of neutrino has a corresponding antineutrino.
The antiparticle of a neutron. It has the same mass as a neutron, but a spin and magnetic moment opposite that of the neutron.
Of or pertaining to the Antinomians; opposed to the doctrine that the moral law is obligatory.

One who maintains that, under the gospel dispensation, the moral law is of no use or obligation, but that faith alone is necessary to salvation. The sect of Antinomians originated with John Agricola, in Germany, about the year 1535.
The tenets or practice of Antinomians.
An Antinomian.

entries.entry:
An*tin"o*my ?; 277 n.; pl.Antinomies. L. antinomia, Gr. �; � against + � law
Opposition of one law or rule to another law or rule. Different commentators have deduced from it the very opposite doctrines. In some instances this apparent antinomy is doubtful.
An opposing law or rule of any kind. As it were by his own antinomy, or counterstatute.
Metaph A contradiction or incompatibility of thought or language; -- in the Kantian philosophy, such a contradiction as arises from the attempt to apply to the ideas of the reason, relations or attributes which are appropriate only to the facts or the concepts of experience.

cs.cd: a method of computing time, from the proclamation of liberty granted to the city of Antioch, about the time of the battle of Pharsalia, B.C. 48.

sn.def: Pertaining to Antiochus, a contemporary with Cicero, and the founder of a sect of philosophers.
Of or pertaining to the city of Antioch, in Syria.

entry.def: Efficacious in curing toothache.

entry.ety: Pref. anti- + Gr. � to swell, as with lust
entry.def: Tending to allay venereal excitement or desire; sedative.
Opposed to the pope or to popery.
Running in a contrary direction.
Straight lines or planes which make angles in some respect opposite in character to those made by parallel lines or planes.
Good against paralysis.
Antiparalytic.

A fundamental particle which has the same mass as one of the common fundamental particles, but which has an opposite charge, and for which certain other of the properties (e. g. baryon number, strangeness) may be opposite to that of the normal particle. The antiparticle to an electron is called a positron; the antiparticle to a proton is called an antiproton; the antiparticle to a neutron is called an antineutron. When a particle and its corresponding antiparticle collide, they typically annihilate each other with the production of large quantities of energy, usually in the form of radiation. The interaction of a proton and antiproton cause annihilation with production of mesons.
The Sunday after Easter; Low Sunday.
Having a natural contrariety, or constitutional aversion, to a thing; characterized by antipathy; -- often followed by to.

entry.ety: NL. antipathicus, Gr. � of opposite feelings
entry.def: Belonging to antipathy; opposite; contrary; allopathic.
One who has an antipathy.
entry.q: Antipathistof light.

entry.def: To feel or show antipathy.
Having a natural contrariety; adverse; antipathetic.

entries.entry:
An*tip"a*thy ☞ Antipathy is opposed to sympathy. It is followed by to against, or between; also sometimes by for. n.; pl.Antipathies. L. antipathia, Gr. �; � against + � to suffer. Cf. F. antipathie. See Pathos
Contrariety or opposition in feeling; settled aversion or dislike; repugnance; distaste. Inveterate antipathies against particular nations, and passionate attachments to others, are to be avoided.
Natural contrariety; incompatibility; repugnancy of qualities; as, oil and water have antipathy . A habit is generated of thinking that a natural antipathy exists between hope and reason. Hatred; aversion; dislike; disgust; distaste; enmity; ill will; repugnance; contrariety; opposition. See Dislike.

entry.def: A product of gastric and pancreatic digestion, differing from hemipeptone in not being decomposed by the continued action of pancreatic juice.
A remedy possessing the property of preventing the return of periodic paroxysms, or exacerbations, of disease, as in intermittent fevers.
Opposed to, or checking motion; acting upward; -- applied to an inverted action of the intestinal tube.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � against + � a standing around, fr. � to stand around; � around + � to stand
entry.def: Opposition by which the quality opposed asquires strength; resistance or reaction roused by opposition or by the action of an opposite principle or quality.
Pertaining to antiperistasis.
Standing before a petal, as a stamen.
Antidotal; alexipharmic.
An opposer of the theory of phlogiston.

sn.def: Opposed to the doctrine of phlogiston.
Counteracting inflammation.

entry.def: Any medicine or diet which tends to check inflammation.

entry.ety: LL. antiphona, fr. Gr. �. See Anthem

sn.def: A musical response; alternate singing or chanting. See Antiphony, and Antiphone.
A verse said before and after the psalms.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to antiphony, or alternate singing; sung alternately by a divided choir or opposite choirs.
A book of antiphons or anthems.
A book containing a collection of antiphons; the book in which the antiphons of the breviary, with their musical notes, are contained.
The response which one side of the choir makes to the other in a chant; alternate chanting or signing.
A book of antiphons.
Antiphonal.

entries.entry:
An*tiph"o*ny n.; pl.Antiphonies. See Antiphon
A musical response; also, antiphonal chanting or signing.
An anthem or psalm sung alternately by a choir or congregation divided into two parts. Also figuratively. O! never more for me shall winds intone, With all your tops, a vast antiphony.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to express by antithesis or negation
entry.def: The use of words in a sense opposite to their proper meaning; as when a court of justice is called a court of vengeance.
Pertaining to antiphrasis.
Relieving or curing phthisis, or consumption.
Contrary to nature; unnatural.
Relieving flatulence; carminative.

sn.def: Diminishing plasticity.
Preventing or checking the process of healing, or granulation.

entry.def: Good against gout.

sn.def: Pertaining to the antipodes; situated on the opposite side of the globe.
Diametrically opposite.
sn.q: Hisantipodalshadow.

entry.note: ☞ The singular, antipode, is exceptional in formation, but has been used by good writers. Its regular English plural would be ăn"tĭ*pōdes, the last syllable rhyming with abodes, and this pronunciation is sometimes heard. The plural form (originally a Latin word without a singular) is in common use, and is pronounced, after the English method of Latin, ăn*tĭp"�*dēz.
entry.def: One of the antipodes; anything exactly opposite.
entry.q: In tale or history your beggar is ever the just antipode to your king.

entry.def: Pertaining to the antipodes, or the opposite side of the world; antipodal.

entry.ety: L. pl., fr. Gr. � with the feet opposite, pl. � �; � against + �, �, foot

sn.def: Those who live on the side of the globe diametrically opposite.
The country of those who live on the opposite side of the globe.
Anything exactly opposite or contrary.
sn.q: Can there be a greater contrariety unto Christ's judgment, a more perfect antipodes to all that hath hitherto been gospel?

entry.def: The opposite pole; anything diametrically opposed.
One who is elected, or claims to be, pope in opposition to the pope canonically chosen; esp. applied to those popes who resided at Avignon during the Great Schism.
Of use in curing the itch.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �; � against + � a falling, a case, � to fall
entry.def: The putting of one case for another.
Counteracting, or preserving from, putrefaction; antiseptic.
Checking or preventing suppuration.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � against + � to be feverish, fr. � fire
entry.def: The condition or state of being free from fever.
Efficacious in preventing or allaying fever.
An artificial alkaloid, believed to be efficient in abating fever.
Good against burns or pyrosis.

def2.def: Anything of use in preventing or healing burns or pyrosis.

entries.entry: An`ti*qua"ri*an a. See Antiquary . Pertaining to antiquaries, or to antiquity; as, antiquarian literature.

sn.def: An antiquary.
A drawing paper of large size. See under Paper n.

entry.def: Character of an antiquary; study or love of antiquities.
To act the part of an antiquary.

entry.ety: L. antiquarius, fr. antiquus ancient. See Antique
entry.def: Pertaining to antiquity.
entry.q: Instructed by theantiquarytimes.

entries.entry: An"ti*qua*ry n.; pl.Antiquaries. One devoted to the study of ancient times through their relics, as inscriptions, monuments, remains of ancient habitations, statues, coins, manuscripts, etc.; one who searches for and studies the relics of antiquity.

entry.ety: L. antiquatus, p. p. of antiquare, fr. antiquus ancient
entry.def: To make old, or obsolete; to make antique; to make old in such a degree as to put out of use; hence, to make void, or abrogate.
entry.q: Christianity might reasonably introduce new laws, and antiquate or abrogate old one.

entry.def: Grown old. Hence: Bygone; obsolete; out of use; old-fashioned; as, an antiquated law.
entry.q: Antiquatedwords.
Old Janet, for so he understood his antiquated attendant was denominated.
entry.syn: Ancient; old; antique; obsolete. See Ancient.

entry.def: Quality of being antiquated.
Antiquatedness.
The act of making antiquated, or the state of being antiquated.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. antiquus old, ancient, equiv. to anticus, from ante before. Cf. Antic

sn.def: Old; ancient; of genuine antiquity; as, an antique statue. In this sense it usually refers to the flourishing ages of Greece and Rome.
sn.q: For the antique world excess and pride did hate.

sn.def: Old, as respects the present age, or a modern period of time; of old fashion; antiquated; as, an antique robe.
sn.q: Antiquewords.

sn.def: Made in imitation of antiquity; as, the antique style of Thomson's “Castle of Indolence.”
Odd; fantastic.
sn.syn: Ancient; antiquated; obsolete; antic; old-fashioned; old. See Ancient.

entry.def: In general, anything very old; but in a more limited sense, a relic or object of ancient art; collectively, the antique, the remains of ancient art, as busts, statues, paintings, and vases.
entry.q: Misshapen monuments and maimed antiques.

entry.def: In an antique manner.
The quality of being antique; an appearance of ancient origin and workmanship.
entry.q: We may discover something venerable in the antiqueness of the work.

entry.def: An antiquary; a collector of antiques.
An admirer of antiquity. Used by Milton in a disparaging sense

entries.entry:
An*tiq"ui*ty n.; pl.Antiquities. L. antiquitas, fr. antiquus: cf. F. antiquité. See Antique
The quality of being ancient; ancientness; great age; as, a statue of remarkable antiquity; a family of great antiquity.
Old age. Obs It not your voice broken? . . . and every part about you blasted with antiquity?
Ancient times; former ages; times long since past; as, Cicero was an eloquent orator of antiquity .
The ancients; the people of ancient times. That such pillars were raised by Seth all antiquity has �vowed.
An old gentleman. Obs You are a shrewd antiquity, neighbor Clench.
A relic or monument of ancient times; as, a coin, a statue, etc.; an ancient institution. In this sense, usually in the plural
Heathenantiquities.

entry.def: Good against the rickets.
One opposed to the payment of rent; esp. one of those who in 1840-47 resisted the collection of rents claimed by the patroons from the settlers on certain manorial lands in the State of New York.
One of a sect which opposes the observance of the Christian Sabbath.
Hostile to priests or the priesthood.

entry.ety: L. antiscii, Gr. �, pl.; � against + � shadow
entry.def: The inhabitants of the earth, living on different sides of the equator, whose shadows at noon are cast in opposite directions.
entry.q: The inhabitants of the north and south temperate zones are always Antiscians.

entry.def: Anthelmintic.
Counteracting scurvy.
Antiscorbutic.
Opposed to, or not in accordance with, the Holy Scriptures.
Opposition to, or hatred of, Semites, esp. Jews. The word is sometimes also applied to acts motivated by or evincing antisemitism.
Standing before a sepal, or calyx leaf.
Prevention of sepsis by excluding or destroying microorganisms.

cs.cd: that system of surgical practice which insists upon a systematic use of antiseptics in the performance of operations and the dressing of wounds.

entry.def: Counteracting or preventing putrefaction, or a putrescent tendency in the system; antiputrefactive.

a substance which kills or retards the growth of microorganisms, especially when used for protection against infection; a substance which prevents or retards putrefaction, or destroys, or protects from, putrefactive organisms; as, carbolic acid, alcohol, cinchona, and many other agents sold commercially.
By means of antiseptics.
Checking the flow of saliva.
A remedy against excessive salivation.
Opposed to slavery.
Tending to interrupt or destroy social intercourse; averse to society, or hostile to its existence; as, antisocial principles.
One opposed to the doctrines and practices of socialists or socialism.
Opposite to the sun; -- said of the point in the heavens 180° distant from the sun.
Good against spasms.

def2.def: A medicine which prevents or allays spasms or convulsions.

entry.ety: L. antispastus, Gr. �, fr. � to draw the contrary way; � against + � to draw
entry.def: A foot of four syllables, the first and fourth short, and the second and third long (#).
Believed to cause a revulsion of fluids or of humors from one part to another.
Counteracting spasms; antispasmodic.
Good as a remedy against disease of the spleen.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to turn to the opposite side; � against + � to turn. See Strophe

sn.def: In Greek choruses and dances, the returning of the chorus, exactly answering to a previous strophe or movement from right to left. Hence: The lines of this part of the choral song.
sn.q: It was customary, on some occasions, to dance round the altars whilst they sang the sacred hymns, which consisted of three stanzas or parts; the first of which, called strophe, was sung in turning from east to west; the other, named antistrophe, in returning from west to east; then they stood before the altar, and sang the epode, which was the last part of the song.

sd.def: The repetition of words in an inverse order; as, the master of the servant and the servant of the master.
The retort or turning of an adversary's plea against him.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an antistrophe.
An argument retorted on an opponent.
Antistrumous.
Good against scrofulous disorders.
Efficacious against syphilis.
The doctrine of antitheists.
A disbeliever in the existence of God.

entries.entry:
An*tith"e*sis n.; pl.Antitheses. L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to set against, to oppose; � against + � to set. See Thesis
Rhet An opposition or contrast of words or sentiments occurring in the same sentence; as, “The prodigal robs his heir; the miser robs himself.” “He had covertly shot at Cromwell; he how openly aimed at the Queen.”
The second of two clauses forming an antithesis.
Opposition; contrast.

entry.def: An antithetic or contrasted statement.
Pertaining to antithesis, or opposition of words and sentiments; containing, or of the nature of, antithesis; contrasted.
By way antithesis.

A substance (sometimes the product of a specific micro-organism and sometimes naturally present in the blood or tissues of an animal), capable of producing immunity from certain diseases, or of counteracting the poisonous effects of pathogenic bacteria.
A westerly wind which blows nearly continuously between 30° and 50° of latitude in both the northern and the southern hemisphere.
A prominence on the lower posterior portion of the concha of the external ear, opposite the tragus. See Ear.
An articular surface on the ilium of birds against which the great trochanter of the femur plays.

entry.ety: Pref. anti- + Gr. � turn, � to turn
entry.def: At the extremity most remote from the hilum, as the embryo, or inverted with respect to the seed, as the radicle.

sn.def: opposed to trusts, monopolies, or other large combinations of business or capital which threaten fair competition; designed to protect trade and commerce from unfair business practices; -- of laws and regulations.
having ability to to suppress or relieve coughing; -- of chemical substances.

entry.note: Codeine is one such commonly used antitussive.

sn.def: a medicament used to suppress or relieve coughing; an antitussive substance.

entry.def: Antitypical.

entry.ety: Gr. � of corresponding form; � against + � type, figure. See Type
entry.def: That of which the type is the pattern or representation; that which is represented by the type or symbol.

sn.def: of or pertaining to antitypes.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an antitype; explaining the type.
Resisting blows; hard.
Opposition or resistance of matter to force.
Opposition to vaccination.
An antivaccinist.
One opposed to vaccination.
Preventing the contagion of smallpox.
Good against venereal poison; antisyphilitic.
The serum of blood rendered antitoxic to a venom by repeated injections of small doses of the venom; also, the component of such a serum which is antitoxic to the venom.
Opposition to vivisection.
One opposed to vivisection
Preventing fermentation.
Preventing fermentation or decomposition.

entry.note: ☞ The branch next to the head is called the brow antler, and the branch next above, the bez antler, or bay antler. The main stem is the beam, and the branches are often called tynes. Antlers are deciduous bony (not horny) growths, and are covered with a periosteum while growing. See Velvet.

cs.cd: a destructive European moth (Cerapteryx graminis), which devastates grass lands.

entry.ety: OE. auntelere, OF. antoillier andoiller endouiller, fr. F. andouiller, fr. an assumed LL. antocularis, fr. L. ante before + oculus eye. See Ocular
entry.def: The entire horn, or any branch of the horn, of a cervine animal, as of a stag.
entry.q: Huge stags with sixteen antlers.

entry.def: Furnished with antlers.
entry.q: The antlered stag.

entries.entry: Ant"li*a Ant"li*a n.; pl.Antilæ. L., a pump, Gr, � hold of a ship Zoöl The spiral tubular proboscis of lepidopterous insects. See Lepidoptera.

entry.def: A neuropterous insect, the larva of which makes in the sand a pitfall to capture ants, etc. The common American species is Myrmeleon obsoletus, the European is Myrmeleon formicarius.

entries.entry:
‖An*tœ"ci ăn*tē"sī An*tœ"cians
-sh�nz n. pl. NL. antoeci, fr. Gr. pl. 'a`ntoiki; 'anti` opposite + o'ikei^n to live Those who live under the same meridian, but on opposite parallels of latitude, north and south of the equator.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to name instead; � + � to name, � name
entry.def: The use of some epithet or the name of some office, dignity, or the like, instead of the proper name of the person; as when his majesty is used for a king, or when, instead of Aristotle, we say, the philosopher; or, conversely, the use of a proper name instead of an appellative, as when a wise man is called a Solomon, or an eminent orator a Cicero.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, antonomasia.
Antonomasia.

entry.ety: Gr. � a word used in substitution for another; � + �, �, a word
entry.def: A word of opposite meaning; a counterterm; -- used as a correlative of synonym.
Pertaining to, or situated in, the region of the front of the orbit.
See Antiorgastic.
A compound formerly supposed to be modification of oxygen, but now known to be hydrogen dioxide; -- so called because apparently antagonistic to ozone, converting it into ordinary oxygen.
Relating to an antrum.

entry.ety: F. antre, L. antrum, fr. Gr. �
entry.def: A cavern.

entry.ety: From L. ante + versun turned; apparently formed in imitation of retrorse
entry.def: Forward or upward in direction.
To bend forward.

entries.entry: An"trum An"trum n.; pl.Antra. L., fr. Gr. � A cavern or cavity, esp. an anatomical cavity or sinus. Huxley.

An*trus"tion An*trus"tion n. F., fr. LL. antrustio
A vassal or voluntary follower of Frankish princes in their enterprises.
Ant" thrush`. Zoöl One of several species of tropical birds, of the Old World, of the genus Pitta, somewhat resembling the thrushes, and feeding chiefly on ants. See Ant bird, under Ant.

entry.def: An Egyptian deity, the conductor of departed spirits to judgment, represented by a human figure with the head of a jackal, dog or fox.

sn.def: any of a group of powerful earth spirits or genii; servitors of the gods.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'an priv. + o'yra` a tail
entry.def: One of the orders of amphibians characterized by the absence of a tail, as the frogs and toads.

sn.def: an amphibian of the order Anura; any of various tailless stout-bodied amphibians with long hind limbs for leaping; semiaquatic and terrestrial species; a frog or toad.
inability to urinate.
of or pertaining to anuresis.
inability to urinate.

entry.def: Destitute of a tail, as the frogs and toads.
Nonsecretion or defective secretion of urine; ischury.

entry.ety: L., prob. for asnus: cf. Gr. � to sit, Skr. ās
entry.def: The posterior opening of the alimentary canal, through which the excrements are expelled.

cs.cd: to be in a state of discussion, formation, or preparation, as when a scheme or measure is forming, but not matured.

entry.ety: OE. anvelt anfelt anefelt, AS. anfilt onfilt; of uncertain origin; cf. OHG. anafalz, D. aanbeld

sn.def: An iron block, usually with a steel face, upon which metals are hammered and shaped.

entry.sn: Anything resembling an anvil in shape or use. Specifically Anat the incus. See Incus.

entry.def: To form or shape on an anvil; to hammer out; as, anviled armor.
The state of being anxious; anxiety.

entries.entry:
Anx*i"e*ty n.; pl.Anxieties. L. anxietas, fr. anxius: cf. F. anxiété. See Anxious
Concern or solicitude respecting some thing or event, future or uncertain, which disturbs the mind, and keeps it in a state of painful uneasiness.
Eager desire.
Med A state of restlessness and agitation, often with general indisposition and a distressing sense of oppression at the epigastrium. Care; solicitude; foreboding; uneasiness; perplexity; disquietude; disquiet; trouble; apprehension; restlessness. See Care.

entry.note: Anxious is followed by foraboutconcerning, etc., before the object of solicitude.
entry.ety: L. anxius, fr. angere to cause pain, choke; akin to Gr. 'a`gchein to choke. See Anger

sn.def: Full of anxiety or disquietude; greatly concerned or solicitous, esp. respecting something future or unknown; being in painful suspense; -- applied to persons; as, anxious for the issue of a battle.
Accompanied with, or causing, anxiety; worrying; -- applied to things; as, anxious labor.
sn.q: The sweet of life, from which God hath bid dwell far off all anxious cares.

sn.def: Earnestly desirous; as, anxious to please.
sn.q: He sneers alike at those who are anxious to preserve and at those who are eager for reform.
sn.syn: Solicitous; careful; uneasy; unquiet; restless; concerned; disturbed; watchful.

entry.def: In an anxious manner; with painful uncertainty; solicitously.
The quality of being anxious; great solicitude; anxiety.

entry.note: ☞ Any is often used in denying or asserting without limitation; as, this thing ought not be done at any time; I ask any one to answer my question.
It is often used, either in the singular or the plural, as a pronoun, the person or thing being understood; anybody; anyone; (pl.) any persons.

cs.cd: whatever may be the state of affairs; anyhow.

entry.ety: OE. æniȝ æni eni ani oni, AS. ǣnig, fr. ān one. It is akin to OS. ēnig, OHG. einic, G. einig, D. eenig. See One

sn.def: One indifferently, out of an indefinite number; one indefinitely, whosoever or whatsoever it may be.
sn.q: No man knoweth the Son, but the Father; neither knoweth any man the Father, save the Son.

sn.def: Some, of whatever kind, quantity, or number; as, are there any witnesses present? are there any other houses like it?
sn.q: Who will show usanygood?
If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, . . . and it shall be given him.
That if he found any of this way, whether they were men or women, he might bring them bound unto Jerusalem.

entry.def: To any extent; in any degree; at all.
entry.q: You are not to go loose any longer.
Before you go any farther.

sn.def: Any one out of an indefinite number of persons; anyone; any person.
sn.q: His Majesty could not keep any secret from anybody.

sn.def: A person of consideration or standing.
sn.q: All the men belonged exclusively to the mechanical and shopkeeping classes, and there was not a single banker or anybody in the list.

entry.def: In any way or manner whatever; at any rate; in any event.
entry.q: Anyhow, it must be acknowledged to be not a simple selforiginated error.
Anyhow, the languages of the two nations were closely allied.

entry.def: One taken at random rather than by selection; anybody. Commonly written as two words

entry.note: ☞ Any thing, written as two words, is now commonly used in contradistinction to any person or anybody. Formerly it was also separated when used in the wider sense. “Necessity drove them to undertake any thing and venture any thing.”
entry.cs: Anything but not at all or in any respect. “The battle was a rare one, and the victory anything but secure.” Hawthorne. Anything like in any respect; at all; as, I can not give anything like a fair sketch of his trials.

sn.def: Any object, act, state, event, or fact whatever; thing of any kind; something or other; aught; as, I would not do it for anything .
sn.q: Did you ever know of anything so unlucky?
They do not know that anything is amiss with them.

sn.def: Expressing an indefinite comparison; -- with as or like.
sn.q: I fear your girl will grow as proud as anything.

entry.def: In any measure; anywise; at all.
entry.q: Mine old good will and hearty affection towards you is not . . . anything at all quailed.

entry.def: One who holds to no particular creed or dogma.
Anywise; at all.
In any place.
To or towards any place.
In any wise or way; at all.
entry.q: Anywiseessential.

cs.cd: the fountain of Aganippe, at the foot of Mount Helicon, not far from Thebes, and sacred to the Muses.

entry.ety: From Aonia, a part of Bœotia, in Greece
entry.def: Pertaining to Aonia, in Bœotia, or to the Muses, who were supposed to dwell there.

entry.ety: Gr. 'ao`ristos indefinite; 'a priv. + "ori`zein to define, � boundary, limit
entry.def: A tense in the Greek language, which expresses an action as completed in past time, but leaves it, in other respects, wholly indeterminate.
Indefinite; pertaining to the aorist tense.

entry.note: ☞ In fishes and the early stages of all higher vertebrates the aorta divides near its origin into several branches (the aortic arches) which pass in pairs round the œsophagus and unite to form the systemic aorta. One or more pairs of these arches persist in amphibia and reptiles, but only one arch in birds and mammals, this being on the right side in the former, and on the left in the latter.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to lift, heave
entry.def: The great artery which carries the blood from the heart to all parts of the body except the lungs; the main trunk of the arterial system.

sn.def: of or pertaining to the aorta.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the aorta.
Inflammation of the aorta.

sn.def: a genus of nocturnal South American monkeys with large eyes; the owl monkeys; the douroucoulis. See douroucouli.

entry.def: An African sheeplike quadruped (the Ammotragus lervia, formerly Ammotragus tragelaphus) having a long mane on the breast and fore legs; the wild sheep of northern Africa; -- called also Barbary sheep. It is, perhaps, the chamois of the Old Testament.
entry.syn: aoudad, arui, Barbary sheep, maned sheep.

entry.ety: Pref. a- + pace. OE. a pas at a walk, in which a is the article. See Pace
entry.def: With a quick pace; quick; fast; speedily.
entry.q: His dewy locks did drop with brine apace.
A visible triumph of the gospel draw� on apace.

entries.entry: A*pa"ches n. pl.; sing. Apache. Ethnol A group of nomadic North American Indians including several tribes native of Arizona, New Mexico, etc.

entry.ety: Gr. � a leading away, fr. � to lead away; � from + � to lead
entry.def: An indirect argument which proves a thing by showing the impossibility or absurdity of the contrary.
Proving indirectly, by showing the absurdity, or impossibility of the contrary.
Paid; pleased.
To impair or become impaired; to injure.
See Appalachian.
Same as Appanage.
An aversion to the company of men; a love of solitude.
See Mataco.
A kind of pack saddle used in the American military service and among the Spanish Americans. It is made of leather stuffed with hay, moss, or the like.

entry.ety: Gr. �, from � to count off or over
entry.def: Enumeration of parts or particulars.

entry.ety: F. à part; (L. ad) + part part. See Part

sn.def: Separately, in regard to space or company; in a state of separation as to place; aside.
sn.q: Others apart sat on a hill retired.
The Lord hath set apart him that is godly for himself.

sn.def: In a state of separation, of exclusion, or of distinction, as to purpose, use, or character, or as a matter of thought; separately; independently; as, consider the two propositions apart .
Aside; away.
sn.q: Wherefore layapartall filthiness and superfluity of naughtiness.
Let Pleasure go, put Care apart.

sn.def: In two or more parts; asunder; to piece; as, to take a piece of machinery apart .
segregation by race; -- a term used in South Africa.
the official policy of strict segregation by race practised by the government of the Union of South Africa up to 1993.

cs.cd: a small apartment{4}, sometimes furnished, with minimal kitchen and bath facilities. The unit may comprise a single room plus a bathroom, and the kitchen facilities are often open to the main room, or may form a small niche in a corner. There are many variations of efficiency apartment, including some in which furnishings such as a bed may be pull out from a wall recess and stored there again when not in use. Also called an efficiency.

entry.ety: F. appartement; cf. It. appartamento, fr. appartare to separate, set apart; all fr. L. ad + pars partis, part. See Apart

sn.def: A room in a building; a division in a house, separated from others by partitions.
A set or suite of rooms.
A compartment.

A room or suite of rooms in a building comprising a dwelling unit separate from others in the building, and typically having its own separate bath, sanitary, and kitchen facilities. Such apartments are in most cases rented from the owner by those dwelling in them.

entries.entry: A*part"ment house. A building comprising a number of lving units (apartments{4}) designed for separate housekeeping tenements, but having conveniences, such as heat, light, elevator service, etc., furnished in common; contrasted to a detached dwelling. Sometimes distinguished in the United States from a flat house, in which each living unit comprises one entire floor, whereas in an apartment house a floor may be partitioned into any number of apartments{4}.

entry.def: The quality of standing apart.
That point in the orbit of a double star where the smaller star is farthest from its primary.
Void of feeling; not susceptible of deep emotion; passionless.
entry.illu: a woman who became active rather than apathetic as she grew older

sn.def: showing a lack of interest or concern; indifferent.

entry.def: In an apathetic manner.
One who is destitute of feeling.
Apathetic; une motional.

entries.entry:
Ap"a*thy ☞ In the first ages of the church, the Christians adopted the term to express a contempt of earthly concerns. n.; pl.Apathies. L. apathia, Gr. �; 'a priv. + �, fr. �, �, to suffer: cf. F. apathie. See Pathos
Want of feeling; privation of passion, emotion, or excitement; dispassion; -- applied either to the body or the mind. As applied to the mind, it is a calmness, indolence, or state of indifference, incapable of being ruffled or roused to active interest or exertion by pleasure, pain, or passion. Theapathyof despair. A certain apathy or sluggishness in his nature which led him . . . to leave events to take their own course. According to the Stoics, apathy meant the extinction of the passions by the ascendency of reason. Insensibility; unfeelingness; indifference; unconcern; stoicism; supineness; sluggishness.

entry.ety: Gr. � deceit, fr. � to deceive; it having been often mistaken for other minerals
entry.def: Native phosphate of lime, occurring usually in six-sided prisms, color often pale green, transparent or translucent.

sn.def: a genus of extinct dinosaurs comprising the brontosaurs; apatosaurs.
a genus of large Old World butterflies.

entry.def: See Appaumé.

entry.note: ☞ The ape of the Old Testament was probably the rhesus monkey of India, and allied forms.
entry.ety: AS. apa; akin to D. aap, OHG. affo, G. affe, Icel. api, Sw. apa, Dan. abe, W. epa

sn.def: A quadrumanous mammal, esp. of the family Simiadæ, having teeth of the same number and form as in man, and possessing neither a tail nor cheek pouches. The name is applied esp. to species of the genus Hylobates, and is sometimes used as a general term for all Quadrumana. The higher forms, the gorilla, chimpanzee, and ourang, are often called anthropoid apes or man apes.
One who imitates servilely (in allusion to the manners of the ape); a mimic.
A dupe.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Aped; p. pr. & vb. n. Aping
entry.def: To mimic, as an ape imitates human actions; to imitate or follow servilely or irrationally.
entry.q: How heapeshis sire.
The people of England will not ape the fashions they have never tried.

entry.ety: Pref. a- + peak. Cf. F. à pic vertically
entry.def: In a vertical line. The anchor in apeak, when the cable has been sufficiently hove in to bring the ship over it, and the ship is them said to be hove apeak.
The state of being an ape.

entry.ety: Pref. a- not + L. pellis skin
entry.def: Destitute of skin.

entry.ety: L. Apenninus, fr. Celtic pen, or ben, peak, mountain
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the Apennines, a chain of mountains extending through Italy.

entry.ety: NL. apepsia, fr. Gr. �, fr. � uncooked, undigested; 'a priv. + � cooked, � to cook, digest
entry.def: Defective digestion, indigestion.
One who apes.

entries.entry:
A`per`çu" A`per`çu" ȧ`pâr`sụ" n.; pl. Aperçus -sụ" . F., prop. p. p. of apercevoir to perceive
A first view or glance, or the perception or estimation so obtained; an immediate apprehension or insight, appreciative rather than analytic. The main object being to develop the several aperçus or insights which furnish the method of such psychology. A series of partial and more or less disparate aperçus or outlooks; each for itself a center of experience.
Hence, a brief or detached view; conspectus; sketch.

entry.def: The wild Guinea pig of Brazil (Cavia aperea).

entry.ety: L. aperiens, p. pr. of aperire to uncover, open; ab + parire parere, to bring forth, produce. Cf. Cover Overt
entry.def: Gently opening the bowels; laxative.

entry.ety: Cf. F. apéritif, fr. L. aperire
entry.def: Serving to open; aperient.

entry.ety: OF. apert, L. apertus, p. p. of aperire. See Aperient, and cf. Pert a.
entry.def: Open; evident; undisguised.
Openly.
The act of opening; an opening; an aperture.
Openly; clearly.
Openness; frankness.

entry.note: ☞ The aperture of microscopes is often expressed in degrees, called also the angular aperture, which signifies the angular breadth of the pencil of light which the instrument transmits from the object or point viewed; as, a microscope of 100° aperture.
entry.ety: L. apertura, fr. aperire. See Aperient

sn.def: The act of opening.
An opening; an open space; a gap, cleft, or chasm; a passage perforated; a hole; as, an aperture in a wall.
sn.q: An aperture between the mountains.
The back aperture of the nostrils.

sn.def: The diameter of the exposed part of the object glass of a telescope or other optical instrument; as, a telescope of four-inch aperture .

entries.entry:
Ap"er*y n.; pl.Aperies.
A place where apes are kept. R
The practice of aping; an apish action.

entry.def: Having no petals, or flower leaves. [See Illust. under Anther].
The state of being apetalous.

entries.entry:
A"pex
Apex of the earth's motion Astron that point of the heavens toward which the earth is moving in its orbit.
n.; pl. E. Apexes; L. Apices. L
The tip, top, point, or angular summit of anything; as, the apex of a mountain, spire, or cone; the apex, or tip, of a leaf.
Mining The end or edge of a vein nearest the surface. U.S

entry.def: Same as Apheresis.

Pertaining to aphakia; as, aphakial eyes.

A very compact, dark-colored �ock, consisting of hornblende, or pyroxene, and feldspar, but neither of them in perceptible grains.
Resembling aphanite; having a very fine-grained structure.

entry.ety: NL. aphasia, Gr. �, fr. � not spoken; 'a priv. + � to speak: cf. F. aphasie
entry.def: Loss of the power of speech, or of the appropriate use of words, the vocal organs remaining intact, and the intelligence being preserved. It is dependent on injury or disease of the brain.
Pertaining to, or affected by, aphasia; speechless.

sn.def: one of two subgroups of Nematoda used in some classification systems.

entries.entry: A*phel"ion ?; 277 n.; pl.Aphelia. Gr. � + � sun Astron That point of a planet's or comet's orbit which is most distant from the sun, the opposite point being the perihelion.

Loss of the power of speaking, while retaining the power of writing; -- a disorder of cerebral origin.

entry.ety: L. aphaeresis, Gr. �, fr. � to take away; � + � to take

An operation by which any part is separated from the rest.

entry.ety: Gr. � a letting go; � + � to let go

entry.ety: Gr. � letting go, fr. � to let go

An aphetized form of a word.
To shorten by aphesis.
entry.q: These words . . . have been aphetized.

entry.def: One of the genus Aphis; an aphidian.
See Aphis.
Of or pertaining to the family Aphidæ.

def2.def: One of the aphides; an aphid.

entries.entry: Aph`i*div"o*rous. Aphis + L. vorare to devour Zoöl Devouring aphides; aphidophagous.

entry.def: Feeding upon aphides, or plant lice, as do beetles of the family Coccinellidæ.

entry.ety: Gr. � not loving man; 'a priv. + � to love + � man
entry.def: Want of love to mankind; -- the opposite of philanthropy.

entries.entry: A"phis A"phis ☞ Besides the true males and females, there is a race of wingless asexual individuals which have the power of producing living young in rapid succession, and these in turn may produce others of the same kind for several generations, before sexual individuals appear. They suck the sap of plants by means of a tubular proboscis, and owing to the wonderful rapidity of their reproduction become very destructive to vegetation. Many of the Aphidæ excrete honeydew from two tubes near the end of the body. n.; pl.Aphides. NL Zoöl A genus of insects belonging to the order Hemiptera and family Aphidæ, including numerous species known as plant lice and green flies.
A"phis li"on. Zoöl The larva of the lacewinged flies (Chrysopa), which feeds voraciously upon aphids. The name is also applied to the larvæ of the ladybugs (Coccinella).

entry.ety: Gr. � not inflammable; 'a priv. + � set on fire. See Phlogiston
entry.def: Flameless; as, an aphlogistic lamp, in which a coil of wire is kept in a state of continued ignition by alcohol, without flame.

entry.ety: NL. aphonia, Gr. �, fr. � voiceless; 'a priv. + � voice: cf. F. aphonie
entry.def: Loss of voice or vocal utterance.
Without voice; voiceless; nonvocal; incapable of all but whispered speech.

entry.ety: F. aphorisme, fr. Gr. � definition, a short, pithy sentence, fr. � to mark off by boundaries, to define; � from + � to separate, part. See Horizon
entry.def: A comprehensive maxim or principle expressed in a few words; a sharply defined sentence relating to abstract truth rather than to practical matters.
entry.q: The first aphorism of Hippocrates is, “Life is short, and the art is long.”
entry.syn: Axiom; maxim; adage; proverb; apothegm; saying; saw; truism; dictum. See Axiom.

entry.def: Pertaining to aphorisms, or having the form of an aphorism.
A dealer in aphorisms.
A writer or utterer of aphorisms.
In the form of, or of the nature of, an aphorism; in the form of short, unconnected sentences; as, an aphoristic style.
entry.q: The method of the book is aphoristic.

entry.def: In the form or manner of aphorisms; pithily.
To make aphorisms.
Without light.

entries.entry: Aphotic region. Phytogeog A depth of water so great that only those organisms can exist that do not assimilate.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'a priv. + fra`sis speech
entry.def: = Dumbness.
A disorder of speech in which words can be uttered but not intelligibly joined together.
See under Calcite.

entry.ety: Gr. � pertaining to sensual love, fr. �. See Aphrodite
entry.def: Exciting venereal desire; stimulating the desire for sexual gratification.
That which (as a drug, or some kinds of food) stimulate sexual desire.
Pertaining to Aphrodite or Venus. “Aphrodisian dames” [that is, courtesans].

sn.def: The Greek goddess of love, corresponding to the Venus of the Romans.

A beautiful butterfly (Argunnis Aphrodite) of the United States.

entry.def: Venereal.

The disease, also called thrush.

entry.def: Roundish pearl-colored specks or flakes in the mouth, on the lips, etc., terminating in white sloughs. They are commonly characteristic of thrush.
Of the nature of aphthæ; resembling thrush.

entry.ety: Gr. � silent; 'a priv. + � voice, sound, fr. � to sound
entry.def: A letter, or a combination of letters, employed in spelling a word, but in the pronunciation having no sound.

Destitute of leaves, as the broom rape, certain euphorbiaceous plants, etc.

sn.def: a family of plants bearing flowers in umbels; examples are: parsley; carrot; anise; caraway; celery; dill.
sn.syn: Umbelliferae, family Umbelliferae, family Apiaceae, carrot family

entry.def: Umbelliferous.
Belonging to bees.
Of or relating to bees.
One who keeps an apiary.
A place where bees are kept; a stand or shed for bees; a beehouse.

entry.ety: L. apex apicis, tip or summit
entry.def: At or belonging to an apex, tip, or summit.
See Apex.
Belonging to Apicius, a notorious Roman epicure; hence applied to whatever is peculiarly refined or dainty and expensive in cookery.

entry.ety: NL. apiculus, dim. of L. apex apicis
entry.def: Situated at, or near, the apex; apical.
Terminated abruptly by a small, distinct point, as a leaf.
Rearing of bees for their honey and wax.

sn.def: a farmer who keeps bees for their honey.
a family of insects comprising the bees; examples are: honeybees; carpenter bees; bumblebees.

entry.def: Each by itself; by the single one; to each; as the share of each; as, these melons cost a shilling apiece .
entry.q: Fined . . . a thousand poundsapiece.

entry.def: In pieces or to pieces.
entry.q: Being tornapieces.

entry.def: Trimmed.
entry.q: Full fresh and new here gear apiked was.

entry.def: An oily liquid derived from parsley.
A student of bees.
The scientific or systematic study of honey bees.
A genus of insects of the order Hymenoptera, including the common honeybee (Apis mellifica) and other related species. See Honeybee.
Having the qualities of an ape; prone to imitate in a servile manner. Hence: Apelike; fantastically silly; foppish; affected; trifling.
entry.q: The apish gallantry of a fantastic boy.

entry.def: In an apish manner; with servile imitation; foppishly.
The quality of being apish; mimicry; foppery.
With quick beating or palpitation; pitapat.

sn.def: feeding on bees; bee-eating.

entry.def: Belonging to the Aplacentata; without placenta.
Mammals which have no placenta.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'a priv. + � a flat cake + fe`rein to bear

sn.def: one of the aplacophora; a deep-water wormlike mollusk lacking calcareous plates on the body but having fine limy spicules on the covering mantle.

entry.cs: Aplanatic focus of a lens Opt the point or focus from which rays diverging pass the lens without spherical aberration. In certain forms of lenses there are two such foci; and it is by taking advantage of this fact that the best aplanatic object glasses of microscopes are constructed.
entry.ety: Gr. 'a priv. + � disposed to wander, wandering, � to wander
entry.def: Having two or more parts of different curvatures, so combined as to remove spherical aberration; -- said of a lens.
Freedom from spherical aberration.
A nonmotile gamete, found in certain lower algæ.

sn.def: Incomplete or faulty development.
a defect, retardation, or cessation of the process of generation of blood cells.

entry.def: Not plastic or easily molded.
an anemia characterized by substantial reduction or cessation of production of red blood cells and hemoglobin by the bone marrow.

sn.def: light-colored and fine-grained granitic rock consisting chiefly of quartz and feldspars.
of or pertaining to an aplite.
the type genus of the family Aplodontiidae, comprising the mountain beavers.
a family of mammals comprising the mountain beavers.

entry.ety: F., lit. perpendicularity; � to + plomb lead. See Plumb
entry.def: Assurance of manner or of action; self-possession.
Simple incision.
An ornamental appendage of wood at the ship's stern, usually spreading like a fan and curved like a bird's feather.

entry.ety: Gr. � a dirty sponge, fr. � unwashed; 'a priv. + � to wash
entry.def: A genus of marine mollusks of the order Tectibranchiata; the sea hare. Some of the species when disturbed throw out a deep purple liquor, which colors the water to some distance. See Illust. in Appendix.

sn.def: transient cessation of respiration.
of or pertaining to apnea.

entry.def: Devoid of air; free from air; as, an apneumatic lung; also, effected by or with exclusion of air; as, an apneumatic operation.

entry.def: An order of holothurians in which the internal respiratory organs are wanting; -- called also Apoda or Apodes.
