entry.def: Approved.

entry.note: ☞ This word is obsolete in England, but is occasionally heard in the United States, chiefly in a technical sense for license; as, a person is approbated to preach; approbated to keep a public house.
entry.def: To express approbation of; to approve; to sanction officially.
entry.q: I approbate the one, I reprobate the other.

entry.usage: Approbation Approval. Approbation and approval have the same general meaning, assenting to or declaring as good, sanction, commendation; but approbation is stronger and more positive. “We may be anxious for the approbation of our friends; but we should be still more anxious for the approval of our own consciences.” “He who is desirous to obtain universal approbation will learn a good lesson from the fable of the old man and his ass.” “The work has been examined by several excellent judges, who have expressed their unqualified approval of its plan and execution.”
entry.ety: L. approbatio: cf. F. approbation. See Approve to prove

sn.def: Proof; attestation.
The act of approving; an assenting to the propriety of a thing with some degree of pleasure or satisfaction; approval; sanction; commendation.
sn.q: Many . . . joined in a loud hum of approbation.
The silent approbation of one's own breast.
Animals . . . love approbation or praise.

sn.def: Probation or novitiate.
sn.q: This day my sister should the cloister enter, And there receive her approbation.

entry.def: Approving, or implying approbation.

sn.def: The quality of being approbative.
Love of approbation.

entry.def: One who approves.
Containing or expressing approbation; commendatory.
To quicken; to prompt.
entry.q: To appromt our invention.

sn.def: Trial; proof.
Approval; commendation.

entry.ety: L. appropinquatus, p. p. of appropinquare; ad + prope near
entry.def: To approach.
A drawing nigh; approach.
Nearness; propinquity.

entry.ety: OE. appropren apropren, OF. approprier, fr. L. appropriare. See Appropriate
entry.def: To appropriate.
Capable of being appropriated, set apart, sequestered, or assigned exclusively to a particular use.
What is peculiarly one's own; peculiar qualification.
entry.q: If you can neglect Your own appropriaments.

entry.ety: L. appropriatus, p. p. of appropriare; ad + propriare to appropriate, fr. proprius one's own, proper. See Proper
entry.def: Set apart for a particular use or person. Hence: Belonging peculiarly; peculiar; suitable; fit; proper.
entry.q: In its strict and appropriate meaning.
Appropriate acts of divine worship.
It is not at all times easy to find words appropriate to express our ideas.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Appropriated; p. pr. & vb. n. Appropriating

sn.def: To take to one's self in exclusion of others; to claim or use as by an exclusive right; as, let no man appropriate the use of a common benefit.

To set apart for, or assign to, a particular person or use, in exclusion of all others; -- with to or for; as, a spot of ground is appropriated for a garden; to appropriate money for the increase of the navy.
To make suitable; to suit.
To annex, as a benefice, to a spiritual corporation, as its property.

entry.def: A property; attribute.

sn.def: taken without permission or consent especially by public authority.

entry.def: In an appropriate or proper manner; fitly; properly.
The state or quality of being appropriate; peculiar fitness.

sn.def: The act of setting apart or assigning to a particular use or person, or of taking to one's self, in exclusion of all others; application to a special use or purpose, as of a piece of ground for a park, or of money to carry out some object.
Anything, especially money, thus set apart.
sn.q: The Commons watched carefully over the appropriation.

sd.def: The severing or sequestering of a benefice to the perpetual use of a spiritual corporation. Blackstone.
The application of payment of money by a debtor to his creditor, to one of several debts which are due from the former to the latter.

entry.def: Appropriating; making, or tending to, appropriation; as, an appropriative act.

sn.def: One who appropriates.
A spiritual corporation possessed of an appropriated benefice; also, an impropriator.

entry.def: Worthy of being approved; meritorious.
Approbation; sanction.
entry.q: A censor . . . without whose approval n� capital sentences are to be executed.

entry.def: Approval.

entry.note: ☞ This word, when it signifies to be pleased with to think favorably of), is often followed by of.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Approved; p. pr. & vb. n. Approving
entry.ety: OE. aproven appreven, to prove, OF. aprover, F. approuver, to approve, fr. L. approbare; ad + probare to esteem as good, approve, prove. See Prove, and cf. Approbate

sn.def: To show to be real or true; to prove.
sn.q: Wouldst thou approve thy constancy? Approve First thy obedience.

sn.def: To make proof of; to demonstrate; to prove or show practically.
sn.q: Opportunities to approve . . . worth.
He had approved himself a great warrior.
'T is an old lesson; Time approves it true.
His account . . . approves him a man of thought.

sn.def: To sanction officially; to ratify; to confirm; as, to approve the decision of a court-martial.
To regard as good; to commend; to be pleased with; to think well of; as, we approve the measured of the administration.
To make or show to be worthy of approbation or acceptance.
sn.q: The first care and concern must be to approve himself to God.
They had not approved of the deposition of James.
They approved of the political institutions.

entry.ety: OF. aprouer; aL. ad) + a form apparently derived fr. the pro prod, in L. prodest it is useful or profitable, properly the preposition pro for. Cf. Improve
entry.def: To make profit of; to convert to one's own profit; -- said esp. of waste or common land appropriated by the lord of the manor.
So as to secure approbation; in an approved manner.

sn.def: Approbation.
sn.q: I did nothing without your approvement.

sn.def: a confession of guilt by a prisoner charged with treason or felony, together with an accusation of his accomplish and a giving evidence against them in order to obtain his own pardon. The term is no longer in use; it corresponded to what is now known as turning king'sor queen's evidence in England, and state's evidence in the United States.

entry.def: Improvement of common lands, by inclosing and converting them to the uses of husbandry for the advantage of the lord of the manor.

sn.def: One who approves. Formerly, one who made proof or trial.
An informer; an accuser.
One who confesses a crime and accuses another. See 1st Approvement, 2.

entry.def: A bailiff or steward; an agent.
Expressing approbation; commending; as, an approving smile.

cs.cd: those which are nearly, but not, equal.

entry.ety: L. approximatus, p. p. of approximare to approach; ad + proximare to come near. See Proximate

sn.def: Approaching; proximate; nearly resembling.
Near correctness; nearly exact; not perfectly accurate; as, approximate results or values.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Approximated; p. pr. & vb. n. Approximating

sn.def: To carry or advance near; to cause to approach.
sn.q: To approximate the inequality of riches to the level of nature.

sn.def: To come near to; to approach.
sn.q: The telescope approximates perfection.

entry.def: To draw; to approach.
With approximation; so as to approximate; nearly.

entries.entry:
Ap*prox`i*ma"tion. n. Cf. F. approximation, LL. approximatio
The act of approximating; a drawing, advancing or being near; approach; also, the result of approximating. The largest capacity and the most noble dispositions are but an approximation to the proper standard and true symmetry of human nature.
An approach to a correct estimate, calculation, or conception, or to a given quantity, quality, etc.
Math
A continual approach or coming nearer to a result; as, to solve an equation by approximation .
A value that is nearly but not exactly correct.

entry.def: Approaching; approximate.
One who, or that which, approximates.

entry.cs: Point d'appui. F., a point of support Mil A given point or body, upon which troops are formed, or by which are marched in line or column. An advantageous defensive support, as a castle, morass, wood, declivity, etc. any point of support or basis of operations, as a rallying point.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. ad + podium foothold, Gr. �, dim. of �, �, foot

sn.def: A support or supporter; a stay; a prop.
sn.q: If a vine be to climb trees that are of any great height, there would be stays and appuies set to it.

sn.def: The mutual bearing or support of the hand of the rider and the mouth of the horse through the bit and bridle.

entry.ety: L. appulsus, fr. appellere appulsum, to drive to; ad + pellere to drive: cf. F. appulse

sn.def: A driving or running towards; approach; impulse; also, the act of striking against.
sn.q: In all consonants there is an appulse of the organs.

sn.def: The near approach of one heavenly body to another, or to the meridian; a coming into conjunction; as, the appulse of the moon to a star, or of a star to the meridian.

entry.def: A driving or striking against; an appulse.
Striking against; impinging; as, the appulsive influence of the planets.
By appulsion.

entry.ety: OF. apurtenaunce apartenance, F. appartenance, LL. appartenentia, from L. appertinere. See Appertain
entry.def: That which belongs to something else; an adjunct; an appendage; an accessory; something annexed to another thing more worthy; in common parlance and legal acceptation, something belonging to another thing as principal, and which passes as incident to it, as a right of way, or other easement to land; a right of common to pasture, an outhouse, barn, garden, or orchard, to a house or messuage. In a strict legal sense, land can never pass as an appurtenance to land.
entry.q: Globes . . . provided as appurtenances to astronomy.
The structure of the eye, and of its appurtenances.

sn.def: miscellaneous articles needed for a particular operation or sport etc.

entry.cs: Common appurtenant. Law See under Common, n.
entry.ety: F. appartenant, p. pr. of appartenir. See Appurtenance
entry.def: Annexed or pertaining to some more important thing; accessory; incident; as, a right of way appurtenant to land or buildings.
Something which belongs or appertains to another thing; an appurtenance.
entry.q: Mysterious appurtenants and symbols of redemption.

sn.def: having uncoordinated muscular movements, symptomatic of a CNS disorder; suffering from apraxia.
inability to make purposeful movements, but without paralysis or loss of sensory function.
having uncoordinated muscular movements, symptomatic of a CNS disorder.
concerned with or designed for use after skiing; occurring after a day of skiing; as, apres-ski wear; an apres-ski party.
the time after skiing.

entry.ety: L. apricatus, p. p. of apricare, fr. apricus exposed to the sun, fr. aperire to uncover, open
entry.def: To bask in the sun.
Basking in the sun.

entry.ety: OE. apricock abricot, F. abricot, fr. Sp. albaricoque or Pg. albricoque, fr. Ar. albirqūq al-burqūq. Though the E. and F. form abricot is derived from the Arabic through the Spanish, yet the Arabic word itself was formed from the Gr. praiko`kia, pl. (Diosc. c. 100) fr. L. praecoquus praecox, early ripe. The older E. form apricock was prob. taken direct from Pg. See Precocious Cook
entry.def: A fruit allied to the plum, of an orange color, oval shape, and delicious taste; also, the tree (Prunus Armeniaca of Linnæus) which bears this fruit. By cultivation it has been introduced throughout the temperate zone.

cs.cd: one who is sportively imposed upon by others on the first day of April.

entry.ety: L. Aprilis. OE. also Averil, F. Avril, fr. L. Aprilis

sn.def: The fourth month of the year.
Fig.: With reference to April being the month in which vegetation begins to put forth, the variableness of its weather, etc.
sn.q: The April's her eyes; it is love's spring.

entries.entry:
A` pri*o"ri A` pri*o"ri. L. a ab) + prior former
Logic Characterizing that kind of reasoning which deduces consequences from definitions formed, or principles assumed, or which infers effects from causes previously known; deductive or deductively. The reverse of a posteriori.
Philos Applied to knowledge and conceptions assumed, or presupposed, as prior to experience, in order to make experience rational or possible.
A priori, that is, form these necessities of the mind or forms of thinking, which, though first revealed to us by experience, must yet have preëxisted in order to make experience possible.

entry.def: An a priori principle.
The quality of being innate in the mind, or prior to experience; a priori reasoning.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'a priv. + prwkto`s anus
entry.def: A group of Turbellaria in which there is no anal aperture.
Without an anal orifice.

entry.ety: OE. napron, OF. naperon, F. napperon, dim. of OF. nape, F. nappe, cloth, tablecloth, LL. napa, fr. L. mappa, napkin, table napkin. See Map

sn.def: An article of dress, of cloth, leather, or other stuff, worn on the fore part of the body, to keep the clothes clean, to defend them from injury, or as a covering. It is commonly tied at the waist by strings.
Something which by its shape or use suggests an apron;

sd.def: The fat skin covering the belly of a goose or duck.
A piece of leather, or other material, to be spread before a person riding on an outside seat of a vehicle, to defend him from the rain, snow, or dust; a boot.
sd.q: The weather being too hot for theapron.

sd.def: A leaden plate that covers the vent of a cannon.

sn.sd: Shipbuilding A piece of carved timber, just above the foremost end of the keel. Totten.

sd.def: A platform, or flooring of plank, at the entrance of a dock, against which the dock gates are shut.
A flooring of plank before a dam to cause the water to make a gradual descent.
The piece that holds the cutting tool of a planer.
A strip of lead which leads the drip of a wall into a gutter; a flashing.
The infolded abdomen of a crab.

entry.def: Wearing an apron.
entry.q: A cobbler aproned, and a parson gowned.

entries.entry: A"pron*ful n.; pl.Apronfuls. The quantity an apron can hold.

entry.def: Without an apron.

entries.entry: A"pron man`. A man who wears an apron; a laboring man; a mechanic. Obs

A"pron string`
To be tied to a wife's apron stringsorTo be tied to a mother's apron strings
to be unduly controlled by a wife or mother. . The string of an apron. He was so made that he could not submit to be tied to the apron strings even of the best of wives.

entry.ety: F. à propos; àL. ad) + propos purpose, L. proposium plan, purpose, fr. proponere to propose. See Propound

sn.def: Opportunely or opportune; seasonably or seasonable.
sn.q: A tale extremely apropos.

sn.def: By the way; to the purpose; suitably to the place or subject; -- a word used to introduce an incidental observation, suited to the occasion, though not strictly belonging to the narration.

entries.entry:
Apse ☞ This word is also written apsis and absis. ăps n.; pl. Apses ăp"sĕz. [See Apsis
Arch
A projecting part of a building, esp. of a church, having in the plan a polygonal or semicircular termination, and, most often, projecting from the east end. In early churches the Eastern apse was occupied by seats for the bishop and clergy. Hence:
The bishop's seat or throne, in ancient churches.
A reliquary, or case in which the relics of saints were kept.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the apsides of an orbit.
Of or pertaining to the apse of a church; as, the apsidal termination of the chancel.

entry.def: See Apsis.

entries.entry:
Ap"sis Ap"sis ăp"sĭs n.; pl.Apsides ăp"sĭ*dēz. See Apse. L. apsis absis, Gr. "apsi`s "apsi^dos, a tying, fastening, the hoop of a wheel, the wheel, a bow, arch, vault, fr. "a`ptein to fasten
Astron One of the two points of an orbit, as of a planet or satellite, which are at the greatest and least distance from the central body, corresponding to the aphelion and perihelion of a planet, or to the apogee and perigee of the moon. The more distant is called the higher apsis; the other, the lower apsis; and the line joining them, the line of apsides.
Math In a curve referred to polar coördinates, any point for which the radius vector is a maximum or minimum.
Arch Same as Apse.

entry.def: father of the gods and consort of Tiamat.

sn.def: a ratite bird order: flightless ground birds having vestigial wings and long bills and small eyes: kiwis.

entry.ety: F. apte, L. aptus, fr. obsolete apere to fasten, to join, to fit, akin to apisci to reach, attain: cf. Gr. � to fasten, Skr. āpta fit, fr. āp to reach attain

sn.def: Fit or fitted; suited; suitable; appropriate.
sn.q: They have always apt instruments.
A river . . . apt to be forded by a lamb.

sn.def: Having an habitual tendency; habitually liable or likely; -- used of things.
sn.q: My vines and peaches . . . were apt to have a soot or smuttiness upon their leaves and fruit.
This tree, if unprotected, is apt to be stripped of the leaves by a leaf-cutting ant.

sn.def: Inclined; disposed customarily; given; ready; -- used of persons.
sn.q: Apter to give than thou wit be to ask.
That lofty pity with which prosperous folk are apt to remember their grandfathers.

sn.def: Ready; especially fitted or qualified (to do something); quick to learn; prompt; expert; as, a pupil apt to learn; an apt scholar.
sn.q: Anaptwit.
Live a thousand years, I shall not find myself so apt to die.
I find thee apt . . . Now, Hamlet, hear.
sn.syn: Fit; meet; suitable; qualified; inclined; disposed; liable; ready; quick; prompt.

entry.def: To fit; to suit; to adapt.
entry.q: Toapttheir places.
That our speech be apted to edification.

entry.def: Capable of being adapted.

entry.ety: L. aptatus, p. p. of aptare. See Apt
entry.def: To make fit.

entry.ety: NL. aptera, fr. Gr. � without wings; 'a priv. + � wing, � to fly
entry.def: Insects without wings, constituting the seventh Linnæn order of insects, an artificial group, which included Crustacea, spiders, centipeds, and even worms. These animals are now placed in several distinct classes and orders.

sn.def: Apterous.
Without lateral columns; -- applied to buildings which have no series of columns along their sides, but are either prostyle or amphiprostyle, and opposed to peripteral.

entry.def: One of the Aptera.
Naked spaces between the feathered areas of birds. See Pteryliæ.

sn.def: Destitute of wings; apteral; as, apterous insects.
Destitute of winglike membranous expansions, as a stem or petiole; -- opposed to alate.

entry.def: An order of birds, including the genus Apteryx.

entry.ety: Gr. 'a priv. + pte`ryx wing. Cf. Aptera
entry.def: A genus of New Zealand birds about the size of a hen, with only short rudiments of wings, armed with a claw and without a tail; the kiwi. It is allied to the gigantic extinct moas of the same country. Five species are known.

entry.ety: F. aptitude, LL. aptitudo, fr. L. aptus. See Apt, and cf. Attitude

sn.def: A natural or acquired disposition or capacity for a particular purpose, or tendency to a particular action or effect; as, oil has an aptitude to burn.
sn.q: He seems to have had a peculiar aptitude for the management of irregular troops.

sn.def: A general fitness or suitableness; adaptation.
sn.q: That sociable and helpful aptitude which God implanted between man and woman.

sn.def: Readiness in learning; docility; aptness.
sn.q: He was a boy of remarkable aptitude.

entry.def: Suitable; fit.
In an apt or suitable manner; fitly; properly; pertinently; appropriately; readily.

sn.def: Fitness; suitableness; appropriateness; as, the aptness of things to their end.
sn.q: The aptness of his quotations.

sn.def: Disposition of the mind; propensity; as, the aptness of men to follow example.
Quickness of apprehension; readiness in learning; docility; as, an aptness to learn is more observable in some children than in others.
Proneness; tendency; as, the aptness of iron to rust.

entry.ety: L. aptotum, Gr. � indeclinable; 'a priv. + � fallen, declined, � to fall
entry.def: A noun which has no distinction of cases; an indeclinable noun.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, aptotes; uninflected; as, aptotic languages.
A shelly plate found in the terminal chambers of ammonite shells. Some authors consider them to be jaws; others, opercula.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �. See Apode n.
entry.def: A genus of fresh-water phyllopod crustaceans. See Phyllopod.
Without fever; -- applied to days when there is an intermission of fever.

entry.ety: NL. apyrexia, fr. Gr. �; 'a priv. + � to be feverish, fr. � fire: cf. F. apyrexie
entry.def: The absence or intermission of fever.
Relating to apyrexy.
entry.q: Apyrexialperiod.

entry.def: Incombustible; capable of sustaining a strong heat without alteration of form or properties.

entry.cs:
Aqua ammoniæ the aqueous solution of ammonia; liquid ammonia; often called aqua ammonia.
Aqua marine, or Aqua marina . Same as Aquamarine. Aqua regia. L., royal water Chem a very corrosive fuming yellow liquid consisting of nitric and hydrochloric acids. It has the power of dissolving gold, the “royal” metal. Aqua Tofana a fluid containing arsenic, and used for secret poisoning, made by an Italian woman named Tofana, in the middle of the 17th century, who is said to have poisoned more than 600 persons. Francis.Aqua vitæ L., water of life. Cf. Eau de vie Usquebaugh
a name given to brandy and some other ardent spirits. Shak.
entry.def: Water; -- a word much used in pharmacy and the old chemistry, in various signification, determined by the word or words annexed.

sn.def: of or pertaining to aquiculture.

the cultivation of aquatic animals, such as fish or shellfish, or of plants, such as seaweed, in a controlled and sometimes enclosed body of water. The term includes use of either salt or fresh water. It is a form of agriculture, but under water.

entries.entry: A`qua for"tis A`qua for"tis. L., strong water Chem Nitric acid. Archaic

entry.def: an apparatus containing compressed air or other oxygen-gas mixture, permitting a person to breathe under water; -- also called a scuba.
A transparent, pale green variety of beryl, used as a gem. See Beryl.

entry.ety: L. aqua water, + punctura puncture, pungere punctum, to, prick
entry.def: The introduction of water subcutaneously for the relief of pain.

entry.ety: F., fr. Ital acquerello, fr. acqua water, L. aqua
entry.def: A design or painting in thin transparent water colors; also, the mode of painting in such colors.
A painter in thin transparent water colors.
Of or pertaining to an aquarium.

entry.ety: L. (assumedAquarianus, fr. aqua: cf. F. Aquarien. See Aqua
entry.def: One of a sect of Christian in the primitive church who used water instead of wine in the Lord's Supper.

entries.entry:
A*qua"ri*um n.; pl. E. Aquariums, L. Aquaria. L. See Aquarius Ewer
An artificial pond, or a globe or tank (usually with glass sides), in which living specimens of aquatic animals or plants are kept.

entry.ety: L. aquarius, adj., relating to water, and n., a water-carrier, fr. aqua. See Aqua
entry.def: The Water-bearer; the eleventh sign in the zodiac, which the sun enters about the 20th of January; -- so called from the rains which prevail at that season in Italy and the East.
A constellation south of Pegasus.

entry.ety: L. aquaticus: cf. F. aquatique. See Aqua
entry.def: Pertaining to water; growing in water; living in, swimming in, or frequenting the margins of waters; as, aquatic plants and fowls.

sn.def: An aquatic animal or plant.
Sports or exercises practiced in or on the water.

entry.def: Aquatic.
Inhabiting the water.

entry.ety: It. acquatinta dyed water; acquaL. aqua) water + tinto, fem. tinta, dyed. See Tint
entry.def: A kind of etching in which spaces are bitten by the use of aqua fortis, by which an effect is produced resembling a drawing in water colors or India ink; also, the engraving produced by this method.

sn.def: to etch in aquatint.

entry.note: ☞ The term is also applied to a structure (similar to the ancient aqueducts), for conveying a canal over a river or hollow; more properly called an aqueduct bridge.
entry.ety: F. aqueduc, OF. aqueductCotgr.), fr. L. aquaeductus; aquae, gen. of aqua water + ductus a leading, ducere to lead. See Aqua Duke

sn.def: A conductor, conduit, or artificial channel for conveying water, especially one for supplying large cities with water.
A canal or passage; as, the aqueduct of Sylvius, a channel connecting the third and fourth ventricles of the brain.
a Scandinavian liquor usually flavored with caroway seeds; -- also called akvavit.

entry.def: Wateriness.

cs.cd: an extract obtained from a vegetable substance by steeping it in water.
one the humors of the eye; a limpid fluid, occupying the space between the crystalline lens and the cornea. (See Eye
those which are deposited from water and lie in strata, as opposed to volcanic rocks, which are of igneous origin; -- called also sedimentary rocks.

entry.ety: Cf. F. aqueux, L. aquosus, fr. aqua. See Aqua Aquose

sn.def: Partaking of the nature of water, or abounding with it; watery.
sn.q: The aqueous vapor of the air.

sn.def: Made from, or by means of, water.
sn.q: An aqueous deposit.

entry.def: Wateriness.

sn.def: an underground bed or layer yielding ground water for wells and springs etc.; as, the Oglala aquifer . The water contained in an aquifer may be of great age, and in such cases is sometimes called fossil water.

entry.def: Consisting or conveying water or a watery fluid; as, aquiferous vessels; the aquiferous system.

sn.def: a family of widely distributed shrubs and trees.
a plant of the genus Aquilegia having irregular showy spurred flowers; N temperate regions esp. mountains.
a plant of the genus Aquilegia having irregular showy spurred flowers; N temperate regions esp. mountains.

entry.def: Having the form of water.

entries.entry:
Aq"ui*la Aq"ui*la
Aquila alba L., white eagle an alchemical name of calomel. Brande & C.
n.; pl.Aquilæ. L., an eagle
Zoöl A genus of eagles.
Astron A northern constellation southerly from Lyra and Cygnus and preceding the Dolphin; the Eagle.

entry.def: Adorned with eagles' heads.

entry.ety: L. aquilinus, fr. aquila eagle: cf. F. aquilin. See Eagle.

sn.def: Belonging to or like an eagle.
Curving; hooked; prominent, like the beak of an eagle; -- applied particularly to the nose
sn.q: Terribly arched and aquiline his nose.

entry.def: The north wind.

entry.ety: L. aqua water + parere to bring forth
entry.def: Secreting water; -- applied to certain glands.
Of or pertaining to Aquitania, now called Gascony.

entry.ety: L. aquosus watery, fr. aqua. See Aqua Aqueous
entry.def: Watery; aqueous.
The condition of being wet or watery; wateriness.
entry.q: Very little water or aquosity is found in their belly.

entry.def: Ere; before.
The Altar; a southern constellation, south of the tail of the Scorpion.
A name of the great blue and yellow macaw (Ara ararauna), native of South America.

cs.cd: a homeless vagabond in the streets of a city, particularly and outcast boy or girl.
cs.q: The ragged outcasts and street Arabs who are shivering in damp doorways.

entry.ety: Prob. ultimately fr. Heb. arabah a desert, the name employed, in the Old Testament, to denote the valley of the Jordan and Dead Sea. Ar. Arab, Heb. arabi arbi arbim: cf. F. Arabe, L. Arabs, Gr. �
entry.def: One of a swarthy race occupying Arabia, and numerous in Syria, Northern Africa, etc.

entry.ety: Ar. or Turk. 'arabah: cf. Russ. arba
entry.def: A wagon or cart, usually heavy and without springs, and often covered.
entry.q: The araba of the Turks has its sides of latticework to admit the air

entry.note: ☞ It was employed in Roman imperial ornamentation, and appeared, without the animal figures, in Moorish and Arabic decorative art. (See Moresque.) The arabesques of the Renaissance were founded on Greco-Roman work.
entry.ety: F. arabesque, fr. It. arabesco, fr. Arabo Arab
entry.def: A style of ornamentation either painted, inlaid, or carved in low relief. It consists of a pattern in which plants, fruits, foliage, etc., as well as figures of men and animals, real or imaginary, are fantastically interlaced or put together.

sn.def: Arabian.
Relating to, or exhibiting, the style of ornament called arabesque; as, arabesque frescoes.

entry.def: Ornamented in the style of arabesques.

cs.cd: the phenix.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Arabia or its inhabitants.
A native of Arabia; an Arab.

entry.cs:
Arabic numerals or figures
the nine digits, 1, 2, 3, etc., and the cipher 0. Gum arabic. See under Gum.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Arabia or the Arabians.

entry.note: ☞ The Arabic is a Semitic language, allied to the Hebrew. It is very widely diffused, being the language in which all Moslems must read the Koran, and is spoken as a vernacular tongue in Arabia, Syria, and Northern Africa.
entry.def: The language of the Arabians.
Relating to Arabia; Arabic.

sn.def: A carbohydrate, isomeric with cane sugar, contained in gum arabic, from which it is extracted as a white, amorphous substance.
Mucilage, especially that made of gum arabic.

entry.def: A sugar of the composition C5H10O5, obtained from cherry gum by boiling it with dilute sulphuric acid.
An Arabic idiom peculiarly of language.
One well versed in the Arabic language or literature; also, formerly, one who followed the Arabic system of surgery.

entry.ety: F. arable, L. arabilis, fr. arare to plow, akin to Gr. �, E. ear, to plow. See Earable
entry.def: Fit for plowing or tillage; -- hence, often applied to land which has been plowed or tilled.
Arable land; plow land.
The country of Arabia.
Of or pertaining to Aracan, a province of British Burmah.

def2.def: A native or natives of Aracan.

entry.def: A South American bird, of the genus Pleroglossius, allied to the toucans. There are several species.

entry.ety: OE. aracen arasen, OF. arachier esracier, F. arracher, fr. L. exradicare eradicare. The prefix a- is perh. due to L. ab. See Eradicate
entry.def: To tear up by the roots; to draw away.

entry.ety: L. arum a genus of plants, fr. Gr. �
entry.def: Of or pertaining to an order of plants, of which the genus Arum is the type.
An arachnidan.

entry.note: ☞ They have four pairs of legs, no antennæ nor wings, a pair of mandibles, and one pair of maxillæ or palpi. The head is usually consolidated with the thorax. The respiration is either by trancheæ or by pulmonary sacs, or by both. The class includes three principal orders: Araneina , or spiders; Arthrogastra , including scorpions, etc.; and Acarina , or mites and ticks.
entry.def: One of the classes of Arthropoda. See Illustration in Appendix.
One of the Arachnida.
Of or pertaining to the Arachnida.
Pertaining to the arachnidium.
The glandular organ in which the material for the web of spiders is secreted.
Inflammation of the arachnoid membrane.

entry.ety: Gr. � like a cobweb; � spider, spider's web + e'i^dos form

sn.def: Resembling a spider's web; cobweblike.
Pertaining to a thin membrane of the brain and spinal cord, between the dura mater and pia mater.
Covered with, or composed of, soft, loose hairs or fibers, so as to resemble a cobweb; cobwebby.
The arachnoid membrane.
One of the Arachnoidea.

entry.def: Pertaining to the arachnoid membrane; arachnoid.
Same as Arachnida.
Of or pertaining to arachnology.
One who is versed in, or studies, arachnology.
The department of zoölogy which treats of spiders and other Arachnida.

entries.entry: A`ræ*om"e*ter ?; 277. See Areometer.

entry.ety: L. araeostylos, Gr. �; � at intervals + � pillar, column
entry.def: See Intercolumniation.
See Intercolumniation.
Of or pertaining to Aragon, in Spain, or to its inhabitants.

def2.def: A native or natives of Aragon, in Spain.

entry.def: A mineral identical in composition with calcite or carbonate of lime, but differing from it in its crystalline form and some of its physical characters.
A South American monkey, the ursine howler (Mycetes ursinus). See Howler n., 2.
To raise.
Same as Arrack.

sn.def: any of various plants of the genus Aralia; often aromatic plants having compound leaves and small umbellate flowers.
a family of mostly tropical trees and shrubs and lianas: ginseng; hedera.

entry.ety: L. Aramaeus, Gr. �, fr. Heb. Arāmi. e. Highland, a name given to Syria and Mesopotamia
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Syrians and Chaldeans, or to their language; Aramaic.

Pertaining to Aram, or to the territory, inhabitants, language, or literature of Syria and Mesopotamia; Aramæan; -- specifically applied to the northern branch of the Semitic family of languages, including Syriac and Chaldee.
An idiom of the Aramaic.
a genus of common garden spiders.
an order of arthropods constituting the spiders.
See Araneina.
relating to or resembling a spider.
Of or pertaining to the Araneina or spiders.

def2.def: One of the Araneina; a spider.

entry.def: Having the form of a spider.

entry.note: ☞ They have mandibles, modified as poison fangs, leglike palpi, simple eyes, abdomen without segments, and spinnerets for spinning a web. They breathe by pulmonary sacs and tracheæ in the abdomen. See Illustration in Appendix.
entry.def: The order of Arachnida that includes the spiders.
Of the aspect of a spider's web; arachnoid.

entry.ety: L. araneosus, fr. aranea spider, spider's web
entry.def: Cobweblike; extremely thin and delicate, like a cobweb; as, the araneous membrane of the eye. See Arachnoid.

entries.entry: A*ran"go A*ran"go ȧ*răṉ"g� n.; pl.Arangoes -gōz. The native name A bead of rough carnelian. Arangoes were formerly imported from Bombay for use in the African slave trade.

entry.def: A large fresh-water food fish of South America.
The palm (or great black) cockatoo, of Australia (Microglossus aterrimus).

sn.def: Goa powder.
A fabaceous tree of Brazil (Centrolobium robustum) having handsomely striped wood; -- called also zebrawood.

entry.ety: L. aratio, fr. arare to plow
entry.def: Plowing; tillage.
entry.q: Lands are said to be in a state of aration when they are under tillage.

entry.def: Contributing to tillage.

entry.ety: Araucania, a territory south of Chili
entry.def: A genus of tall conifers of the pine family. The species are confined mostly to South America and Australia. The wood cells differ from those of other in having the dots in their lateral surfaces in two or three rows, and the dots of contiguous rows alternating. The seeds are edible.

sn.def: a family of tall evergreen cone-bearing trees of South America and Australia with broad leathery leaves; in some classifications included in the Pinaceae.

entry.def: Relating to, or of the nature of, the Araucaria. The earliest conifers in geological history were mostly Araucarian.

sn.def: small genus of South American evergreen vines.

entry.def: Lord of Annwfn (the other world; land of fairies).
Someone who engages in arbitrage (who purchases securities in one market for immediate resale in another in the hope of profiting from the price differential); shortened form of arbitrageur.

entry.ety: OF. arbaleste, LL. arbalista, for L. arcuballista; arcus bow + ballista a military engine. See Ballista
entry.def: A crossbow, consisting of a steel bow set in a shaft of wood, furnished with a string and a trigger, and a mechanical device for bending the bow. It served to throw arrows, darts, bullets, etc.

entry.ety: OF. arblastere, OF. arbalestier. See Arbalest
entry.def: A crossbowman.

entry.note: ☞ In modern usage, arbitrator is the technical word.
entry.ety: L. arbiter; ar-for ad) + the root of betere to go; hence properly, one who comes up to look on

sn.def: A person appointed, or chosen, by parties to determine a controversy between them.
Any person who has the power of judging and determining, or ordaining, without control; one whose power of deciding and governing is not limited.
sn.q: For Jove is arbiter of both to man.
sn.syn: Arbitrator; umpire; director; referee; controller; ruler; governor.

entry.def: To act as arbiter between.

entry.ety: Cf. F. arbitrable, fr. L. arbitrari. See Arbitrate v. t.
entry.def: Capable of being decided by arbitration; determinable.

entry.ety: F., fr. arbiter to give judgment, L. arbitrari

sn.def: Judgment by an arbiter; authoritative determination.
A traffic in bills of exchange (see Arbitration of Exchange).
the simultaneous or near simultaneous purchase and sale of the same or closely linked securities or commodities in different markets to make a profit on the (often small) differences in price.

entry.def: same as arbitrageur.
someone who engages in arbitrage; i. e. one who purchases securities in one market for immediate resale in another in the hope of profiting from the price differential.
Of or relating to an arbiter or an arbitration.

sn.def: Determination; decision; arbitration.
sn.q: The arbitrament of time.
Gladly at this moment would MacIvor have put their quarrel to personal arbitrament.

sn.def: The award of arbitrators.

entry.def: In an arbitrary manner; by will only; despotically; absolutely.
The quality of being arbitrary; despoticalness; tyranny.
Arbitrary; despotic.

cs.cd: a quantity of function that is introduced into the solution of a problem, and to which any value or form may at will be given, so that the solution may be made to meet special requirements.
one to which any value can be assigned at pleasure.

entry.ety: L. arbitrarius, fr. arbiter: cf. F. arbitraire. See Arbiter

sn.def: Depending on will or discretion; not governed by any fixed rules; as, an arbitrary decision; an arbitrary punishment.
sn.q: It was wholly arbitrary in them to do so.
Rank pretends to fix the value of every one, and is the most arbitrary of all things.

sn.def: Exercised according to one's own will or caprice, and therefore conveying a notion of a tendency to abuse the possession of power.
sn.q: Arbitrary power is most easily established on the ruins of liberty abused licentiousness.

sn.def: Despotic; absolute in power; bound by no law; harsh and unforbearing; tyrannical; as, an arbitrary prince or government.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Arbitrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Arbitrating
entry.ety: L. arbitratus, p. p. of arbitrari to be a hearer or beholder of something, to make a decision, to give judgment, fr. arbiter. See Arbiter

sn.def: To hear and decide, as arbitrators; as, to choose to arbitrate a disputed case.
To decide, or determine generally.
sn.q: There shall your swords and lances arbitrate The swelling difference of your settled hate.

sn.def: To decide; to determine.
To act as arbitrator or judge; as, to arbitrate upon several reports; to arbitrate in disputes among neighbors; to arbitrate between parties to a suit.

entry.note: ☞ This may be done by one person; but it is usual to choose two or three called arbitrators; or for each party to choose one, and these to name a third, who is called the umpire. Their determination is called the award.

cs.cd: a bond which obliges one to abide by the award of an arbitration.

the operation of converting the currency of one country into that of another, or determining the rate of exchange between such countries or currencies. An arbitrated rate is one determined by such arbitration through the medium of one or more intervening currencies.

entry.ety: F. arbitration, L. arbitratio, fr. arbitrari
entry.def: The hearing and determination of a cause between parties in controversy, by a person or persons chosen by the parties.

sn.def: relating to or resulting from arbitration.
of or pertaining to arbitration; relating to or having the authority to arbitrate.

entry.ety: L., fr. arbitrari: cf. F. arbitrateur

sn.def: A person, or one of two or more persons, chosen by parties who have a controversy, to determine their differences. See Arbitration.
One who has the power of deciding or prescribing without control; a ruler; a governor.
sn.q: Though Heaven be shut, And Heaven's high Arbitrators sit secure.
Masters of their own terms and arbitrators of a peace.
sn.syn: Judge; umpire; referee; arbiter. See Judge.

entry.def: A female who arbitrates or judges.
A female arbiter; an arbitratrix.
A crossbow. See Arbalest.

entry.ety: OE. herber herbere, properly a garden of herbs, F. herbier, fr. L. herbarium. See Herb, and cf. Herbarium
entry.def: A kind of latticework formed of, or covered with, vines, branches of trees, or other plants, for shade; a bower.

sn.def: A tree, as distinguished from a shrub.

sd.def: An axle or spindle of a wheel or opinion.
A mandrel in lathe turning.

cs.cd: a day appointed for planting trees and shrubs.

sn.def: abounding in trees.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to trees; arboreal.
One who plants or who prunes trees.

entries.entry: Ar"bor Di*a"næ Ar"bor Di*a"næ. L., the tree of Diana, or silver Chem A precipitation of silver, in a beautiful arborescent form.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a tree, or to trees; of nature of trees.
Attached to, found in or upon, or frequenting, woods or trees; as, arboreal animals.
sn.q: Woodpeckers are eminently arboreal.

entry.def: Furnished with an arbor; lined with trees.
entry.q: Anarborealwalk.

sn.def: Having the form, constitution, or habits, of a proper tree, in distinction from a shrub.
Pertaining to, or growing on, trees; as, arboreous moss.

entry.def: The state of being arborescent; the resemblance to a tree in minerals, or crystallizations, or groups of crystals in that form; as, the arborescence produced by precipitating silver.

entry.ety: L. arborescens, p. pr. of arborescere to become a tree, fr. arbor tree
entry.def: Resembling a tree; becoming woody in stalk; dendritic; having crystallizations disposed like the branches and twigs of a tree.
entry.q: Arborescenthollyhocks.

sn.def: resembling a tree in form and branching structure.
sn.syn: arboreal, arboreous, arborescent, arboriform, dendriform, dendroid, dendroidal, treelike, tree-shaped.

entry.ety: OF. arboret, dim. of arbre tree, L. arbor
entry.def: A small tree or shrub.
entry.q: Among thick-woven arborets, and flowers Imbordered on each bank.

entries.entry: Ar`bo*re"tum Ar`bo*re"tum n.; pl.Arboreta. L., a place grown with trees A place in which a collection of rare trees and shrubs is cultivated for scientific or educational purposes.

entry.def: Relating to trees.
Tree-inhabiting; -- said of certain birds.
Pertaining to arboriculture.

entry.ety: L. arbor tree + cultura. See Culture
entry.def: The cultivation of trees and shrubs, chiefly for timber or for ornamental purposes.
One who cultivates trees.
Treelike in shape.

entry.ety: F. arboriste, fr. L. arbor tree
entry.def: One who makes trees his study, or who is versed in the knowledge of trees.

entry.ety: Cf. F. arborisation, fr. L. arbor tree
entry.def: The appearance or figure of a tree or plant, as in minerals or fossils; a dendrite.
Having a treelike appearance.
entry.q: Anarborizedor moss agate.

entry.def: Formed by trees.
entry.q: From under shady, arborous roof.

entries.entry: Ar"bor vine`. A species of bindweed.

Ar"bor vi"tæ Ar"bor vi"tæ. L., tree of life
Bot An evergreen tree of the cypress tribe, genus Thuja. The American species is the Thuja occidentalis.
Anat The treelike disposition of the gray and white nerve tissues in the cerebellum, as seen in a vertical section.

entry.ety: L. arbuscula small tree, shrub, dim. of arbor tree
entry.def: A dwarf tree, one in size between a shrub and a tree; a treelike shrub.
Of or pertaining to a dwarf tree; shrublike.

entry.ety: L. arbustivus, fr. arbustum place where trees are planted
entry.def: Containing copses of trees or shrubs; covered with shrubs.

cs.cd: a creeping or trailing plant of the Heath family (Epigæa repens), having white or usually rose-colored flowers with a delicate fragrance, growing in small axillary clusters, and appearing early in the spring; in New England known as mayflower; -- called also ground laurel.

entry.ety: L. arbutus, akin to arbor tree
entry.def: The strawberry tree, a genus of evergreen shrubs, of the Heath family. It has a berry externally resembling the strawberry; the arbute tree.

entry.cs: Electric arc Voltaic arc . See under Voltaic.
entry.ety: F. arc, L. arcus bow, arc. See Arch n.

sn.def: A portion of a curved line; as, the arc of a circle or of an ellipse.
A curvature in the shape of a circular arc or an arch; as, the colored arcthe rainbow); the arc of Hadley's quadrant.
An arch.
sn.q: Statues and trophies, and triumphal arcs.

sn.def: The apparent arc described, above or below the horizon, by the sun or other celestial body. The diurnal arc is described during the daytime, the nocturnal arc during the night.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Arcked ärkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Arcking
entry.def: To form a voltaic arc, as an electrical current in a broken or disconnected circuit.

sn.def: the type genus of the family Arcidae, including ark shells and blood clams.

entry.ety: F. arcade, Sp. arcada, LL. arcata, fr. L. arcus bow, arch

sd.def: A series of arches with the columns or piers which support them, the spandrels above, and other necessary appurtenances; sometimes open, serving as an entrance or to give light; sometimes closed at the back (as in the cut) and forming a decorative feature.
A long, arched building or gallery.

sn.def: An arched or covered passageway or avenue.

entry.def: Furnished with an arcade.

sn.def: A mountainous and picturesque district of Greece, in the heart of the Peloponnesus, whose people were distinguished for contentment and rural happiness.
Fig.: Any region or scene of simple pleasure and untroubled quiet.
sn.q: Where the cow is, there is Arcadia.

entry.ety: L. Arcadius Arcadicus, fr. Arcadia: cf. F. Arcadien Arcadique

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Arcadia; pastoral; ideally rural; as, Arcadian simplicity or scenery.
the dialect of Ancient Greek spoken by Arcadians.

entry.def: Hidden; secret.
entry.q: Thearcanepart of divine wisdom.

entries.entry:
Ar*ca"num Ar*ca"num n.; pl.Arcana. L., fr. arcanus closed, secret, fr. arca chest, box, fr. arcere to inclose. See Ark
A secret; a mystery; -- generally used in the plural. Inquiries into the arcana of the Godhead.
Med A secret remedy; an elixir.

entry.def: A buttress that stands apart from the main structure and connected to it by an arch; same as flying buttress.
An amoebalike protozoan with a chitinous shell resembling an umbrella.
A natural family of soil and freshwater protozoa; cosmopolitan.
A genus of chiefly American plants parasitic on conifers.

entry.note: ☞ Scientifically considered, the arch is a means of spanning an opening by resolving vertical pressure into horizontal or diagonal thrust.

cs.cd: a monumental structure resembling an arched gateway, with one or more passages, erected to commemorate a triumph.

entry.ety: F. arche, fr. LL. arca, for arcus. See Arc

sn.def: Any part of a curved line.

sd.def: Usually a curved member made up of separate wedge-shaped solids, with the joints between them disposed in the direction of the radii of the curve; used to support the wall or other weight above an opening. In this sense arches are segmental roundi. e., semicircular), or pointed.
A flat arch is a member constructed of stones cut into wedges or other shapes so as to support each other without rising in a curve.

sn.def: Any place covered by an arch; an archway; as, to pass into the arch of a bridge.
Any curvature in the form of an arch; as, the arch of the aorta.
sn.q: Colors of the showeryarch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Arched ärcht; p. pr. & vb. n. Arching

sn.def: To cover with an arch or arches.
To form or bend into the shape of an arch.
sn.q: The horse arched his neck.

entry.def: To form into an arch; to curve.

entries.entry:
Arch- ärch-, except in archangel and one or two other words. L. arch-, Gr. 'arch- = 'archi-. See Arch-
A prefix signifying chief, as in archbuilder, archfiend.

sn.def: Chief; eminent; greatest; principal.
sn.q: The most arch act of piteous massacre.

sn.def: Cunning or sly; sportively mischievous; roguish; as, an arch look, word, lad.
sn.q: He] spoke his request with so arch a leer.

entry.def: A chief.
entry.q: My worthy arch and patron comes to-night.

entries.entry:
-arch. Gr. 'archo`s chief, commander, 'a`rchein to rule. See Arch a.
A suffix meaning a ruler, as in monarcha sole ruler).

entry.def: Ancient; pertaining to the earliest period in geological history.

entry.note: ☞ This is equivalent to the formerly accepted term Azoic, and to the Eozoic of Dawson.
entry.def: The earliest period in geological period, extending up to the Lower Silurian. It includes an Azoic age, previous to the appearance of life, and an Eozoic age, including the earliest forms of life.
A description of, or a treatise on, antiquity or antiquities.

entry.ety: Gr. 'archai^os ancient + liqiko`s pertaining to a stone
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the earliest Stone age; -- applied to a prehistoric period preceding the Paleolithic age.
An archæologist.
Relating to archæology, or antiquities; as, archæological researches.
One versed in archæology; an antiquary.

entry.ety: Gr. 'archaiologi`a; 'archai^os ancient (fr. 'archh` beginning) + lo`gos discourse, le`gein to speak
entry.def: The science or study of antiquities, esp. prehistoric antiquities, such as the remains of buildings or monuments of an early epoch, inscriptions, implements, and other relics, written manuscripts, etc.
A fossil bird, of the Jurassic period, remarkable for having a long tapering tail of many vertebræ with feathers along each side, and jaws armed with teeth, with other reptilian characteristics.

sn.def: an extinct primitive toothed bird with a long feathered tail and three free clawed digits on each wing.
a subclass of primitive reptilelike fossil birds of the Jurassic or early Cretaceous.

entry.def: Applied to a gastrula when the blastopore does not entirely close up.
Like or belonging to the earliest forms of animal life.

sn.def: formed in or belonging to the earlier of two divisions of the Precambrian era.

entry.def: the time from 1.5 billion to 5 billion years ago; the time when the earth's crust formed; a time when only unicellular organisms and the earliest forms of life are present.
Of or characterized by antiquity or archaism; antiquated; obsolescent.
Archaic.

entry.ety: Gr. 'archai:smo`s, fr. 'archai^os ancient, fr. 'archh` beginning: cf. F. archaïsme. See Arch a.

sn.def: An ancient, antiquated, or old-fashioned, word, expression, or idiom; a word or form of speech no longer in common use.
Antiquity of style or use; obsoleteness.
sn.q: A select vocabulary corresponding (in point of archaism and remoteness from ordinary use) to our Scriptural vocabulary.

sn.def: Am antiquary.
One who uses archaisms.

entry.def: Like, or imitative of, anything archaic; pertaining to an archaism.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Archaized; p. pr. & vb. n. Archaizing
entry.def: To make appear archaic or antique.

entry.ety: L. archangelus, Gr. 'archa`ggelos: cf. OF. archangel, F. archange. See Arch-, pref., and Angel

sn.def: A chief angel; one high in the celestial hierarchy.
A term applied to several different species of plants (Angelica archangelica Lamium album, etc.).

entry.def: Of or pertaining to archangels; of the nature of, or resembling, an archangel.

entry.ety: AS. arcebisceop arcebiscop, L. archiepiscopus, fr. Gr. 'archiepi`skopos. See Bishop
entry.def: A chief bishop; a church dignitary of the first class (often called a metropolitan or primate) who superintends the conduct of the suffragan bishops in his province, and also exercises episcopal authority in his own diocese.
The jurisdiction or office of an archbishop; the see or province over which archbishop exercises archiepiscopal authority.

entries.entry: Arch" brick`. A wedge-shaped brick used in the building of an arch.

entry.def: A chief butler; -- an officer of the German empire.

entry.ety: Cf. G. erzkämmerer. See Arch- pref
entry.def: A chief chamberlain; -- an officer of the old German empire, whose office was similar to that of the great chamberlain in England.

entry.ety: Cf. Ger. erzkanzler. See Arch- pref
entry.def: A chief chancellor; -- an officer in the old German empire, who presided over the secretaries of the court.
Of supreme chemical powers.
entry.q: Thearchchemicsun.

entry.ety: AS. arcediacon archidiacon, L. archidiaconus, fr. Gr. �. See Arch- pref., and Deacon
entry.def: In England, an ecclesiastical dignitary, next in rank below a bishop, whom he assists, and by whom he is appointed, though with independent authority.
The district, office, or residence of an archdeacon. See Benefice.
entry.q: Every diocese is divided into archdeaconries.

entry.def: The office of an archdeacon.
The diocese of an archbishop.
Of or pertaining to an archduke or archduchy.
The consort of an archduke; also, a princess of the imperial family of Austria. See Archduke.
The territory of an archduke or archduchess.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly this title was assumed by the rulers of Lorraine, Brabant, Austria, etc. It is now appropriated to the descendants of the imperial family of Austria through the make line, all such male descendants being styled archduke, and all such female descendants archduchesses.
entry.def: A prince of the imperial family of Austria.
An archduchy.

entry.ety: Pref. arche- = archi- + Gr. bi`wsis bi`os, life
entry.def: The origination of living matter from non-living. See Abiogenesis.
Made with an arch or curve; covered with an arch; as, an arched door.
Relating to the archegonium.

sn.def: of or pertaining to an archegonium.
bearing archegonia.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � the first of a race
entry.def: The pistillidium or female organ in the higher cryptogamic plants, corresponding to the pistil in flowering plants.
Spontaneous generation; abiogenesis.

entry.ety: Gr. � an element or first principle + -logy
entry.def: The science of, or a treatise on, first principles.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. pref. � + � the brain
entry.def: The division that includes man alone.
A principal enemy. Specifically, Satan, the grand adversary of mankind.
Relating to the archenteron; as, archenteric invagination.
The primitive enteron or undifferentiated digestive sac of a gastrula or other embryo. See Illust. under Invagination.

sn.def: of or pertaining to archeology.
related to or dealing with or devoted to archaeology.
an anthropologist who studies prehistoric people and their culture.

entry.def: the branch of anthropology that studies prehistoric people and their cultures. Same as Archæology, etc.

sn.def: an extinct primitive toothed bird (Archaeopteryx lithographica) of the Upper Jurassic having a long feathered tail and hollow bones; usually considered the most primitive of all known birds. Same as archaeopteryx.
same as archaeozoic.
the time from 1.5 billion to 5 billion years ago, when the earth's crust was formed; the time when only unicellular organisms and the earliest forms of life are present. Same as Archaeozoic.
of or pertaining to an archbishop.

entry.ety: archier, F. archer, LL. arcarius, fr. L. arcus bow. See Arc Arch n.
entry.def: A bowman, one skilled in the use of the bow and arrow.
A female archer.

entries.entry: Arch"er fish`. Zoöl A small fish (Toxotes jaculator), of the East Indies; -- so called from its ejecting drops of water from its mouth at its prey. The name is also applied to Chætodon rostratus.

entry.def: The art or skill of an archer.

sn.def: The use of the bow and arrows in battle, hunting, etc.; the art, practice, or skill of shooting with a bow and arrows.
Archers, or bowmen, collectively.
sn.q: Let all our archery fall off In wings of shot a-both sides of the van.

cs.mcol: Court of arches, or Arches Court
cs.cd: the court of appeal of the Archbishop of Canterbury, whereof the judge, who sits as deputy to the archbishop, is called the Dean of the Arches, because he anciently held his court in the church of St. Mary-le-Bow (de arcubus. It is now held in Westminster.

entry.def: pl. of Arch n.
same as archesporium.

sn.def: of or pertaining to an archespore.
a primitive cell or group of cells from which a mother cell develops.

entry.note: ☞ Among Platonists, the archetypal world is the world as it existed as an idea of God before the creation.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to an archetype; consisting a model (real or ideal) or pattern; original.
entry.q: Onearchetypalmind.

entry.def: With reference to the archetype; originally. “Parts archetypally distinct.”

entry.ety: L. archetypum, Gr. 'arche`typon, fr. 'arche`typos stamped first and as model; 'arche = 'archi + ty`pos stamp, figure, pattern, ty`ptein to strike: cf. F. archétype. See Arch- pref

sn.def: The original pattern or model of a work; or the model from which a thing is made or formed.
sn.q: The House of Commons, the archetype of all the representative assemblies which now meet.
Types and shadows of that glorious archetype that was to come into the world.

sn.def: The standard weight or coin by which others are adjusted.
The plan or fundamental structure on which a natural group of animals or plants or their systems of organs are assumed to have been constructed; as, the vertebrate archetype .

entry.def: Relating to an archetype; archetypal.

entry.ety: LL. archēus, Gr. 'archai^os ancient, primeval, fr. 'archh` beginning. See Archi- pref
entry.def: The vital principle or force which (according to the Paracelsians) presides over the growth and continuation of living beings; the anima mundi or plastic power of the old philosophers.

entries.entry:
Ar"chi-. L., archi-, Gr. 'archi-, a prefix which is from the same root as 'a`rchein to be first, to begin; 'archh the first place, beginning; 'archo`s chief. Cf. AS. arce- erce-, OHG. erzi-, G. erz-
A prefix signifying chief arch; as, architect, archiepiscopal. In Biol and Anat it usually means primitive original ancestral; as, archipterygium, the primitive fin or wing.

entry.def: A group of Annelida remarkable for having no external segments or distinct ventral nerve ganglions.

entry.ety: L. archiatrus, Gr. �; pref. � + � physician, � to heal
entry.def: Chief physician; -- a term applied, on the continent of Europe, to the first or body physician of princes and to the first physician of some cities.

entries.entry: Ar"chi*bald wheel. A metal-hubbed wheel of great strength and elasticity, esp. adapted for artillery carriages and motor cars.

entry.def: A hollow blastula, supposed to be the primitive form; a cœloblastula.

entry.ety: Gr. 'archiko`s able to govern, fr. 'archh` beginning, government. See Arch- pref.
entry.def: Chief; primary; primordial.

entry.ety: L. archidiaconus, Gr. �, equiv. to E. archdeacon
entry.def: Of or pertaining to an archdeacon.
entry.q: This offense is liable to be censured in an archidiaconal visitation.

sn.def: That form of episcopacy in which the chief power is in the hands of archbishops.
The state or dignity of an archbishop.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an archbishop; as, Canterbury is an archiepiscopal see.
The station or dignity of an archbishop; archiepiscopacy.
The office of an archbishop; an archbishopric.

entry.ety: Russ. archieréi, fr. Gr. �; pref. � (E. arch-) + ☞ priest
entry.def: The higher order of clergy in Russia, including metropolitans, archbishops, and bishops.

entry.ety: OF. orchel orcheil, It. orcella oricello, or OSp. orchillo. Cf. Orchil

sn.def: A violet dye obtained from several species of lichen (Roccella tinctoria, etc.), which grow on maritime rocks in the Canary and Cape Verd Islands, etc.
The plant from which the dye is obtained.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the satiric Greek poet Archilochus; as, Archilochian meter.

entry.ety: NL.; pref. archi- + L. magus, Gr. �, a Magian

sn.def: The high priest of the Persian Magi, or worshipers of fire.
A great magician, wizard, or enchanter.

entry.ety: L. archimandrita, LGr. �; pref. � (E. arch-) + � an inclosed space, esp. for cattle, a fold, a monastery
entry.def: A chief of a monastery, corresponding to abbot in the Roman Catholic church.
A superintendent of several monasteries, corresponding to superior abbot, or father provincial, in the Roman Catholic church.

cs.cd: an instrument, said to have been invented by Archimedes, for raising water, formed by winding a flexible tube round a cylinder in the form of a screw. When the screw is placed in an inclined position, and the lower end immersed in water, by causing the screw to revolve, the water is raised to the upper end.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Archimedes, a celebrated Greek philosopher; constructed on the principle of Archimedes' screw; as, Archimedean drill, propeller, etc.
An extinct genus of Bryzoa characteristic of the subcarboniferous rocks. Its form is that of a screw.

sn.def: The arched part of a structure.
Hogging; -- opposed to sagging.
the olfactory cortex of the cerebrum.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an archipelago.

entries.entry:
Ar`chi*pel"a*go n.; pl.-goes or -gos. It. arcipelago, properly, chief sea; Gr. pref � + � sea, perh. akin to � blow, and expressing the beating of the waves. See Plague
The Grecian Archipelago, or Ægean Sea, separating Greece from Asia Minor. It is studded with a vast number of small islands.
Hence: Any sea or broad sheet of water interspersed with many islands or with a group of islands.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. pref. 'archi-E. arch-) + ptery`gion wing, fin
entry.def: The primitive form of fin, like that of Ceratodus.

entry.ety: L. architectus architecton, Gr. � chief artificer, master builder; pref. 'archi-E. archi-) + � workman, akin to � art, skill, � to produce: cf. F. architecte, It. architetto. See Technical

sn.def: A person skilled in the art of building; one who understands architecture, or makes it his occupation to form plans and designs of buildings, and to superintend the artificers employed.
A contriver, designer, or maker.
sn.q: The architects of their own happiness.
A French woman is a perfect architect in dress.

entry.def: Used in building; proper for building.

sn.def: Pertaining to a master builder, or to architecture; evincing skill in designing or construction; constructive.
sn.q: Architectonicwisdom.
These architectonic functions which we had hitherto thought belonged.

sn.def: Relating to the systemizing of knowledge.
The science of architecture.
The act of arranging knowledge into a system.

entry.def: The science of architecture.
An architect.
A female architect.
Of or pertaining to the art of building; conformed to the rules of architecture.

cs.cd: the art of fortifications.
the art of building ships.

entry.ety: L. architectura, fr. architectus: cf. F. architecture. See Architect

sn.def: The art or science of building; especially, the art of building houses, churches, bridges, and other structures, for the purposes of civil life; -- often called civil architecture.
sn.q: Many other architectures besides Gothic.

sn.def: Construction, in a more general sense; frame or structure; workmanship.
sn.q: The architecture of grasses, plants, and trees.
The formation of the first earth being a piece of divine architecture.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. pref. � + �, �, a kind of squid
entry.def: A genus of gigantic cephalopods, allied to the squids, found esp. in the North Atlantic and about New Zealand.

entry.ety: F. architrave, fr. It. architrave; pref. archi- + trave beam, L. trabs
entry.def: The lower division of an entablature, or that part which rests immediately on the column, esp. in classical architecture. See Column.
The group of moldings, or other architectural member, above and on both sides of a door or other opening, especially if square in form.
Furnished with an architrave.
Pertaining to, or contained in, archives or records.

entries.entry:
Ar"chive n.; pl.Archives. F. archives, pl., L. archivum archium, fr. Gr. � government house, � � archives, fr. � the first place, government. See Archi- pref
pl. The place in which public records or historic documents are kept. Our words . . . . become records in God's court, and are laid up in his archives as witnesses.
pl. Public records or documents preserved as evidence of facts; as, the archives of a country or family. Rarely used in sing.
Some rotten archive, rummaged out of some seldom explored press. Registers; records; chronicles.

sn.def: a collection of records especially about an institution.
a place where historical records and documents are kept.

entry.def: A keeper of archives or records.

entry.ety: F. archivolte, fr. It. archivolto; pref. archi- + volto vault, arch. See Vault
entry.def: The architectural member surrounding the curved opening of an arch, corresponding to the architrave in the case of a square opening.
More commonly, the molding or other ornaments with which the wall face of the voussoirs of an arch is charged.
A large theorbo, or double-necked lute, formerly in use, having the bass strings doubled with an octave, and the higher strings with a unison.
In an arch manner; with attractive slyness or roguishness; slyly; waggishly.
entry.q: Archly the maiden smiled.

entry.def: The grand marshal of the old German empire, a dignity that to the Elector of Saxony.
The quality of being arch; cleverness; sly humor free from malice; waggishness.

entry.ety: L. archon, Gr. �, �, ruler, chief magistrate, p. pr. of � to be first, to rule
entry.def: One of the chief magistrates in ancient Athens, especially, by preëminence, the first of the nine chief magistrates.
The office of an archon.
An archon's term of office.
The group including man alone.
The substance from which attraction spheres develop in mitotic cell division, and of which they consist.

entries.entry: Arc light. Elec The light of an arc lamp. See arc lamp under lamp.

entry.def: An archbishop or other chief prelate.
Same as Archpriest.
The absolute dominion of presbytery.
A chief priest; also, a kind of vicar, or a rural dean.
The chief primate.

entries.entry: Arch" stone`. A wedge-shaped stone used in an arch; a voussoir.

entry.def: A chief or transcendent traitor.
A chief treasurer. Specifically, the great treasurer of the German empire.
A way or passage under an arch.
A big, masculine wife.
Arch-shaped.
Arched; as, archy brows.

entries.entry:
*ar"chy. Gr. �, fr. � chief. See Arch- pref
A suffix properly meaning a rule ruling, as in monarchy, the rule of one only. Cf. -arch.

entry.def: Having the form of an arch; curved.
An instrument for drawing a circular arc without the use of a central point; a cyclograph.

entry.ety: L. arctus shut in, narrow, p. p. of arcere to shut in: cf. F. arctation
entry.def: Constriction or contraction of some natural passage, as in constipation from inflammation.

entry.note: ☞ The arctic circle is a lesser circle, parallel to the equator, 23° 28' from the north pole. This and the antarctic circle are called the polar circles, and between these and the poles lie the frigid zones. See Zone.
entry.ety: OE. artik, OF. artique, F. arctique, L. arcticus, fr. Gr. �, fr. � a bear, also a northern constellation so called; akin to L. ursus bear, Skr. �ksha
entry.def: Pertaining to, or situated under, the northern constellation called the Bear; northern; frigid; as, the arctic pole, circle, region, ocean; an arctic expedition, night, temperature.

sn.def: The arctic circle.
A warm waterproof overshoe.
a stout-bodied broad-winged moth with conspicuously striped or spotted wings; larvae are hairy caterpillars.
a family comprising the tiger moths.

entry.def: A group of Arachnida. See Illust. in Appendix.

sn.def: the burdock.
a genus of fur seals.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to arctic lands; as, the arctogeal fauna.
A group of the Carnivora, that includes the bears, weasels, etc.

sn.def: a genus of plants including the bearberry; manzanita.
a genus of herbs and subshrubs: African daisy.

entry.note: ☞ Arcturus has sometimes been incorrectly used as the name of the constellation, or even of Ursa Major.
entry.ety: L. Arcturus, Gr. � bearward, equiv. to �; � bear + � ward, guard. See Arctic
entry.def: A fixed star of the first magnitude in the constellation Boötes.
entry.q: Canst thou guide Arcturus with his sons [Rev. Ver.: “the Bear with her train”].

cs.cd: that in which the unit angle has its measuring arc equal to the radius of the circle.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an arc.

entry.ety: L. arcuatus, p. p. of arcuare to shape like a bow, fr. arcus. See Arc
entry.def: Bent or curved in the form of a bow.
entry.q: Arcuatestalks.

entry.def: In the form of a bow.

sn.def: The act of bending or curving; incurvation; the state of being bent; crookedness.
A mode of propagating trees by bending branches to the ground, and covering the small shoots with earth; layering.

entry.def: A crossbow.
A crossbowman; one who used the arcubalist.
See Arquebus.

entries.entry: -ard -art . The termination of many English words; as, coward, reynard, drunkard, mostly from the French, in which language this ending is of German origin, being orig. the same word as English hard. It usually has the sense of one who has to a high or excessive degree the quality expressed by the root; as, braggart, sluggard .

entry.ety: F. (cf. Sp. ardacina), fr. ardasse a kind of silk thread, fr. Ar. & Per. ardan a kind of raw silk
entry.def: A very fine sort of Persian silk.

sn.def: a familu of wading birds incuding the herons, egrets, night herons, and bitterns.
Heat.
Warmth of passion or affection; ardor; vehemence; eagerness; as, the ardency of love or zeal.
a wooded plateau in the Champagne-Ardenne region of France; the site of intense fighting in World Wars I and II.

entry.ety: OE. ardaunt, F. ardant, p. pr. of arder to burn, fr. L. ardere

sn.def: Hot or burning; causing a sensation of burning; fiery; as, ardent spirits, that is, distilled liquors; an ardent fever.
Having the appearance or quality of fire; fierce; glowing; shining; as, ardent eyes.
Warm, applied to the passions and affections; passionate; fervent; zealous; vehement; as, ardent love, feelings, zeal, hope, temper.
sn.q: An ardent and impetuous race.
sn.syn: Burning; hot; fiery; glowing; intense; fierce; vehement; eager; zealous; keen; fervid; fervent; passionate; affectionate.

entry.def: In an ardent manner; eagerly; with warmth; affectionately; passionately.
Ardency.
any type of strongly alcoholic beverage prepared by distillation of an alcohol-containing fermented material.

entries.entry: Ar`dois" sys"tem. Naut A widely used system of electric night signals in which a series of double electric lamps (white and red) is arranged vertically on a mast, and operated from a keyboard below. Archaic

entry.ety: L. ardor, fr. ardere to burn: cf. OF. ardor ardur, F. ardeur

sn.def: Heat, in a literal sense; as, the ardor of the sun's rays.
Warmth or heat of passion or affection; eagerness; zeal; as, he pursues study with ardor; the fought with ardor; martial ardor.
Bright and effulgent spirits; seraphim.

entry.usage: Arduous Hard Difficult. Hard is simpler, blunter, and more general in sense than difficult; as, a hard duty to perform, hard work, a hard task, one which requires much bodily effort and perseverance to do. Difficult commonly implies more skill and sagacity than hard, as when there is disproportion between the means and the end. A work may be hard but not difficult. We call a thing arduous when it requires strenuous and persevering exertion, like that of one who is climbing a precipice; as, an arduous task, an arduous duty. “It is often difficult to control our feelings; it is still harder to subdue our will; but it is an arduous undertaking to control the unruly and contending will of others.”
entry.ety: L. arduus steep, high; akin to Ir. ard high, height

sn.def: Steep and lofty, in a literal sense; hard to climb.
sn.q: Those arduous paths they trod.

sn.def: Attended with great labor, like the ascending of acclivities; difficult; laborious; as, an arduous employment, task, or enterprise.

entry.def: In an arduous manner; with difficulty or laboriousness.
The quality of being arduous; difficulty of execution.
Burning; ardent.
entry.q: Lo! further on, Where flames the arduous Spirit of Isidore.

entries.entry:
Are. AS. (Northumbrianaron, akin to the 1st pers. pl. forms, Icel. erum, Goth. sijum, L. sumus, Gr. �, Skr. smas; all from a root as. � See Am and Is, and cf. Be
The present indicative plural of the substantive verb to be; but etymologically a different word from be, or was. Am art are, and is, all come from the root as.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. area. See Area
entry.def: The unit of superficial measure, being a square of which each side is ten meters in length; 100 square meters, or about 119.6 square yards.

entries.entry:
A"re*a
Dry area. See under Dry.
ā"r�*ȧ; 277 n.; pl.Areas -ȧz . L. area a broad piece of level ground. Cf. Are n.
Any plane surface, as of the floor of a room or church, or of the ground within an inclosure; an open space in a building. The Alban lake . . . looks like the area of some vast amphitheater.
The inclosed space on which a building stands.
The sunken space or court, giving ingress and affording light to the basement of a building.
An extent of surface; a tract of the earth's surface; a region; as, vast uncultivated areas .
Geom The superficial contents of any figure; the surface included within any given lines; superficial extent; as, the area of a square or a triangle.
Biol A spot or small marked space; as, the germinative area .
Extent; scope; range; as, a wide area of thought. The largest area of human history and man's common nature.

entry.ety: OE. areden, AS. ārǣdan to interpret. See Read

sn.def: To tell, declare, explain, or interpret; to divine; to guess; as, to aread a riddle or a dream.
sn.q: Therefore more plain aread this doubtful case.

sn.def: To read.
To counsel, advise, warn, or direct.
sn.q: But mark what I aread thee now. Avaunt!

sn.def: To decree; to adjudge.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an area; as, areal interstices (the areas or spaces inclosed by the reticulate vessels of leaves.
To raise; to set up; to stir up.
Backward; in or to the rear; behindhand.

entry.ety: Canarese adiki: cf. Pg. & Sp. areca
entry.def: A genus of palms, one species of which (Areca catechu) produces the areca nut, or betel nut, which is chewed in India and Southeast Asia with the leaf of the Piper Betle and lime.

sn.def: one of four subclasses or superorder of Monocotyledones; comprises about 6400 species in 5 families of trees and shrubs and terrestrial herbs and a few free-floating aquatics including: Palmae; Araceae; Pandanaceae: and Lemnaceae.

entries.entry: A*re"co*line n. Also -lin . From NL. Areca, a genus of palms bearing betel nut An oily liquid substance, C8H13O2N, the chief alkaloid of the betel nut, to which the latter owes its anthelmintic action. arecholine; arecaline; methylarecaidin; methyl N-methyltetrahydronicotinate; 1,2,5,6-tetrahydro-1-methyl-3-pyridinecarboxylic acid methyl ester.

entry.def: In a reeking condition.
The act of drying, or the state of growing dry.
entry.q: The arefaction of the earth.

entry.def: To dry, or make dry.

entries.entry:
A*re"na n.; pl. E. Arenas; L. Arenæ . L. arena harena, sand, a sandy place
Rom. Antiq The area in the central part of an amphitheater, in which the gladiators fought and other shows were exhibited; -- so called because it was covered with sand.
Any place of public contest or exertion; any sphere of action; as, the arenaof debate; the arena of life.
Med “Sand” or “gravel” in the kidneys.

entry.def: Sandy or consisting largely of sand; of the nature of sand; easily disintegrating into sand; friable; as, arenaceous limestone.
Sandy; as, arenarious soil.
A sand bath; application of hot sand to the body.

entry.note: ☞ A person who rents an estate belonging to the crown is called crown arendator.
entry.ety: LL. arendator arrendator, fr. arendare arrendare, to pay rent, fr. arenda yearly rent; ad + renda, F. rente, E. rent. Cf. Arrentation and Rent
entry.def: In some provinces of Russia, one who farms the rents or revenues.
A palm tree (Saguerus saccharifer) which furnishes sago, wine, and fibers for ropes; the gomuti palm.

entry.ety: L. arena sand + colere to cherish or live
entry.def: An ancient wormhole in sand, preserved in the rocks.

sn.def: growing or living or burrowing in sand.

entry.ety: L. arena sand + Gr. li`qos stone
entry.def: Of or pertaining to sandstone; as, arenilitic mountains.
Sandy; full of sand.

entry.ety: L. arenula fine sand, dim. of arena
entry.def: Full of fine sand; like sand.

entries.entry:
A*re"o*la n.; pl.Areolæ. L. areola, dim. of area: cf. F. aréole. See Area
An interstice or small space, as between the cracks of the surface in certain crustaceous lichens; or as between the fibers composing organs or vessels that interlace; or as between the nervures of an insect's wing.
Anat. & Med The colored ring around the nipple, or around a vesicle or pustule.

cs.cd: a form of fibrous connective tissue in which the fibers are loosely arranged with numerous spaces, or areolæ, between them.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or like, an areola; filled with interstices or areolæ.
Divided into small spaces or areolations, as the wings of insects, the leaves of plants, or the receptacle of compound flowers.

sn.def: Division into areolæ.
Any small space, bounded by some part different in color or structure, as the spaces bounded by the nervures of the wings of insects, or those by the veins of leaves; an areola.

entry.def: Same as Areola.
A small inclosed area; esp. one of the small spaces on the wings of insects, circumscribed by the veins.

entry.ety: Gr. 'araio`s thin, rare + -meter: cf. F. aréomètre
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the specific gravity of fluids; a form hydrometer.
Pertaining to, or measured by, an areometer.
The art or process of measuring the specific gravity of fluids.
See Areopagite.
A member of the Areopagus.
Pertaining to the Areopagus.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, and � �, hill of Ares (Mars' Hill)
entry.def: The highest judicial court at Athens. Its sessions were held on Mars' Hill. Hence, any high court or tribunal
See Intercolumniation, and Aræostyle.
See Intercolumniation, and Aræosystyle.
See Arear.
A support for the spear when couched for the attack.

entry.ety: OE. aretten, OF. areter; aL. ad) + OF. reter, L. reputare. See Repute
entry.def: To reckon; to ascribe; to impute.
The ethical theory which excludes all relations between virtue and happiness; the science of virtue; -- contrasted with eudemonics.

entry.ety: F., lit., a sharp fish bone, ridge, sharp edge, fr. L. arista beard of grain
entry.def: An acute and rugged crest of a mountain range or a subsidiary ridge between two mountain gorges.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � virtue + � discourse, � to speak: cf. F. arétologie
entry.def: That part of moral philosophy which treats of virtue, its nature, and the means of attaining to it.

entries.entry:
A*rew". adv. See Arow Row
In a row. Obs All her teetharew.

entry.def: Crude tartar. See Argol.
A ludicrous corruption of the Latin word ergo, therefore.

entry.note: ☞ The bearded argali is the aoudad. See Aoudad. The name is also applied to the bighorn sheep of the Rocky Mountains. See Bighorn.
entry.def: A species of wild sheep (Ovis ammon, or Ovis argali), remarkable for its large horns. It inhabits the mountains of Siberia and central Asia.
The adjutant bird.

entries.entry:
Ar"gand lamp`
Argand burner a burner for an Argand lamp, or a gas burner in which the principle of that lamp is applied. . Named from the inventor, Aimé Argand of Geneva A lamp with a circular hollow wick and glass chimney which allow a current of air both inside and outside of the flame.

entry.def: A genus of venomous ticks which attack men and animals. The famous Persian Argas, also called Miana bug, is Argas Persicus; that of Central America, called talaje by the natives, is Argas Talaje.
